    The information requested on this form must be completed in order to submit a document electronically for
    review under the Massachusetts Environmental Policy Act, 301 CMR 11.00.
    Project Name: Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs
    Street Address: Suffolk Downs Racecourse
    Municipality: East Boston and Revere                           Watershed: Boston Harbor
    Universal Transverse Mercator Coordinates:                     Latitude: 42° 23' 51.219" N

    Project Type: Mixed Use                                        Status of project design: 25% complete

    Does this project meet or exceed a mandatory EIR threshold (see 301 CMR 11.03)?             Yes     No

    If this is an Expanded Environmental Notification Form (ENF) (see 301 CMR 11.05(7)) or a
    Notice of Project Change (NPC), are you requesting:
         a Single EIR? (see 301 CMR 11.06(8))                     Yes    No
         a Special Review Procedure? (see 301CMR 11.09)           Yes    No
         a Waiver of mandatory EIR? (see 301 CMR 11.11)           Yes    No
         a Phase I Waiver? (see 301 CMR 11.11)                    Yes    No
         (Note: Greenhouse Gas Emissions analysis must be included in the Expanded ENF.)

    Which MEPA review threshold(s) does the project meet or exceed (see 301 CMR 11.03)?
        301 CMR 11.03(1)(a)(1): direct alteration of 50 or more acres of land, unless the Project is
           consistent with an approved conservation farm plan or forest cutting plan or other similar
           generally accepted agricultural or forestry practices.
        301 CMR 11.03(5)(b)(4)(a): New discharge or Expansion in discharge to a sewer system of
           100,000 or more gpd of sewage.
        301 CMR 11:03(6)(a)(6): Generation of 3,000 or more new adt on roadways providing access to
           a single location.
        301 CMR 11.03(11)(b): Any Project within a designated ACEC.

1
     Project construction will commence following receipt of the gaming license and necessary permits and approvals beyond
     applicable appeal periods.
2
     The Proponent expects that Casino Area I will be completed within approximately 15 months of the beginning of
     construction, while the balance of the Project will be completed within 30 months. Proposed off-site improvements are
     expected to take approximately two years to complete.
Effective January 2011
    Which State Agency Permits will the project require?
    Massachusetts Gaming Commission: Category 1 Gaming License;

    Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection (MassDEP): Sewer Connection Permit, MA
    Clean Air Act Permit or Plan Approval, Superseding Order of Conditions (only on appeal, if
    necessary);

    Highway Division Category III Vehicular Access Permit;

    Department of Conservation and Recreation (DCR): Access Permit; and

    Massachusetts Water Resources Authority (MWRA): Sewer Use Discharge Permit (or waiver),
    Dewatering Permit (if required).

    Identify any financial assistance or land transfer from an Agency of the Commonwealth, including the Agency
    name and the amount of funding or land area in acres: N/A

       Gross square footage                              405,480               1,396,883            1,802,363
       Number of housing units                               0                      0                     0
       Maximum height (feet)                                88'                    78'                   166'

3
     Off-site Project elements related to the Boardman Street improvements and Route 1A flyover will also create 1.04 acres
     of impervious area, and will not involve any wetlands impacts, buildings, or wastewater.
4
     According to the applicable FEMA-FIRM maps 25025C0038G and 252025C0019G, a portion of the Project site is located
     within a mapped 100-year floodplain, Zone AE, Base Elevation 9 feet NGVD (15.46 feet Boston City Base). Under the
     Wetlands Protection Act regulations, the 100-year floodplain may be classified as Bordering Land Subject to Flooding
     (BLSF) (310 CMR 10.57) or Land Subject to Coastal Storm Flowage (LSCSF) (310 CMR 10.04) depending on site
     specific conditions and flooding characteristics. As described in further detail below, the Project has conservatively
     classified the 100-year floodplain as BLSF based on two open Orders of Conditions issued by the Boston and Revere
     Conservation Commissions in 2011 (MassDEP File Nos. 006-1276 and 061-0620).
5
     Existing and proposed square footage does not include existing horse barns.
6
     As defined in the Boston Zoning Code.

7
    Under existing conditions, the Project site generates trips associated with the Suffolk Downs Racetrack which, although
    somewhat seasonal in nature, is operational throughout the year. In addition, the three vehicular site access points (Rte
    1A/Tomasello Drive, Rte 145/Winthrop Avenue/Tomasello Drive, and Rte 1A/Furlong Drive) attract other users not
    associated with the Project site itself. These include trips associated with the retail plaza abutting the site on Furlong
    Drive and unrelated trips that utilize Tomasello Drive as a connection between Rte 1A and Rte 145/Winthrop Avenue. It
    is difficult to distinguish accurately between the different users of the three site access points. Therefore, the existing site
    trips include a summation of the Average Daily Trips (ADT) established by full-week Automatic Traffic Recorder (ATR)
    counts performed on each access roadway in July 2012.
8
    Based on preliminary analysis. The DEIR will present a comprehensive trip generation analysis to refine this estimate.
    See also Section 3.4 of Attachment A.
                                                            -3-
PROJECT DESCRIPTION:

Describe the existing conditions and land uses on the project site:

EXISTING CONDITIONS

Section 2.1 of the Supplemental Project Information in Attachment A describes existing conditions and the
geographic context of the Project site.

Describe the proposed project and its programmatic and physical elements:

PROPOSED PROJECT

Section 2.2 of the Supplemental Project Information in Attachment A contains a detailed Project description
that includes programmatic and physical elements; open space and landscaping plans are described in
Section 2.2.4. The Project's numerous public benefits are identified in Section 1.5, and the Proponent's
commitment to green design and practices is described in Section 2.3. Urban design elements of the
proposed Project, including sustainable design and Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)
goals, are described in Section 4.2.

POTENTIAL IMPACTS

Wetland Resource Areas/100-Year Floodplain: Potential impacts related to on-site wetland resource areas,
off-site wetland resource areas, and the 100-year floodplain are described in Section 4.1.6 of the
Supplemental Project Information in Attachment A.

Wastewater: Section 4.4.2 of the Supplemental Project Information in Attachment A addresses wastewater.
Estimated wastewater generation is quantified in Section 4.4.2.2, and sewer capacity and impacts are
described in Section 4.4.2.3.

Water: Section 4.4.3 of the Supplemental Project Information in Attachment A addresses water. Estimated
proposed water consumption is quantified in Section 4.4.3.2, and water system capacity and impacts are
described in Section 4.4.3.3.

Transportation: Section 3.0 contains an overview of transportation conditions relative to the Project that
includes data and information regarding the existing transportation system supporting the Project site, a
discussion of expected transportation characteristics of the Project, and proposed technical analyses and
information to be included in the Draft Environmental Impact Report (DEIR).

Air/Greenhouse Gas Emissions: Sections 4.1.5 and 4.1.11 of the Supplemental Project Information in
Attachment A address air quality and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, respectively. Due to the size of the
Project and the proposed changes in traffic operations, the potential air quality impacts will be modeled for
both existing and future conditions in the DEIR to demonstrate conformance with the National Ambient Air
Quality Standards. Project GHG emissions will come from three sources: (1) on-site fuel combustion in the
Central Utility Plant (CUP); (2) off-site emissions related to electricity provided by utilities and used on-site and

                                                 -4-
off-site for water supply and wastewater treatment; and (3) transportation-related emissions. All of these will
be described and quantified, and mitigation measures will be documented, in a GHG Analysis within the DEIR
in accordance with the Massachusetts Environmental Policy Act (MEPA) GHG Emissions Policy and Protocol.
At this time, the exact size and capacity of combustion units for the Project have not been finalized. Typical
boilers and emergency generators for development projects fall under the Environmental Results Program
(ERP) supervised by MassDEP. At the time of final design, it will be determined if preconstruction Air Plan
Approvals are required or post-construction ERP certifications are needed.

Historic/Archaeological Resources: The Project involves continued operations at the Suffolk Downs
racetrack with renovations to the grandstand, clubhouse, and barn area. Proposed improvements will be
reviewed with the Massachusetts Historical Commission (MHC) as plans are developed.

Construction-Period Air and Noise: Construction-period air and noise impacts are described in Sections
4.5.1 and 4.5.2, respectively.

INFRASTRUCTURE REQUIREMENTS

The Proponent will coordinate the design of the proposed water, drainage, and sewer connections with the
Boston Water and Sewer Commission (BWSC). The appropriate permits and approvals will be acquired prior
to construction.

Sewage System: Section 4.4.2.1 of Attachment A describes existing sewage infrastructure, as well as the
Project's anticipated sewage generation; proposed wastewater infrastructure is described in Section 4.4.2.4.

Water Supply System: Existing water infrastructure is described in Section 4.4.3.1 of Attachment A, and
proposed water infrastructure is addressed in Section 4.4.3.4.

Stormwater: The Project includes a new stormwater management system that will significantly improve
existing conditions and thereby improve the water quality of nearby wetlands and water bodies (see Section
4.4.4 of Attachment A). In addition, the proposed development will decrease impervious area on the site by
approximately nine acres, thereby reducing the rate and volume of stormwater leaving the site. A combination
of new conventional and Low-Impact Development (LID) drainage Best Management Practices (BMPs) will be
included as part of the site's drainage design to improve water quality treatment. Proposed stormwater BMPs
will likely include catch basins with deep sumps and hoods, water quality swales, bioretention basins, and
proprietary water quality units, when necessary to meet design standards. The Proponent will continue to
explore the feasibility of incorporating additional sustainable stormwater mitigation techniques such as
constructed stormwater wetlands and rainwater harvesting. These BMPs will be further evaluated as the
design progresses. Project compliance with MassDEP Stormwater Management Standards is discussed in
Section 4.4.4.4 of Attachment A.

Additional Utility Connections: Energy and site utilities are discussed in Section 4.4.1 of the Supplemental
Project Information (see Attachment A). In summary, new power service will be brought to the site to supply
the Project's electrical needs. The incoming power feed from the electric utility will terminate in one or two
customer stations located on the site. Power will be routed underground from the stations to main electrical
service in the CUP. Natural gas will be provided via a new or existing service, as will water supply and
wastewater disposal. Mechanical and electrical systems will be designed to meet requirements of the
                                               -5-
Massachusetts Stretch Energy Code and to achieve the energy use requirements of the Stretch Code and the
LEED standard(s). The Proponent anticipates that the Project will include at least the following energy
efficiency measures: high-efficiency chillers, condensing boilers, water- and air-side economizers, heat
recovery, high-efficiency lighting with energy-saving lighting controls, and water-conserving plumbing fixtures.

NOTE: The project description should summarize both the project's direct and indirect impacts (including
construction period impacts) in terms of their magnitude, geographic extent, duration and frequency, and
reversibility, as applicable. It should also discuss the infrastructure requirements of the project and the capacity
of the municipal and/or regional infrastructure to sustain these requirements into the future.

Describe the on-site project alternatives (and alternative off-site locations, if applicable), considered by the
proponent, including at least one feasible alternative that is allowed under current zoning, and the reasons(s)
that they were not selected as the preferred alternative:

ALTERNATIVES

Even with its abundance of open space and view corridors, without expanded gaming it is not financially viable
to maintain the 161-acre Project site solely as a thoroughbred racetrack. For over ten years, the Suffolk Downs
owners have sustained the racetrack use at a huge economic loss with the hope that gaming legislation would
permit a compatible entertainment use which could be used to permit the continued existence of the site as a
racetrack venue. Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs represents that compatible alternative.

The current use (i.e., the No Build Alternative) is not a feasible or practical economic alternative for the use of
the site. As currently zoned, the land in both Boston and Revere, including the area in East Boston specifically
zoned as an Economic Development Area (EDA), would yield its highest and best use for the owners as a
mixed commercial/residential use with its proximity to Logan Airport, two existing Massachusetts Bay
Transportation Authority (MBTA) stations, and downtown Boston with an existing network of adjacent highways
and connector roads.

For a comparative environmental impact analysis, as well as a comparative analysis of public benefits and
mitigation, it is fortunate that redevelopment of the entire 161-acre Project site for mixed uses was studied in
2006. Specifically, Vanasse & Associates, Inc. (in consultation with the Cities of Revere and Boston, DCR, the
Massachusetts Highway Department, and the MBTA) conducted a feasibility study to assess the impacts of the
potential redevelopment of the site with respect to access and off-site improvements that may be required to
accommodate such redevelopment. The study considered a mixed-use development including 3,236
residential units (consisting of 1,618 rental apartment units and 1,618 condominium units) together with
698,305 square feet of retail and restaurant uses.

The proposed mixed use development would have utilized the majority of the open space at the site, including
the racetrack and infield area (which will be preserved as part of the proposed casino development).
Comparing results of that analysis to impacts of the proposed Project using the site as a destination resort
casino, racetrack, and ancillary development shows the Project as proposed will avoid and minimize damage to
the environment. Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs, as now proposed, will not only minimize new acres of land
altered, but will actually decrease impervious area from 70 acres to 61 acres. In contrast to the mixed use




                                                -6-
development alternative, there will be no additional BVW wetlands alteration. The most significant
environmental impact under both development alternatives is the generation of new traffic and its resultant air
quality impacts.

From a transportation perspective, there are three important distinctions among the alternatives, each
discussed in the following paragraphs, all of which support the preferred alternative.

First, a destination resort casino's traffic patterns are starkly different from a mixed-use development's traffic
patterns in terms of peaking characteristics. Peak hours for a mixed-use development typically coincide with
the peak commuting periods on the roadway network. Peak hours for traffic associated with the proposed
destination resort casino, in contrast, are not expected to coincide with commuter peaks, thus reducing impacts
to traffic operations.

Second, the amount and degree of private financial investment into local and regional transportation
infrastructure improvements is drastically different under the statutorily-mandated gaming legislation than it is
under traditional development scenarios.         Under the 2006 mixed use development scenario, traffic
improvements would have consisted of normal or somewhat aggressive signalization improvements, lane
additions and alterations, intersection improvements, etc. Under the proposed destination resort casino
development, major new roadway infrastructure will be designed in coordination with the Massachusetts
Department of Transportation (MassDOT) and the City of Boston, and constructed with private funds, along
Route 1A in the vicinity of the site. These improvements could include a northbound flyover at Boardman
Street, an additional southbound lane on Route 1A, and signalization of both the Waldemar Avenue intersection
and the Tomasello Drive intersection to improve safety and enhance access to the neighborhood and the
Project site. Improvements at the Route 1/Route 16 interchange and along Revere Beach Parkway will also be
evaluated in coordination with MassDOT, DCR, and the cities of Revere and Chelsea to address long-standing
regional traffic issues, and the Proponent will assist in funding additional locally-desired roadway and safety
improvements. This discussion does not include alternatives for the proposed off-site transportation
improvements because, given the traffic demand patterns and existing bridge and roadway network, there is no
feasible alternative to what is proposed.

Third, the effectiveness and types of TDM programs that can be considered and implemented for a traditional
residential/commercial mixed use development are often somewhat limited. The TDM program associated with
the consolidated management of the Project, in contrast, will go beyond traditional TDM concepts to provide a
multi-modal transportation plan for the Project, possibly including shuttle services and transportation linkages
with other entertainment and tourism venues across the region.

In addition, the Project will increase open space, including pervious open space, whereas the considered
alternative would reduce open space on the Project site.

In summary, environmental impacts from the Project will be less than the impacts of any reasonably-sized
development alternative at the site, and the public infrastructure investment and improvements constructed or
funded by the Project will be far superior even without considering the jobs, local revenues, mandated
infrastructure and mitigation investments, and tourism multiplier effects that the Project will generate, which a
traditional mixed use development would not.



                                               -7-
The reason that the owners of the site are pursuing the preferred alternative, Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs,
rather than the alternative as a full-site commercial/residential mixed use development is that Caesars Resort
at Suffolk Downs combines the financial strength of a destination casino resort with the green space and
agricultural-sector benefits of the existing thoroughbred racetrack and helps them meet their long-term goal of
keeping racing alive at historic Suffolk Downs.

NOTE: The purpose of the alternatives analysis is to consider what effect changing the parameters and/or siting
of a project, or components thereof, will have on the environment, keeping in mind that the objective of the
MEPA review process is to avoid or minimize damage to the environment to the greatest extent feasible.
Examples of alternative projects include alternative site locations, alternative site uses, and alternative site
configurations.

Summarize the mitigation measures proposed to offset the impacts of the preferred alternative:

MITIGATION MEASURES

Transportation Demand Management (TDM): A comprehensive package of TDM actions and strategies to
reduce single-occupancy vehicle (SOV) travel by employees and patrons and encourage use of alternative
transportation modes will be presented in the DEIR.

Transit: The Proponent will collaborate with the MBTA to determine ways to enhance the connections
between the Suffolk Downs Station and the resort. Stronger pedestrian, bicycle and shuttle bus connections
will be made on-site to promote use of the station. The DEIR will include details of these proposed
improvements.

Pedestrian Access: The Project site layout has been designed to encourage pedestrian activity to and from
the site by making appropriate connections to the existing off-site pedestrian network in the area.
The Project recognizes the existing connection between the Orient Heights neighborhood and the retail stores
located north of the site, and the Project site plan will enhance and strengthen the safety and quality of this
pedestrian link.

Pedestrian accommodations and safety will be afforded priority in the design development of off-site
infrastructure. Pedestrian improvements incorporating "Complete Streets" principles will be identified in the
DEIR analysis.

Bicycle Access; The Project's proposed expansion of the existing bicycle network would extend bicycle
accommodations from Saratoga Street along Bennington Street to Eliot Circle at Revere Beach. This
connection would provide the area with an almost continuous route between the East Boston waterfront,
Constitution Beach, and the front entrance to DCR's Belle Isle Marsh and Revere Beach, connecting several
residential neighborhoods with retail, recreation, and transportation opportunities. The Proponent also plans to
provide a spur connection from the Bennington Street corridor to the site to support Project employees and
patrons with bicycle access to the site.

Bicycle paths and connections will be integrated into the Project site plans, and secure bicycle parking will be
provided at the employee entrances and at locations convenient for patrons. Bicycle improvements
incorporating "Complete Streets" principles will be identified in the DEIR analysis.
                                               -8-
Traffic and Roadway Infrastructure: The Project includes major off-site roadway, traffic, and safety
improvements, comprising new roadway infrastructure to be designed and constructed in consultation with
MassDOT and the City of Boston on Route 1A in the vicinity of the site. These improvements could include a
Route 1A northbound flyover at Boardman Street, an additional Route 1A southbound lane, traffic signal
control at Waldemar Avenue, and signalization of the Tomasello Drive intersection to address existing local
and regional traffic difficulties at Boardman Street, improve safety, and provide ample capacity to
accommodate Project trips entering and exiting the site.

In addition, as part of the discussions for the Host and Surrounding Community Agreements, the cities of
Revere and Chelsea have asked that existing regional traffic issues along the Route 60 and Route 1 corridors
be studied to identify and assist in funding potential improvements. New ramp connections at the Route
1/Route 16 interchange and improvements along the Revere Beach Parkway corridor have been identified as
potential mid-term improvements, which would shift some regional and Project traffic from the Route 60
corridor to Route 1/Route 16. Such strategic new connections, and other improvements along the Revere
Beach Boulevard corridor, would be developed in consultation with MassDOT, DCR, and the cities of Revere
and Chelsea, and would be expected to address long-standing regional traffic issues in the Cities of Revere
and Chelsea along the Route 60 corridor through Butler Circle and Bell Circle, as well as along Route
16/Revere Beach Parkway between Webster Avenue and the split to Route 145.

A full analysis of these and other infrastructure improvements will be presented in the DEIR. The design of
local traffic and roadway improvements will be developed incorporating "Complete Streets" principles.

Wetland Resource Areas: Wetland resource area impacts associated with the on-site development work is
limited to minor re-grading to install stormwater management BMPs (e.g., rip rap, flared end structures) within
the 25-foot Riverfront Area of Sales Creek, portions of which are previously developed and degraded as
defined by the Wetlands Protection Act regulations (310 CMR 10.58(5)). The Project does not propose to alter
Sales Creek nor does it propose any activities in Bordering Vegetated Wetlands (BVW) located elsewhere
along the perimeter of the Site.

Activities proposed in the 100-year floodplain will occur primarily in two locations: (1) in the vicinity of the
proposed entrance drive and traffic circle area at the southern end of the site; and (2) in the parking lot located
at the north end of the Project site. These activities will likely include raising site elevations in some areas to
construct the interior driveways and parking areas, utility connections and stormwater management system
improvements. The work will occur in previously developed areas comprised of pavement or urban fill. As
previously noted, under the Wetlands Protection Act regulations, the 100-year floodplain may be classified as
Bordering Land Subject to Flooding (BLSF, 310 CMR 10.57) or Land Subject to Coastal Storm Flowage
(LSCSF, 310 CMR 10.04) depending on site specific conditions and flooding characteristics. The Proponent
has conservatively classified the 100-year floodplain as BLSF based on two open Orders of Conditions issued
by the Boston and Revere Conservation Commissions in 2011 (MassDEP File Nos. 006-1276 and 061-0620).
The Proponent has been made aware that there may be differing interpretations based on specific site
characteristics and specific storm conditions because, even though no portion of the property is subject to tidal
action, the site may experience flooding due to one or more causes during extreme (e.g., 100-year flood)
events and the floodplain may therefore be characterized as Land Subject to Coastal Storm Flowage (LSCSF).
The Proponent intends to work in consultation with the local Conservation Commissions to explore this matter
further. Neither BLSF nor LSCSF have a 100-foot Buffer Zone as defined by the Wetlands Protection Act
regulations. As a general rule, filling LSCSF located in an A-zone does not require compensatory flood storage
                                                -9-
    as is required in BLSF. The reason lies with the vast size of the ocean as a water body in comparison with
    inland water bodies.9 Compliance with the Wetlands Protection Act regulations is generally demonstrated by
    complying with the construction provisions of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) as
    incorporated in the State Building Code at 780 CMR 3107.

    The Proponent currently plans to provide compensatory flood storage to mitigate potential impacts from
    flooding as is required under 310 CMR 10.57. The compensatory storage will result in floodplain storage
    capacity equivalent to or exceeding the existing floodplain storage capacity on the property. Exact locations of
    floodplain compensation areas will be further defined as the site design progresses.

    With regard to activities proposed in the 100-foot buffer zone, erosion controls comprised of hay bales and
    siltation fence will be installed along the limit of work line in these locations to protect the adjacent wetland
    resource areas.

    Off-Site Wetland Resource Areas: The off-site roadway improvements associated with the Project currently
    include approximately 40,000 square feet of work within LSCSF and approximately 20,000 square feet of work
    within the 100-foot buffer zone to Coastal Bank and Salt Marsh. A 25-foot Riverfront Area (in Boston) and 200-
    foot Riverfront Area (in Revere) is associated with the Chelsea River, however this resource does not extend
    into the proposed work area. Work proposed in LSCSF and buffer zone will occur in or immediately adjacent to
    areas that are presently developed (i.e. paved surfaces). Measures to prevent adverse impacts will include
    installation of erosion and sedimentation controls and installation of measures to treat stormwater runoff from
    adjacent roadways. Please see Figure 4-1 in Section 4.0, Off Site Wetland Resource Areas for a graphical
    depiction of these resource areas. The current design does not currently result in alterations to other wetland
    resource areas located in the vicinity of the proposed work zone including Riverfront Area, Salt Marsh and
    Coastal Bank.
     
    Water and Sewer: The Proponent will work closely with the BWSC to ensure the design and capacity of the
    proposed wastewater infrastructure will avoid adverse impacts to the existing BWSC 12-inch sanitary sewer
    gravity main. In addition, the Proponent will submit a General Service Application and site plan for review as
    the Project progresses. All proposed improvements and connections to BWSC infrastructure will be reviewed
    as part of the BWSC site plan review process. This process will include a comprehensive design review of
    proposed service connections, an assessment of estimated Project demands and system capacity, and the
    establishment of service accounts.

    The State Building Code requires the use of water-conserving fixtures. Water conservation measures such as
    low-flow toilets and restricted flow faucets will reduce the domestic water demand on the existing distribution
    system. Sensor-operated sinks with water-conserving aerators and sensor-operated toilets will be installed in
    all restrooms. All new water services will be installed in accordance with the latest local, state, and federal
    codes and standards. Backflow preventers will be installed at domestic and fire protection service
    connections. New meters will be installed with Meter Transmitter Units as part of the BWSC's Automatic
    Meter Reading (AMR) system.




9
    Dawson, Alexandra D. and Sally A. Zielinksi. Environmental Handbook for Massachusetts Conservation
    Commissioners. Ninth Edition. Belmont, MA: Massachusetts Association of Conservation Commissions, 2006, 656 pp.
                                                   - 10 -
Stormwater and Erosion Control: The Project includes a new stormwater management system that will
significantly improve existing conditions. A detailed discussion of proposed stormwater management is
provided in Section 4.4.4.2 of Attachment A.

Various measures will also be utilized during construction to minimize potential adverse impacts from runoff.
Erosion and sediment control measures such as silt fence and hay bales will be installed to protect off-site
areas and BWSC storm drain systems. Existing and proposed catch basins will be protected with filter fabric,
hay bales, and/or crushed stone to remove sediment from runoff during construction. These controls will be
inspected and maintained throughout construction until disturbed areas have been stabilized by the placement
of pavement, structure, or vegetative cover. All necessary dewatering will be conducted in accordance with
applicable MWRA and BWSC discharge permits. Once construction is complete, the Project will be in
compliance with all local and state stormwater management policies to the maximum extent practicable (see
Section 4.4.4.4 of Attachment A).

Energy: Mechanical and electrical systems will be designed to meet requirements of the Massachusetts
Stretch Energy Code and to achieve the energy use requirements of the Stretch Code and the LEED standard.
The Proponent anticipates that the Project will include at least the following energy efficiency measures: high-
efficiency chillers, condensing boilers, water- and air-side economizers, heat recovery, high-efficiency lighting
with energy-saving lighting controls, and water-conserving plumbing fixtures.

Construction-Period: Construction-period mitigation measures, including adherence to a Construction
Management Plan (CMP), are described in Section 4.5.6 of the Supplemental Project Information in
Attachment A.

If the project is proposed to be constructed in phases, please describe each phase:

PROJECT SEQUENCING

The Project schedule is described in Section 2.4 of the Supplemental Project Information in Attachment A.

AREAS OF CRITICAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERN:
Is the project within or adjacent to an Area of Critical Environmental Concern?
            Yes (Specify: Rumney Marshes ACEC)             No
     if yes, does the ACEC have an approved Resource Management Plan? X Yes ___ No;

    if yes, describe how the project complies with this plan:

    The Rumney Marshes ACEC Salt Marsh Restoration Plan identifies priority projects to restore
    degraded salt marsh within the ACEC. Sales Creek and Belle Isle Inlet are within the Rumney
    Marshes ACEC. The Project will not have any impacts to salt marsh. On the contrary, the Project
    will significantly improve the quality of stormwater discharged from the property relative to
    existing conditions by incorporating a mix of LID and new, conventional BMPs into the site design
    to provide water quality treatment.

STORMWATER MANAGEMENT:

Generally describe the project's stormwater impacts and measures that the project will take to comply with the
standards found in MassDEP's Stormwater Management Regulations:

The Project includes a new stormwater management system that will significantly improve water quality
as compared with existing conditions. In addition, the proposed development will decrease impervious
area on the site by approximately nine acres, thereby reducing the rate and volume of stormwater
leaving the site. A combination of conventional and LID drainage BMPs will be included as part of the
site's drainage design. Furthermore, installation of stormwater BMPs designed in accordance with


                                                 - 12 -
MassDEP's Stormwater Management Guidelines will improve water quality treatment. The new
drainage system will significantly improve the quality of water discharged relative to existing
conditions.

A detailed discussion of proposed stormwater management is provided in Section 4.4.4.2 of
Attachment A, and specific Project compliance with MassDEP Stormwater Management Standards is
discussed in Section 4.4.4.4 of Attachment A.

MASSACHUSETTS CONTINGENCY PLAN:
Has the project site been, or is it currently being, regulated under M.G.L.c.21E or the Massachusetts
Contingency Plan? Yes X No ___ ; if yes, please describe the current status of the site (including Release
Tracking Number (RTN), cleanup phase, and Response Action Outcome classification):

On February 21, 1997, the site was reported to MassDEP by its previous owner, Belle Isle Limited
Partnership, for a release in soil and groundwater related to heavy metals, petroleum, and polyaromatic
hydrocarbons. The reportable conditions were identified during a due diligence environmental
investigation completed in association with a real estate transaction, and the site was assigned
Release Tracking Number (RTN) 3-14857.

Completion of a subsequent subsurface investigation, sampling, and testing program of soil and
groundwater media and a Method 3 Risk Characterization by Rizzo Associates, Inc. (Rizzo) found a
condition of No Significant Risk to human health or the environment. Rizzo ultimately closed the file
under the Massachusetts Contingency Plan (MCP) in February 1998 by submitting a Permanent
Solution Class B-1 Response Action Outcome (RAO) to MassDEP (RAO Statement, Suffolk Downs, East
Boston and Revere, MA, RTN 3-14857, February 12, 1998, prepared by Rizzo Associates, Inc.). No
Activity and Use Limitation (AUL) has been placed on the property and none is proposed in connection
with the preferred alternative. The preferred alternative does not involve disturbance of the easement
area in the Revere portion of the racetrack infield in which the Commonwealth may have deposited
materials dredged from the Sales Creek drainage channel in the early 1980s.

Additional subsurface investigations with soil and groundwater sampling and testing were completed
by GEI Consultants, Inc. in 2007. The resulting Phase I/II report (Phase I/Phase II Environmental Site
Assessment, Suffolk Downs, East Boston and Revere, MA, GEI Consultants, Inc., February 14, 2007)
notes that the further testing in 2007 confirmed low levels of various analytes in soil and/or
groundwater which are relatively common at urban sites and are entirely consistent with the 1998
Permanent Solution RAO.

Is there an Activity and Use Limitation (AUL) on any portion of the project site? Yes ___ No X ;
if yes, describe which portion of the site and how the project will be consistent with the AUL: _____________.
MassDEP has clarified in previous guidance that hotels are not considered to be a residential use, AULs are
not expected to be required for this Project.

Are you aware of any Reportable Conditions at the property that have not yet been assigned an RTN?
Yes ___ No X ; if yes, please describe:

SOLID AND HAZARDOUS WASTE:

If the project will generate solid waste during demolition or construction, describe alternatives considered for re-
use, recycling, and disposal of, e.g., asphalt, brick, concrete, gypsum, metal, wood:

The Proponent will reuse or recycle demolition and construction materials to the greatest extent
feasible. Construction procedures will allow for the segregation, reuse, and recycling of materials such
as asphalt pavement. As described above, the existing grandstand building will be renovated, with new
gaming and restaurant functions incorporated below the seating area. During the demolition and
                                                - 13 -
renovation phases, appropriate measures to be identified in the CMP will be employed to provide
required demolition notices and manage materials arising from demolition and renovation, and all
recyclable materials will be sorted and diverted from landfills. Existing asphalt will be recycled and
may be reused on site. Recyclable construction and demolition waste, including packaging waste and
material scraps, will be sorted either on-site or hauled to a local sorting facility. Materials that cannot
be reused or recycled will be transported in covered trucks by a contract hauler to a licensed facility.
The Construction Management team will target a minimum diversion rate of 75%. Recyclable waste
from typical daily job site activities such as plastic beverage bottles, metal and glass containers,
cardboard, and paper waste will be collected, sorted, and recycled.

Site-specific information regarding environmental conditions related to the presence of oil and
hazardous materials was summarized in the above-referenced reports. Though the intent is to limit off-
site disposal or transport of excavated soils to the maximum extent practicable, foundation
construction and associated earthwork activities for the new buildings will likely generate some soil
that may require off-site transport. This soil will likely consist primarily of urban fill materials
generated from pile cap construction and installation of an on-site stormwater recharge system.
Chemical testing of the material will be required for acceptance by receiving facilities to confirm
chemical constituents and contaminants present. Additional testing of the specific soil material to be
generated is planned. Chemical testing of the material will be conducted prior to construction in
accordance with facility requirements.

Any material leaving the Project site will be required to be legally transported in accordance with local,
state and federal requirements. In addition, any unanticipated conditions related to oil or hazardous
materials will be managed in accordance with appropriate MassDEP regulatory requirements. In the
event that potential contaminants are detected, they will be compared with those constituents and
levels previously observed in the historical release which achieved a Permanent Solution RAO in 1998
under RTN 3-14857. If the contamination is consistent with that observed previously, there would be no
new reporting obligation to MassDEP under the MCP and construction could be managed outside of
the regulatory process as post-RAO construction. If this is not the case and there is evidence of new
or newly discovered contamination above reportable concentrations and above levels resolved by the
1998 Permanent Solution RAO, then a reporting obligation would exist and construction would need to
be completed under a Release Abatement Measure (RAM) Plan within the regulatory process. In any
case, the CMP will include construction-period dust control measures and will address construction
vehicle trips associated with any off-site soil transport. As previously noted, a draft CMP will be
provided in the DEIR. Also as previously noted, the Project does not involve disturbance of the
easement area in the Revere portion of the racetrack infield in which the Commonwealth may have
deposited materials dredged from the Sales Creek drainage channel in the early 1980s.

(NOTE: Asphalt pavement, brick, concrete and metal are banned from disposal at Massachusetts landfills and
waste combustion facilities and wood is banned from disposal at Massachusetts landfills. See 310 CMR
19.017 for the complete list of banned materials.)

Will your project disturb asbestos containing materials? Yes X No ___;
if yes, please consult state asbestos requirements at http://mass.gov/MassDEP/air/asbhom01.htm
Based on a February 14, 2007 Phase I/Phase II Environmental Site Assessment report completed by GEI
Consultants, Smith & Wessel of Merrimac, Massachusetts conducted an on-site inspection for
asbestos-containing building materials in select buildings on the Project site. Materials that tested
positive for asbestos included floor tile and paper, wall and ceiling panels, insulation, window glazing
compound, and door caulking. It is unclear whether the existing grandstand roof contains asbestos.
See Section 4.5.5 of the Supplemental Project Information in Attachment A.

Describe anti-idling and other measures to limit emissions from construction equipment:

The construction contract will require contractors to use a number of measures to reduce potential
emissions and minimize impacts from construction vehicles, including:
    Use wetting agents where needed on a scheduled basis;

                                              - 14 -
        Use covered trucks;
        Minimize exposed storage of debris on-site;
        Monitor construction practices to minimize unnecessary transfers and mechanical disturbances
        of loose materials;
        Store aggregate materials away from the areas of greatest pedestrian activity, where and when
        possible;
        Establish a tire cleaning area at the exit gate to prevent dirt from reaching the street;
        Clean streets and sidewalks regularly to minimize dust accumulations;
        Use appropriate mufflers on equipment, and properly maintain intake and exhaust mufflers;
        Use muffling enclosures on continuously-operating equipment (e.g., air compressors and
        welding generators);
        Use the most quiet construction operations, techniques, and equipment, where feasible;
        Schedule equipment operations to keep average noise levels low, synchronize noisiest
        operations with times of highest ambient noise levels, and maintain relatively uniform noise
        levels;
        Turn off idling equipment; and
        Use shielding or distance to separate noisy equipment from sensitive receptors.

LAND SECTION ­ all proponents must fill out this section
   I. Thresholds / Permits
      A. Does the project meet or exceed any review thresholds related to land (see 301 CMR 11.03(1)
          X Yes ___ No; if yes, specify each threshold:

         The Project exceeds the threshold at 301 CMR 11.03(1)(a)(1): direct alteration of 50 or more
         acres of land, unless the Project is consistent with an approved conservation farm plan or
         forest cutting plan or other similar generally accepted agricultural or forestry practices.
         The Project will alter 71.5 acres of land; it should be noted that the entire 161-acre Project
         site has been previously altered.

  III. Consistency
        A. Identify the current municipal comprehensive land use plan:
              Title: East Boston Master Plan Date April, 2000
                    City of Revere, Massachusetts, FY2010-2015 Strategic Plan

      B. Describe the project's consistency with that plan with regard to:
          1) economic development ­ The Project will create and support economic development
             and provide jobs for East Boston, Revere and the surrounding community.


                                                      -17-
    2) adequacy of infrastructure ­ The Project will improve existing infrastructure
       including transportation networks, enhance access to and from the MBTA Blue
       Line Suffolk Downs Station, and will upgrade pedestrian and shuttle connections
       to the Project site.

    3) open space impacts ­ The Project will create additional pervious area and will
       redevelop an existing impervious parking lot. The Project will preserve existing
       open spaces and create new open spaces for the public to enjoy.

    4) compatibility with adjacent land uses ­ The Project will improve access to and from
       the MBTA Blue Line Suffolk Downs Station and will upgrade pedestrian and shuttle
       connections within the Project site.        In addition, the Project will promote
       connectivity to adjacent land uses and includes on-street bicycle accommodations
       to connect Constitution Beach to Revere Beach along the Bennington Street
       corridor, along with connections to the Project site behind the Suffolk Downs
       MBTA Station and from Winthrop Avenue. This network will establish access to a
       walkway in the Belle Isle Marsh that is being constructed as part of a separate
       project associated with a U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) consent
       decree and in accordance with a plan developed by the Friends of Belle Isle Marsh.

   The Project is consistent with the City of Revere Strategic Plan by increasing economic
   development and employment opportunities, one of the major objectives of the
   Strategic Plan. The Project will also provide funding to the City which could be used for
   infrastructure improvements, another objective in the Plan. The Project will also
   increase access to open space on site and will provide bicycle accommodations to
   enhance access to open spaces and beaches.

C. Identify the current Regional Policy Plan of the applicable Regional Planning Agency (RPA)
      RPA: Boston Region Metropolitan Planning Organization
      Title: Journey to 2030 (September 27, 2007)

D. Describe the project's consistency with that plan with regard to:
   1) economic development
   2) adequacy of infrastructure
   3) open space impacts

   The Project is consistent with Journey to 2030, the Metropolitan Planning
   Organization's current Transportation Plan, by proposing growth near transit services,
   improving the streetscape, and supporting pedestrians and bicycle use, which will
   reduce single-occupant vehicle trips in the area. The Project will improve the
   pedestrian environment by providing new lighting, landscaping, and walkways, improve
   access to and from the Suffolk Downs MBTA Blue Line Station, and will provide
   upgraded pedestrian and shuttle connections to the Project. In addition, the Project
   includes on-street bicycle accommodations to connect Constitution Beach to Revere
   Beach along the Bennington Street corridor, along with connections to the Project site
   from the Suffolk Downs MBTA Station and from Winthrop Avenue. This network will
   establish access to a walkway in the Belle Isle Marsh that is being constructed as part
   of a separate project associated with an EPA consent decree and in accordance with a
   plan developed by the Friends of Belle Isle Marsh.

   Based on an analysis of the existing wastewater infrastructure and the estimated
   proposed sewer generation, the existing BWSC 12-inch gravity sewer line demonstrates
   adequate capacity to accept and convey the increase in flow from the proposed Project.
   Furthermore, water capacity problems are not anticipated within the existing system as
   a result of Project construction.

WASTEWATER SECTION
  I. Thresholds / Permits
     A. Will the project meet or exceed any review thresholds related to wastewater (see 301 CMR
        11.03(5))? X Yes ___ No; if yes, specify, in quantitative terms:

        The Project will exceed the threshold at 301 CMR 11.03(5)(b)(4)(a): New discharge or
        Expansion in discharge to a sewer system of 100,000 or more gpd of sewage... The
        Project will expand existing wastewater generation from the Project site by approximately
        307,080 gallons per day, calculated using Title V design flow figures.

     B. Does the project require any state permits related to wastewater?     X Yes ___ No; if yes,
        specify which permit:

        The Project requires a Sewer Connection Permit and a Sewer Extension Permit from
        MassDEP and a Sewer Use Discharge Permit (or waiver) from the MWRA.

     C. If you answered "No" to both questions A and B, proceed to the Transportation -- Traffic
        Generation Section. If you answered "Yes" to either question A or question B, fill out the
        remainder of the Wastewater Section below.

  II. Impacts and Permits
      A. Describe the volume (in gallons per day) and type of disposal of wastewater generation for
         existing and proposed activities at the project site (calculate according to 310 CMR 15.00 for
         septic systems or 314 CMR 7.00 for sewer systems):
                                                         Existing          Net Change     Total
         Discharge of sanitary wastewater                166,020           307,080        473,100
         Discharge of industrial wastewater              0                 0              0
         TOTAL                                           166,020           307,080        473,100*

                                                    Existing           Change           Total
        Discharge to groundwater                    0                  0                0
        Discharge to outstanding resource water     0                  0                0
        Discharge to surface water                  0                  0                0
        Discharge to municipal or regional wastewater
             facility                               166,020             307,080         473,100
        TOTAL                                       166,020             307,080         473,100

        * See Section 4.4.2 of the Supplemental Project Information in Attachment A.

     B. Is the existing collection system at or near its capacity? ___ Yes X No; if yes, then describe
        the measures to be undertaken to accommodate the project's wastewater flows:

        As described in Section 4.4.2.3, the existing 12-inch gravity sewer line demonstrates
        adequate capacity to accept and convey the increase in flow from the proposed Project.
        Any sanitary sewage generated by the Project will not impact the existing 12-inch gravity
        sewer line in Waldemar Avenue. The Proponent will work cooperatively with BWSC to
        identify any off-site impacts resulting from the Project and will provide mitigation if
        necessary.




                                                   -24-
   C. Is the existing wastewater disposal facility at or near its permitted capacity? ___ Yes X No; if
      yes, then describe the measures to be undertaken to accommodate the project's wastewater
      flows:

   D. Does the project site currently contain a wastewater treatment facility, sewer main, or other
      wastewater disposal facility, or will the project involve construction of a new facility? X Yes ___
      No; if yes, describe as follows:

       The Project site currently contains 2.5 miles of sewer mains. The Project will lengthen
       sewer mains to approximately 3.2 miles on site, but the proposed work on sewer mains
       will replace some of the existing line, such that proposed construction will involve
       approximately 1.9 miles of new sewer mains. Project construction will also include two
       new sewer pump stations.

      direction of the transfer, and is the interbasin transfer existing or new? N/A

   G. Is there an existing facility, or is a new facility proposed at the project site for the storage,

   H. Describe the water conservation measures to be undertaken by the project, and other wastewater
      mitigation, such as infiltration and inflow removal.

      Water conservation measures such as low-flow toilets and restricted flow faucets will
      reduce the domestic water demand on the existing distribution system. Sensor-operated
      sinks with water-conserving aerators and sensor-operated toilets will be installed in all
      restrooms.

III. Consistency
    A. Describe measures that the proponent will take to comply with applicable state, regional, and
       local plans and policies related to wastewater management:

      The Proponent will coordinate with the BWSC regarding the design and capacity of
      proposed connections to the sewer system. In addition, the Proponent will submit a
      General Service Application and site plan for review as the Project progresses. The
      Project will generate new wastewater flows greater than 50,000 GPD; therefore, a Sewer

                                                  -25-
             Connection Permit (BRP WP 74) will be required from MassDEP. Since the Project also
             includes an extension of sewer line greater than 1,000 linear feet, it will also require a
             Sewer Extension Permit (BRP WP 71) from MassDEP.

             All improvements and connections to BWSC infrastructure will be reviewed as part of the
             BWSC's site plan review process for the proposed Project. This process includes a
             comprehensive design review of the proposed service connections, an assessment of
             Project demands and system capacity, and the establishment of service accounts.

         B. If the project requires a sewer extension permit, is that extension included in a comprehensive
            wastewater management plan? ___ Yes X No; if yes, indicate the EEA number for the plan
            and whether the project site is within a sewer service area recommended or approved in that
            plan:

            Transportation Facilities Section. If you answered "Yes" to either question A or question B, fill
            out the remainder of the Traffic Generation Section below.

      II. Traffic Impacts and Permits
          A. Describe existing and proposed vehicular traffic generated by activities at the project site:
                                                           Existing        Change             Total
                   Number of parking spaces                6,000           (-850)             5,150
                   Number of vehicle trips per day         15,90011        24,60012           40,500
                   ITE Land Use Code(s):                   ATR             n/a                _______

         B. What is the estimated average daily traffic on roadways serving the site?
                Roadway                                    Existing       Change Total
                1. Rte 1A (south of Tomasello Dr.)         56,547         TBD                        TBD
                2. Rte 1A (north of Rte 145)               44,838         TBD                        TBD
                3. Rte 60 (north of Bell Circle            38,048         TBD                        TBD

         C. If applicable, describe proposed mitigation measures on state-controlled roadways that the
            project proponent will implement:

             The Project includes major off-site roadway, traffic, and safety improvements, comprising
             new roadway infrastructure to be designed and constructed in consultation with MassDOT
             and the City of Boston on Route 1A in the vicinity of the site. These improvements could
             include a Route 1A northbound flyover at Boardman Street, an additional Route 1A

11
     Existing Site trips include a summation of the Average Daily Trips (ADT) established by full-week Automatic
     Traffic Recorder (ATR) counts performed on each access roadway in July 2012.
12
     The Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation manual does not contain guidance appropriate to
     the proposed Project land use. Therefore, the Project trip generation projection is based on preliminary analysis.
     A comprehensive trip generation analysis will be presented in the DEIR.

                                                            -26-
   southbound lane, traffic signal control at Waldemar Avenue, and signalization of the
   Tomasello Drive intersection. The design of these improvements will be developed in
   consultation with MassDOT and the City of Boston to address existing local and regional
   traffic difficulties at Boardman Street, improve safety, and provide ample capacity to
   accommodate Project trips entering and exiting the site.

   In addition, as part of the discussions for the Host and Surrounding Community
   Agreements, the cities of Revere and Chelsea have asked that existing regional traffic
   issues along the Route 60 and Route 1 corridors be studied to identify and assist in
   funding potential improvements. New ramp connections at the Route 1/Route 16
   interchange and improvements along the Revere Beach Parkway corridor have been
   identified as potential mid-term improvements, which, consistent with the Boston
   Metropolitan Planning Organization (Boston MPO)'s Lower North Shore Transportation
   Improvement Study (prepared by the Central Transportation Planning Staff for the
   Massachusetts Highway Department in October 2000), would shift some regional and
   Project traffic from the Route 60 corridor to Route 1/Route 16. Such strategic new
   connections would be expected to address long-standing regional traffic issues in the
   Cities of Revere and Chelsea along the Route 60 corridor through Butler Circle and Bell
   Circle, as well as along Route 16/Revere Beach Parkway between Webster Avenue and the
   split to Route 145. Any such improvements would be intended primarily to address pre-
   existing regional traffic problems, independent of the proposed Project and would be
   expected to realize benefits for regional traffic that far exceed the potential impacts of
   Project traffic. Again the design of the improvements would be developed in consultation
   with MassDOT, DCR, and the cities of Revere and Chelsea.

   A full analysis of these and other infrastructure improvements will be presented in the
   DEIR. The design development for all traffic and roadway improvements will incorporate
   "Complete Streets" principles.

D. How will the project implement and/or promote the use of transit, pedestrian and bicycle facilities
   and services to provide access to and from the project site?

    The Project site is served by the MBTA Blue line (at Suffolk Downs and Beachmont
    stations) as well as several MBTA bus routes.              The Project will improve the
    pedestrian/shuttle link between Suffolk Downs Station and the Project entrances to
    encourage travel by public transit. In addition, the feasibility of connections between the
    Project and water transportation will continue to be explored, along with potential HOV
    service between the Project and area transportation, hotel and other visitor locations.
    Pedestrian access to, and circulation within, the Project site will be improved, and new
    on-street bicycle accommodations on the Bennington Street corridor will improve bicycle
    access. The proposed transportation infrastructure improvements will be supported by
    robust TDM plans for employees and patrons to reduce SOV travel and encourage use of
    alternative modes of transit.


E. Is there a Transportation Management Association (TMA) that provides transportation demand
   management (TDM) services in the area of the project site? X Yes ___ No; if yes, describe if
   and how will the project will participate in the TMA:

   The Proponent has already initiated discussions with Massport with the intention of
   joining the Logan Airport TMA and coordinating with Massport to seek efficiencies in
   sharing transportation services for patrons, employees and airport users.




                                              -27-
     F. Will the project use (or occur in the immediate vicinity of) water, rail, or air transportation facilities?
         X Yes ____ No; if yes, generally describe:

        The Project site abuts the MBTA Blue Line corridor and is located within approximately
        one mile of Logan International Airport.

     G. If the project will penetrate approach airspace of a nearby airport, has the proponent filed a
        Massachusetts Aeronautics Commission Airspace Review Form (780 CMR 111.7) and a
        Notice of Proposed Construction or Alteration with the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)
        (CFR Title 14 Part 77.13, forms 7460-1 and 7460-2)? The Proponent is in the process of
        conducting this analysis and, if necessary, will submit the appropriate notices to the
        FAA.

  III. Consistency
         Describe measures that the proponent will take to comply with municipal, regional, state, and
         federal plans and policies related to traffic, transit, pedestrian and bicycle transportation
         facilities and services:

        The Project is consistent with Journey to 2030, the Metropolitan Planning
        Organization's current Transportation Plan, by proposing growth near transit services,
        improving the streetscape, and supporting pedestrians and bicycle use, which will
        reduce single-occupant vehicle trips in the area. The Project will improve the
        pedestrian environment by providing new lighting, landscaping, and walkways, improve
        access to and from the Suffolk Downs MBTA Blue Line Station, and will provide
        upgraded pedestrian and shuttle connections to the Project. In addition, the Project
        includes on-street bicycle accommodations to connect Constitution Beach to Revere
        Beach along the Bennington Street corridor, along with connections to the Project site
        from the Suffolk Downs MBTA Station and from Winthrop Avenue. This network will
        establish access to a walkway in the Belle Isle Marsh that is being constructed as part
        of a separate project associated with an EPA consent decree and in accordance with a
        plan developed by the Friends of Belle Isle Marsh.

      The Suffolk Downs clubhouse, grandstand, and racetrack are included in the Inventory of
      Historic and Archaeological Assets of the Commonwealth (MHC No. BOS.209). The Project
      involves continued operations at the Suffolk Downs racetrack with renovations to the
      grandstand, clubhouse, and barn area.

II. Impacts
    Describe and assess the project's impacts, direct and indirect, on listed or inventoried historical and
    archaeological resources:

   The Project involves continued operations at the Suffolk Downs racetrack with renovations to
   the grandstand, clubhouse, and barn area. The Project will enable the preservation of the
   racetrack/racing uses at Suffolk Downs. Proposed improvements will be reviewed with the
   MHC as plans are developed.

   Register review process will be initiated through the filing of this ENF under MEPA.

3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF           1-2     Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Introduction                                                                       Epsilon Associates, Inc.
1.2     Project Summary

        Sterling Suffolk Racecourse, LLC (the Proponent), is the owner of a 161-acre parcel of land
        located both in the cities of Boston and Revere, Massachusetts where it operates the historic
        Suffolk Downs, a thoroughbred horse racing facility (the "Property"). The existing Project
        site is shown in Figures 1-1 through 1-3. The Proponent plans to file an application with
        the Massachusetts Gaming Commission seeking a license to operate a category I gaming
        establishment at Suffolk Downs pursuant to the provisions of M.G.L. chapter 23K (on
        August 10, 2012, the Proponent paid to the Massachusetts Gaming Commission a
        statutorily-established fee to commence that process and filed its RFA-1 suitability
        application with the Commission on January 15, 2013). Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs
        (the Project) is a redevelopment proposed to contain two distinct gaming areas (referred to
        herein as "Casino Area I" and "Casino Area II"), up to 450 guestrooms in two hotels, a
        multi-purpose meeting/entertainment space, dedicated covered parking, fine dining, and
        retail space (see Figure 1-5).

        The Project will bring significant new investment to the cities of Boston and Revere,
        increased governmental revenue, and new permanent employment opportunities for
        residents of Boston, Revere, and other local communities. Furthermore, pursuant to M.G.L.
        chapter 23K, a portion of the taxes on the proposed Project's gross gaming revenue will be
        allocated to a community mitigation fund, from which the Massachusetts Gaming
        Commission will allocate funds to the cities of Boston and Revere and others to address
        potential Project impacts. Public benefits are further described in Section 1.5, and a
        detailed Project description is provided in Section 2.0. That detailed description addresses
        existing conditions (see Section 2.1) and the context of development and proposed site
        uses.

1.3     Consistency with Planning

        The Project is consistent with the policy and planning objectives set forth by the City of
        Boston in the East Boston Master Plan (April 2000). Specifically, the Project will serve to
        promote the goals of supporting economic development in East Boston and increasing the
        quality and variety of employment opportunities for residents of East Boston. The Project
        will also improve bicycle and pedestrian access to the Belle Isle Marsh as well as other local
        amenities.

        The Project is also consistent with the planning objectives set forth by the City of Revere in
        the City of Revere Strategic Plan, FY2010-2015. Specifically the Project will increase
        economic development and employment opportunities, one of the major objectives of the
        Strategic Plan. The Project will also provide funding to the City which will be available to
        fund infrastructure improvements, another objective in the Plan. The Project will increase
        access to open space on site and will provide bicycle accommodations to enhance access
        to open spaces and beaches.


3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         1-3    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Introduction                                                                    Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        In accordance with Section 9(a)(18) of M.G.L. chapter 23K, the Proponent's gaming license
        application will include information related to whether the proposed gaming establishment
        is part of a regional or local economic plan.

1.4     Consistency with Zoning

        1.4.1           Revere

        Within Revere, the Project site is located in an area designated in the City's Zoning
        Ordinances as PDD (Planned Development District) 1. Currently, the Project includes only
        racing and ancillary parking uses within the City of Revere, which are permitted by right in
        the PDD1. Gaming facilities are permitted within the PDD1 by special permit. The
        Proponent will apply for the necessary special permit at the appropriate time.

        1.4.2           Boston

        Within Boston, the Property is located in the Suffolk Downs EDA and the Suffolk Downs
        Special Study Overlay Area, both of which are contained within the East Boston
        Neighborhood Zoning District, which is governed by Article 53 of the Boston Zoning Code.
        The Proponent intends to comply with the relevant provisions of the Boston Zoning Code,
        including obtaining any zoning approvals or zoning relief as may be required for Project
        development. It will submit relevant plans to the Boston Redevelopment Authority (BRA)
        for development review pursuant to the provisions of Article 80 of the Boston Zoning Code,
        including any design review of proposed buildings required pursuant to the BRA's
        development review guidelines. The Proponent will pay to the BRA any Development
        Impact Project Fees required under Article 80. At the completion of development review,
        the Proponent and the BRA will enter into a Cooperation Agreement pursuant to Article 80
        in which the Proponent will commit to undertake such mitigation measures and such
        additional undertakings as are typically included in Cooperation Agreements for similar
        projects. Any mitigation and other commitments that may be made by the Proponent in the
        Host Community Agreement may also be included in the Cooperation Agreement.

1.5     Public Benefits

        The Project will provide numerous significant public benefits, included but not limited to
        the following:

                New Real and Personal Property Tax Revenue: Enhanced annual property tax
                revenues;

                Tax Revenues: The Project will generate significant new tax revenue at the state and
                local levels in the form of sales taxes, hotel taxes, food and beverage taxes, as well
                as taxes on gross gaming revenues;




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF           1-4    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Introduction                                                                      Epsilon Associates, Inc.
                New Jobs: Approximately 2,500 construction jobs and approximately 4,000
                permanent resort jobs, the latter of which will encompass 39 job categories such as
                hotel/resort personnel, facility employees, food and beverage, gaming, racing, and
                management and operational areas and will include full job training, benefits and
                opportunities for career advancement;

                $40 Million in Roadway Improvements: Significant transportation improvements to
                the surrounding roadway network that would improve existing conditions and
                accommodate the additional Project-generated trips. These improvements are
                valued at approximately $40 million and are further detailed in Section 3.0.

                Sustainable Design/Green Building: The Proponent will set a new standard of
                excellence in sustainable design for gaming development projects. Striving for
                LEED Gold, the Project will be sustainably designed, energy efficient,
                environmentally conscious, and healthy for its employees and visitors. Innovative
                technologies are currently being explored to determine what works best with the
                Project as well as what might set a visible example for those visiting the site.

                Open Space: The Project will promote connectivity to adjacent land uses and
                includes on-street bicycle accommodations to connect Constitution Beach to Revere
                Beach along the Bennington Street corridor, along with connections to the Project
                site from the Suffolk Downs MBTA Station and from Winthrop Avenue. The project
                will increase pervious surfaces by at least nine acres.

                Support for Local Businesses: The Proponent expects to spend approximately $150
                million annually for goods and services at local and regional businesses in
                connection with the ongoing operation of the Project and also intends to partner
                with Boston, Revere, Chelsea, and Winthrop area hotels, restaurants, entertainment
                venues and tourism organizations to attract visitors and boost the local economy;

                Partnership with Citi-Center: The Performing Arts Center (including the Wang,
                Shubert, and Emerson Colonial theaters), a 77 year old non-profit, has partnered
                with the Project to collaborate on the entertainment and cultural activities at a future
                resort casino

                City of Revere Infrastructure Improvements: Provision to the City of Revere of a
                concept plan for streetscape, lighting, planting, and other infrastructure
                improvements in and around the Beachmont section of the City (i.e., the area
                bounded by Winthrop Avenue, Unity Avenue, Bennington Street, and Washburn
                Avenue), and funding for the City to plan, design, and construct such
                improvements;

Introduction                                                                       Epsilon Associates, Inc.
                Boston and Revere Host Community Agreements: Payment to the cities of Boston
                and Revere of Community Impact Fees pursuant to the respective Host Community
                Agreements for each city;

                Water Quality Improvements: Improved stormwater management on the Project
                site, which will lead to enhanced water quality reaching Sales Creek, the Belle Isle
                Inlet, and Rumney Marshes ACEC;

                Strengthened MBTA Connection: Improved access to the MBTA Blue Line Suffolk
                Downs Station, including upgraded pedestrian and shuttle connections to the
                Project;

                New Bicycle and Pedestrian Connections: To enhance local and regional
                connectivity, the Project will improve bike and pedestrian circulation and access.
                The Project includes provision of on-street bicycle accommodations to connect
                Constitution Beach to Revere Beach along the Bennington Street corridor, along
                with connections to the Project site from the Suffolk Downs MBTA station and from
                Winthrop Avenue. On-site pedestrian paths and aesthetically-pleasing open spaces
                will encourage pedestrian activity and access, including at the site entry

                Additional Community Benefits: In collaboration with the cities of Boston and
                Revere, the establishment of Community Advisory Boards to provide additional
                community benefits (e.g., inclusion of local vendors) relevant to Project impacts and
                to generally benefit the communities and their residents.; and

                Agricultural Support: The Project, unlike conventional mixed-use development
                alternatives which would typically involve higher-density build-out, will maintain
                open space and support continued agricultural and open space practices in
                Massachusetts.

        In addition to the specific Project benefits listed above, the Proponent has committed as part
        of a consent decree with the U.S. EPA to fund over the next four years three important
        regional supplemental environmental projects valued at approximately $742,000. This
        includes construction of a boardwalk that will improve public access through Belle Isle
        Marsh and protect natural resources within the marsh from degradation through pedestrian
        contact. The Proponent is also contemplating a potential connection to water shuttle
        service.
