3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF            1-7     Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Introduction                                                                         Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        The National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) requires the disclosure of the environmental
        impacts of proposed "major Federal actions significantly affecting the quality of the human
        environment" (40 U.S.C. § 4332(2)(C)). Such "major Federal actions" include "projects and
        programs entirely or partly financed, assisted, conducted, regulated or approved by federal
        agencies" (40 CFR § 1508.18(a)). At this time, it does not appear that the Project will
        involve any Federal funding or subsidy, any Federal permit, license, or approval or any
        other Federal agency activity that would trigger NEPA review. Although the Proponent may
        seek one or more Determinations of No Hazard from the FAA and may also make a NPDES
        general permit filing for stormwater runoff related to construction, these filings do not
        typically trigger NEPA review.

        1.6.1        Legislation

        Chapter 194 of the Acts of 2011: An Act Establishing Expanded Gaming in the
        Commonwealth (the "Gaming Act") was signed into law by Governor Deval Patrick on
        November 22, 2011 with the goal of providing economic investment and job creation
        within the Commonwealth (and to continue to preserve racetracks in the Commonwealth,
        including the distribution of purse funds to those racetracks). The Gaming Act provides for
        the licensing of up to three destination resort casinos in diverse geographic locations within
        the Commonwealth as well as one slots facility and the creation of a Gaming Commission
        to oversee the implementation of expanded gaming within the Commonwealth. The
        Proponent plans to file an application with the Massachusetts Gaming Commission seeking
        a license to operate a category I gaming establishment at Suffolk Downs pursuant to the
        provisions of M.G.L. chapter 23K (on August 10, 2012, the Proponent paid to the
        Massachusetts Gaming Commission a statutorily-established fee to commence that process
        and filed its RFA-1 suitability application with the Commission on January 15, 2013). With
        the potential creation of approximately 2,500 construction jobs and more than 4,000
        permanent jobs, as well as substantial proposed investment in infrastructure and the local
        economy, the Project is in keeping with the economic development and job creation goals
        of the Gaming Act.

        1.6.2        City Referendum

        The Proponent is actively engaged with the Cities of Boston and Revere to plan for a
        referendum in each of its host communities of East Boston and Revere as required by the
        Gaming Act.

        1.6.3        Surrounding Community Agreements

        The Proponent plans to enter into Surrounding Community Agreements with Chelsea and
        Winthrop.

1.7     Legal Information

        1.7.1           Legal Judgments Adverse to the Proposed Project

        The Proponent is not aware of any legal judgments that are adverse to the proposed Project.

        1.7.2           History of Tax Arrears on Property

        The Proponent is not aware of any history of tax arrears on the Property under the current
        ownership.

        1.7.3           Site Control/Public Easements

        The Proponent owns fee title to the Project site. As discussed in further detail in Section
        2.2.1, the Project will include certain off-site traffic improvements along Route 1A,
        including widening Route 1A and construction a flyover at the intersection of Boardman
        Street and Route 1A in East Boston. The Proponent has already begun discussions with
        certain property owners who own property in the proposed Right of Way (ROW) and will
        continue to work with these property owners to obtain all rights required for construction of
        the proposed Route 1A flyover and Route 1A improvements.

        Once constructed, ownership of the improvements and the necessary rights in land on
        which the improvements have been made will be transferred to the owner and operator of
        the roadway facility.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF          1-10       Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Introduction                                                                         Epsilon Associates, Inc.
          Section 2.0
PROJECT DESCRIPTION
2.0     PROJECT DESCRIPTION

This section describes existing conditions as well as the proposed Project development.

2.1     Project Site and Context

        Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs is a redevelopment proposed on approximately 161 acres
        of land in East Boston and Revere (see Figures 1-1 and 1-2). Of the 161 acres comprising
        the site, approximately 116 are located in Boston and 45 are located in Revere. To the
        west, the property is bordered by a retail shopping plaza, properties containing fuel storage
        tanks owned by Irving Oil Terminals Inc. and Global Petroleum, and McClellan Highway
        (Route 1A). Winthrop Avenue is located to the north of the Project site. The neighborhood
        north of Winthrop Avenue is Crescent Beach, which in turn borders Revere Beach and the
        Atlantic Ocean. The Project site is located less than one mile from the beach. The MBTA
        Blue Line and Bennington Street lie east of the Project site, and Waldemar Avenue is at the
        southern boundary. Orient Heights is the residential neighborhood located immediately
        south of the Project site.

        The portion of the Project site located within Boston is located within the East Boston
        Neighborhood District and is zoned as the Suffolk Downs EDA, the purpose of which is to
        "encourage sound development and growth that will expand the City's economic base and
        afford broad employment opportunities." The site is also included in a Special Study
        Overlay Area that overlays the EDA.

        The main access point to the site is from Route 1A via Tomasello Drive. Another access
        point is from Winthrop Avenue at the north end of the property. Two mass transit stops on
        the MBTA Blue Line (Suffolk Downs and Beachmont stations) currently serve the Project
        site. Parallel to the train tracks is Bennington Street, which connects East Boston to the
        Town of Winthrop and to the City of Revere. Beyond Bennington Street lies the Belle Isle
        Reservation where DCR manages a 28-acre park with pathways, benches, and an
        observation tower; the reservation is part of the 241-acre Belle Isle Marsh, the last
        remaining salt marsh in Boston. As described in Section 2.2.2, the Project includes a
        comprehensive network of on-street bicycle accommodations and pedestrian paths that will
        provide access to these public amenities.

        DCR manages the Sales Creek drainage channel and culverts within the Project site as a
        flood control project and pursuant to non-exclusive easements. DCR also manages the
        related Sales Creek flood control structures downstream of the Project site. The proposed
        Project does not involve disturbance of the easement area in the Revere portion of the
        racetrack infield in which the Commonwealth may have deposited materials dredged from
        the Sales Creek drainage channel in the early 1980s. As noted below (see Section 4.1.6.2),
        the new stormwater management facilities and BMPs associated with the proposed Project
        will reduce the rate and volume of stormwater leaving the site and will improve stormwater
        quality.

3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                  2-1   Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                             Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        The property is currently home to Suffolk Downs, which opened in 1935 and remains New
        England's only operating thoroughbred racetrack. Historically, the Project site has
        contained as many as 10,000 to 12,000 parking spaces. Racetrack operations require
        approximately 63 acres for a one-mile oval racing surface and related open space, all of
        which exist in an urban environment. The maintenance of this open space and related view
        corridor is an important community amenity. Existing structures on the Project site are
        listed in Table 2-1 and shown on Figure 1-3. Photographs of existing conditions are
        provided in Attachment J.

Table 2-1        Existing Structures on the Project site

                                Existing Building 1                             Gross Square Footage 2
        Racing Building                                                                392,480
             Grandstand                                                                263,840
             Link (3,700-sf west stair to be demolished)                                52,840
             Clubhouse                                                                  75,800
        Site Structures
             Office Building (to be demolished)                                         10,000
             Utility Buildings (to be demolished)                                        3,000
                                                                    total              405,480
                                                  total to be demolished               16,700


        The grandstand building was constructed in 1935 along with the clubhouse, which was
        originally separated from the grandstand by an access path from the original paddock.
        Originally designed in the International Style, the property has undergone substantial
        renovations through the years including enclosure of the grandstand in 1945, major
        renovations and modifications in 1962 with a new grand entrance and the joining and
        complete enclosure of the grandstand and clubhouse, another major renovation in 1992,
        and a series of updates and improvements over the past five years. Smaller existing
        buildings on the site are the administration building, electrical substation, sewer pump
        station, maintenance building, and stables. Figure 1-3 illustrates an existing conditions
        plan.

        As shown on Figure 1-4, the Project site does contain some wetlands, and existing
        vegetation largely coincides with the existing wetlands. Of the 161-acre Project site,
        approximately 71 acres are impervious and 90 acres are pervious. The existing racetrack
        and infield comprise the majority of the pervious area.




1
    Does not include existing horse barns.
2
    Per Boston Zoning Code requirements.


3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                        2-2    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                                    Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        Sales Creek is associated with the Belle Isle Inlet and Rumney Marshes ACEC and extends
        through the Project site, primarily as a manmade drainage channel, from approximately the
        northwest corner of the site, passing between the proposed construction and the existing
        horse barns, through the northern portion of the racing track infield, and continuing east of
        the Project site (see Figure 1-6). Areas north of Sales Creek house stables for the ongoing
        racing program.

        2.1.1            Existing Concentrated Animal Feeding Operation

        To the Proponent's knowledge, the stable area at Suffolk Downs constitutes the only
        Concentrated Animal Feeding Operation (CAFO) in Massachusetts. In October 2012, a
        consent decree was finalized between EPA and Sterling Suffolk Racecourse as a result of
        unauthorized discharges from the CAFO into Sales Creek and an adjacent wetland. In
        addition to making the needed reparations and repairs to the stormwater system, Sterling
        Suffolk Racecourse agreed to apply a portion of its proposed penalty to three Supplemental
        Environmental Projects (SEPs), projects intended to improve the water quality of nearby
        rivers and waterways.3

        Sterling Suffolk Racecourse worked closely with local community groups and not-for-profit
        organizations within the cities, towns, and watersheds connected to Suffolk Downs.
        Ultimately, Sterling Suffolk Racecourse recommended that SEP funds be made available to
        three organizations: (1) the Mystic River Watershed Association, which monitors the water
        quality of the Mystic River and the 44 lakes and ponds within its Watershed, impacting 22
        communities; (2) the Saugus River Watershed Council (SWRC), whose goal is to protect and
        restore the natural resources of the Saugus River Watershed and its 11 communities; and (3)
        DCR's Belle Isle Marsh, which has a strong and active Friends group and which is located
        downstream of the Suffolk Downs property.

        A number of meetings were held and site visits conducted to determine, in conjunction
        with the organizations, which projects would produce the most impactful environmental
        and public health benefits. Ultimately, Sterling Suffolk Racecourse recommended and the
        court approved a number of improvements, which Sterling Suffolk Racecourse will fund
        over the next several years. Specifically, the SEPs are:

              Sterling Suffolk Racecourse will make available $495,000 over three years to the
              Mystic River Watershed Association. The Association will use the majority of those
              funds to continue its comprehensive collection of water quality data, evaluate
              changes in that data to identify and address water pollution problems, and raise
              public awareness of water quality in the watershed. Additional funds will be made



3
    Sterling Suffolk's provision of funding toward the SEPs referenced herein is being undertaken in connection with the
    settlement of an enforcement action, United States v. Sterling Suffolk Racecourse, LLC on behalf of the United States
    Environmental Protection Agency under the Clean Water Act.


3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                            2-3    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                                            Epsilon Associates, Inc.
                available for "hot spot" monitoring, a more intensive effort to document water
                quality conditions in tributaries to the Mystic River, monitor stormwater outfall
                pipes, and compare water quality in dry and wet weather.
             SRWC will receive $90,000 over four years. Initially it will develop a Quality
             Assurance Project Plan for collection of water quality data. In accordance with that
             plan, SWRC will raise public awareness of the overall water quality in the
             watershed and will supervise and ensure collection and analysis of all water quality
             samples collected.
             In conjunction with DCR, Sterling Suffolk Racecourse will design and construct
             a boardwalk and related signage at Belle Isle Marsh Reservation intended to protect
             the marsh habitat.

        In 2011 and 2012 Sterling Suffolk Racecourse installed a number of new stormwater
        separation and CAFO process water management facilities in and around the horse barns
        and portions of the racetrack infield, under supervision of the U.S. EPA and a variety of
        Massachusetts authorities, to address Federal CAFO requirements. This work was covered
        by an ENF filed in May 2011 (EEA #14747). In June 2011, the Secretary of Energy and
        Environmental Affairs (EEA) issued a MEPA Certificate determining that no EIR was required
        for that work. That work has been completed and is reflected on existing conditions plans.

2.2     Detailed Project Description

        Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs is a redevelopment proposed on approximately 161 acres
        of land that will contain two distinct gaming areas (referred to herein as "Casino Area I" and
        "Casino Area II"), up to 450 guestrooms in two hotels, a multi-purpose
        meeting/entertainment space, dedicated covered parking, fine dining, and retail space (see
        Figure 1-5, Proposed Project).          The Proponent proposes to construct substantial
        infrastructure improvements on Route 1A in the vicinity of the Project site as an integral part
        of the Project (see Section 2.2.1). The Project elements are more specifically listed below:

             Two hotels: an approximately 300-room Hotel I and an approximately 150-room
             Hotel II;
             Multi-purpose meeting/entertainment space;
             Dining: approximately 16 restaurants including fine dining concepts, casual outlets,
             and a marketplace;
             Gaming Space: approximately 200,000 square feet of gaming space containing
             4,000-5,000 slot machines, 200 table games, and a World Series of PokerTM room;
             Retail: approximately 30,000 square feet;
             Central Utility Plant; and




3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                   2-4   Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                              Epsilon Associates, Inc.
              Parking: an approximately 2,600-space, seven-story parking garage, one level of
              underground valet parking for approximately 450 cars, and approximately 2,100
              surface parking spaces (total of 5,150 spaces).

        The Project also involves continued operations at the Suffolk Downs racetrack as well as
        ongoing maintenance in the existing horse barn area which will include replacing or
        improving horse barns as necessary. As shown in Table 2-2, the Project involves both
        renovation and new construction. Figure 2-1 shows a view of the proposed development
        from the Orient Heights neighborhood, while Figures 2-2 and 2-3 illustrate the north and
        south arrival plazas, respectively. Floor plans are provided as Figures 2-4 through 2-7.

        Casino Area I will be housed on the first floor of the existing, re-purposed Suffolk Downs
        grandstand building and link building on the Project site. In its current design, the first floor
        will be a gaming floor (slot machines and table games) that will include restaurants, a
        dedicated poker room, and a high-limit gaming area. Figure 2-8 provides an elevation view
        of Casino Area I. The second floor of the grandstand building will be re-purposed to house
        a marketplace, back-of-house support spaces, and a service connection to Casino Area II.
        The second floor of the adjacent link building will be re-purposed to house gaming offices
        and additional back-of-house support spaces. A double-bay loading dock and employee
        service entrance will be located on the north side of the building. Construction of the
        second hotel and retail component may follow development of the casino areas, initial
        hotel, and other amenities. Just to the north, a CUP will provide utility services for the
        entire Project. The Proponent is committed to developing a Project that is sustainably
        designed, energy efficient, environmentally conscious, and healthy for its employees and
        visitors. Pursuant to Article 37 of the Boston Zoning Code and the Gaming Act legislation,
        the Project is striving for Gold certification in the U.S. Green Building Council's (USGBC'S)
        LEED program.
