        The existing clubhouse, attached to the grandstand building via the link building, will
        undergo renovations and will continue to house the horse racing program (see Figure 2-9).
        Gaming and racing components will be operated jointly and will be fully accessible to
        patrons.

        The main entrance of Casino Area II, centered on the crescent-shaped luxury hotel (Hotel I),
        will be flanked by two fine dining restaurants and the hotel lobby (see Figure 2-10). The
        lower-story façade will provide a clear visual connection to the interior, and terrace dining
        will support an urban, pedestrian-friendly environment along the access drive. A draped
        glass canopy and port-cochere (i.e., covered entrance) will accommodate drop-off and valet
        services. The 300-room, seven-story luxury Hotel I will feature breathtaking views of
        Boston and the eastern Massachusetts seacoast. A two-story entrance lobby will lead to the
        gaming floor of Casino Area II, which will be flanked by an additional three fine dining
        restaurants, high-limit gaming room, and support services (see Figure 2-11). Escalators in
        the front lobby will provide access to a 25,000-square-foot multi-purpose conference and
        entertainment space flanked by a spa. The two-story entrance lobby will allow for views
        from these function areas into the lobby below. Below-grade parking under Casino Area II
        will provide approximately 450 valet parking spaces. Direct access to a double-bay loading
        dock and mechanical area will be provided northwest of the gaming floor.

        A northern entrance to Casino Area II will have access from a detached seven-story, 2,600-
        space parking structure and will support a lobby dedicated to the 150-room Hotel II.
        Elevation views of Hotel II and the parking structure are provided as Figures 2-12 and 2-13
        in Attachment B; additional renderings and views are provided in Attachment C. A glass
        pavilion will connect the two casino areas at the ground-level adjacent to the north
        entrance of Casino Area II. This pavilion will also be the primary arrival point for the drop-
        off loop for dedicated charter buses and shuttles from Logan Airport and other major tourist




5
    As defined by the Boston Zoning Code.

3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                   2-6    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                               Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        or travel venues in Boston as well as from the mass transit station. The Proponent expects
        that a significant number of visitors and a substantial proportion of Project employees will
        access the site via public transportation. .

        Supplementary parking will be provided by 2,100 surface parking spaces in lots located
        north and south of the entrance drive to Casino Area I.

        The Project will bring significant new investment to the cities of Boston and Revere,
        increased governmental revenue, and new permanent employment opportunities for
        residents of the cities and other local communities. Furthermore, pursuant to Chapter 23K,
        a portion of the taxes on the proposed Project's gross gaming revenue will be allocated to a
        community mitigation fund, from which the Massachusetts Gaming Commission will
        allocate funds to the cities of Boston and Revere and others to address potential Project
        impacts. In addition to new jobs, public funding, and direct investment at Suffolk Downs,
        the proposed Project will promote small business and the tourism industry and have
        positive economic effects on the cities and the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Locating
        a category I gaming establishment at Suffolk Downs will permit tourists to enjoy both the
        gaming establishment and the unique cultural and social resources of Boston and Revere,
        and will result in additional enjoyment of and support for those resources.

        Caesars Entertainment believes that the most compelling destination resort casinos, those
        that provide the maximum value to host and surrounding communities as well as their own
        customers, are integrated into a destination's existing infrastructure and its restaurant,
        entertainment, hospitality, and recreational offerings. As such, the resort is being designed
        to emphasize linkages with existing local and regional attractions and services, and these
        community assets will benefit from the Project's ability to attract tourists and local visitors.

        Aesthetically, the Project will create a resort embedded within a beautifully-landscaped site
        to establish a vibrant, accessible, and attractive urban destination. Proposed Project
        massing will offer a sense of monumentality, while the carefully-scaled composition of new
        and restored buildings, streets, and open spaces will be contextually-relevant to the
        surrounding landscape. Visitors entering the resort from Route 1A will be welcomed by a
        tree-lined entrance drive.

        As a City-integrated resort, the Project design incorporates an iconic physical design for the
        casino and core amenities that are intended to be a magnet for tourism, an anchor for other
        leisure and hospitality businesses, and a regional engine for economic growth. Specifically,
        Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs will promote and utilize civic, cultural, entertainment, and
        hospitality offerings available in the Greater Boston region. Project patrons will have
        coordinated access to those offerings through the resort's marketing team and via a
        concierge desk located in the Project's winter garden.

        Proposed roadway infrastructure improvements are described in Sections 3.4.7 and 3.4.8.



3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                   2-7   Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                               Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        2.2.1         Bike and Pedestrian Circulation and Access

        To enhance local and regional connectivity, the Project will improve bike and pedestrian
        circulation and access. The Project includes provision of on-street bicycle accommodations
        to connect Constitution Beach to Revere Beach along the Bennington Street corridor, along
        with connections to the Project site from the Suffolk Downs MBTA station and from
        Winthrop Avenue. On-site pedestrian paths and aesthetically-pleasing open spaces will
        encourage pedestrian activity and access, including at the site entry (see Figure 2-16).
        Circulation for bicyclists and pedestrians is shown on Figure 2-17. Section 3.7 contains a
        more detailed regional description of bike and pedestrian circulation.

        2.2.2         Public Transportation

        The Project site is served by the MBTA Blue line (at Suffolk Downs and Beachmont stations)
        as well as several MBTA bus routes. The Project will improve the pedestrian/shuttle link
        between Suffolk Downs Station and the Project entrances to encourage travel by public
        transit. In addition, the feasibility of shuttle services between the Project and Logan Airport,
        water transportation terminals, local and downtown hotels, downtown Boston, the Boston
        Convention and Exhibition Center, the Black Falcon Cruise Terminal, and major tourist
        attractions will be explored. As described in detail in Section 3.7, the TDM Plan for the
        Project will include a range of incentives to encourage public transit as an access mode,
        particularly for employees.

        2.2.3         Parking and Transportation Demand Management

        Parking management and transit, bicycle and pedestrian connectivity enhancements to
        support alternate travel modes will be supported by a robust TDM plan. The TDM plan,
        described in Section 3.7, will comprise a comprehensive package of incentives to
        encourage non-single occupant vehicle travel, including public transit as an access mode,
        particularly for employees.

        2.2.4         Open Space and Landscaping Plan

        The open space and landscaping plan for the proposed Project responds to five central
        tenets:

             History: The proposed landscape design embraces the history of the Project site, its
             unique location between the waterfronts of Boston and Chelsea, and its
             transformation over the last 100 years into an active racetrack and clubhouse (see
             below).

             Natural Connections: The site design seeks to link neighborhoods and ecosystems
             by re-connecting adjacent land uses and includes on-street bicycle accommodations
             to connect Constitution Beach to DCR's Belle Isle Marsh and to Revere Beach along
             the Bennington Street corridor, along with connections to the Project site from the


3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                   2-8   Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                               Epsilon Associates, Inc.
                Suffolk Downs MBTA Station and from Winthrop Avenue. This network will
                establish access to a walkway in the Belle Isle Marsh that is being constructed as
                part of a separate project associated with an EPA consent decree and in accordance
                with a plan developed by the Friends of Belle Isle Marsh.

             Public Accessibility: The proposed open space design will create a publicly-
             accessible landscape offering a variety of open space experiences for visitors and
             community members. Bike accommodations and pedestrian connections along
             Tomasello Drive will connect Route 1A with Winthrop Avenue and Waldemar
             Avenue through a park-like setting. By creating a hierarchy and diversity of open
             spaces, the landscape design seeks to transform the existing asphalt parking lots into
             to a series of gardens and landscaped parking lots which will surround the proposed
             resort and existing racetrack. Each area will have its own identity and atmosphere,
             offering places for events, markets and dining, promenading and spectator views
             towards the racetrack. Approximately nine acres of existing impervious paving in
             the parking lots will be transformed into a vibrant and active landscape. Visitor
             experiences will range from the ceremonial Entry Boulevard of Tomasello Drive, to
             the park-like setting of the open space bordering the Orient Heights Neighborhood,
             to the active programmed plazas and gardens of the proposed resort offering places
             to sit and relax for patrons and visitors alike. The Project will improve pedestrian
             connections to the Suffolk Downs MBTA Station, strengthening the pedestrian
             connection. Pedestrian amenities will include benches, picnic tables, and new
             lighting fixtures.

             Permeable Surfaces: New surface parking will be integrated into the landscape
             design through the use of landscaped parking lots, where trees will be planted to
             create shade and improve the visual appearance of the parking lots. Approximately
             nine acres of existing impervious paving in the parking lots will be transformed into
             pervious landscaping.

             Sustainability: In fostering a regenerative approach to the site and landscape design,
             the planting plan will be based on an understanding of the regional landscape
             character and natural communities in the Northeast Coastal Zone Eco region,
             specifically the Boston Basin. Sustainable features will be a priority, and select
             existing trees and vegetation will be considered for preservation while new
             landscape plantings will feature native plant materials which correspond to natural
             communities. This strategy will help establish a more resilient landscape in the face
             of climate change as well as foster a stronger local landscape identity.

        2.2.5         Water Transportation Opportunities and Constraints

        The Proponent understands the importance of water transportation to the area, is supportive
        of innovative ways to increase the use of water transportation to East Boston, and plans to
        coordinate with Massport regarding potential water/bus shuttle system from downtown

3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                 2-9   Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                            Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        Boston to East Boston and the resort. The Project team has also met with Super Duck Tours
        to explore the possibility of utilizing the "duck boat" vehicles to provide water
        transportation access to the proposed casino. Although the Proponent will continue to
        explore this and other water transportation options, the following analysis has concluded
        that water transportation dedicated to the Project is not practical.

        The Boston Inner Harbor is generally well sheltered and often remains essentially ice-free
        throughout the winter. Hence, public and commercial water transportation within the Inner
        Harbor is available year-round and has become a well-established mode of transportation to
        certain destinations. Of particular note within the Inner Harbor are the water shuttle routes
        between downtown Boston and Logan Airport, the Seaport District, and the Charlestown
        Navy Yard. Constraints to establishing water transportation in the upper reaches of the
        Inner Harbor include limited bathymetric and overhead clearances, a lack of existing
        landings, the potential for shipping conflicts, and lack of landside services and support.
        Time of travel can also pose a practical limitation on water transportation when timeliness is
        of concern.

        The Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs Project site does not directly abut a navigable
        waterway that could support commercial water transportation access directly to the site.
        There are essentially three routes to the Project site that could potentially incorporate
        indirect water transportation for a segment of the access routes from the downtown Boston
        and Seaport waterfronts: Chelsea Creek; Boston Inner Harbor (the Logan Airport Dock and
        the Boston Harbor Shipyard & Marina); and the Orient Heights/Belle Isle embayment north
        of Logan Airport. Chelsea Creek, and to a lesser degree the Orient Heights/Belle Isle
        embayment, are located in relatively close proximity to the Project site but are highly
        constrained by navigational considerations, limited landing and multi-modal transportation
        opportunities and significant travel times. Meanwhile, while the Boston Inner Harbor
        routes to the Logan Airport Dock and the Boston Harbor Shipyard & Marina offer a direct
        connection across the Boston Inner Harbor via existing water transportation routes, they
        also necessitate a physically longer landside connection to the Project site. The water
        segments for each of these routes are shown on Figure 2-18 (Attachment B) and are
        reviewed below.

        2.2.5.1       Chelsea Creek

        Chelsea Creek is the closest navigable waterway to the Project site, approaching to within
        approximately 500 feet of the site's Tomasello Drive access. Unfortunately, Chelsea Creek
        is also the most highly-constrained water transportation route to the site, with heavy
        commercial marine traffic in the form of deep-draft oil tankers and associated tugboats.
        These vessels can effectively occupy the entire navigable channel while in transit, and often
        extend well into the channel when at dock. The presence of these vessels would
        significantly interfere with efficient travel times of any water transportation in this area.




3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                   2-10 Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                             Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        In addition, although water depths are sufficient for water transportation, navigation in the
        upper half of Chelsea Creek is impeded by the seven-foot clearance of the Chelsea Street
        Bridge. Navigation beyond the bridge requires raising the structure, thus impacting
        automobile traffic on Chelsea Street.

        There are no public landings located along Chelsea Creek upstream of the McArdle Bridge,
        and there are currently no existing public docking structures or amenities along the Chelsea
        Creek shoreline, which is marked by intertidal mud flats that pose a considerable constraint
        on shoreline access. Compounding this constraint, the New England Division of the U.S.
        Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) has established a typical setback for in-water structures
        equal to three times the design depth of the navigation channel. In Chelsea Creek, this
        equates to a 114-foot setback from the designated federal channel, which would push the
        siting of any new water-side docking structure into intertidal mud flats, requiring the
        dredging of a side channel to establish navigable water depths to the landing. Furthermore,
        the industrial nature of the southern shoreline of Chelsea Creek offers limited opportunity
        for the development of a water transportation landing facility, particularly in that section of
        Chelsea Creek upstream of the Chelsea Street Bridge.

        Even if a new landing facility could be sited and built, the landside component would be
        constrained by existing industrial or commercial land uses. Landside transportation
        infrastructure along this section of the Creek is also limited, with only internal private
        roadways along or proximate to the Creek, no public transportation connections, and
        limited or one-way vehicle access to Route 1A.

        The development of water transportation landing facility along the Chelsea Creek shoreline
        between the McArdle Bridge and Chelsea Street Bridge is similarly constrained by the
        required federal channel setbacks and the industrial nature of the adjacent land uses.
        However, there are two notable open space parcels: the new Condor Street Urban Wild
        Park built on the site of a former fuel tank farm on Condor Street; and the adjacent MBTA
        "Car Barn" site on Condor and Eagle Streets. The park protrudes into Chelsea Creek and
        includes remnants of a formerly-dredged landing on its downstream edge. The Car Barn
        site is located in an indent along the shoreline. Condor Street and Eagle Street are both
        improved roads with limited traffic which, while not proximate to public transportation, are
        readily accessible by taxi or shuttle bus. The park does not include landside or waterside
        boat landing facilities, and some maintenance dredging would likely be required to
        establish a new landing with adequate water depths. The Car Barn site is fronted by an
        extensive mud flat which would require extensive dredging to be made navigable.

        2.2.5.2       Boston Inner Harbor

        Boston Inner Harbor routes to the Logan Airport Dock and the Boston Harbor Shipyard &
        Marina offer direct connections across Boston Inner Harbor, but necessitate a physically
        longer landside connection to the Project site. These routes have the benefit of existing
        waterside and landside docking infrastructure as well as proximity to public transportation

3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                   2-11 Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                              Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        and direct vehicular connections. The development of additional water taxi or water ferry
        landings at undeveloped or underdeveloped sites in East Boston that are located closer to
        existing bus routes or the Maverick Station may also be possible.

        There are no depth or clearance limitations for water transportation from the public wharfs
        and commuter docks along the downtown Boston and Seaport waterfronts and the existing
        Logan Airport Dock and Boston Harbor Shipyard & Marina in East Boston.

        Both the Logan Airport Dock and the Boston Harbor Shipyard & Marina are located
        approximately one mile directly opposite Boston Inner Harbor from the downtown Boston
        and Seaport waterfronts. The other potential East Boston water landing sites are similarly
        located within close proximity to the downtown Boston and Seaport waterfronts. Water
        travel times to these existing and potential sites are on the order of five to seven minutes.

        The Boston Harbor Shipyard & Marina is within walking distance of MBTA rail and bus
        services, although the existing bus route to the Project site is not direct. The other potential
        East Boston water landing sites are also within walking distance of these landside services.
        Although the East Boston waterfront is more distant from the Project site by land than
        Chelsea Creek or the Orient Heights/Belle Isle Embayment, the existing roadway
        infrastructure is such that landside travel to the Project site by vehicle (e.g., taxi, livery
        service, or shuttle bus) is approximately 10 minutes. As a result (and discounting existing
        bus travel as a component), the combined time of travel to the Project site via the Boston
        Inner Harbor routes is a little over 15 minutes. However, use of this alternative would
        require multiple different transportation modes, which numerous studies have shown
        significantly discourages passenger use.

        2.2.5.3       Orient Heights/Belle Isle Embayment

        The Orient Heights/Belle Isle Embayment is located almost eight miles from the downtown
        Boston waterfront via water. The first half or more of the route travels the eastern extent of
        the Boston Inner Harbor, then veers northward past the approaches to Winthrop Harbor
        and around the eastern edge of Logan Airport. Time of travel and the lack of existing or
        potential docking facilities constrain the feasibility of utilizing this route for water
        transportation to the Project site.

        While the first half of the water route from the downtown Boston and Seaport waterfronts to
        the Orient Heights/Belle Isle Embayment is located within deep waters, the second half
        follows a relatively narrow channel between shoals of the Governors Island Flats and Deer
        Island Flats, past the shallows of Snake Island in Winthrop Harbor, and through the Belle
        Isle straights between Chelsea Point in Winthrop and the runway extensions of Logan
        Airport. While the most recent nautical chart for the Governors Island Flats and Deer Island
        Flats area suggests water depths of 10 feet or more at Mean Low Water, the most recent
        edition of Coast Pilot I suggests a "least depth of 3 feet" along this route. The channel width
        is generally narrow, and decreases to approximately 100 feet through the Belle Isle

3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                   2-12 Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                               Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        straights. Meanwhile, the portion of the route east of Logan Airport and within the
        President Roads approach to the Harbor is susceptible to adverse wind and weather during
        storm events.

        There are no public landings within the Orient Heights/Belle Isle Embayment, and the
        residential character of the northern (i.e., Project-side) of the Orient Heights/Belle Isle
        Embayment limits the potential for establishing a new landing facility. It may be possible to
        establish a public access point for water taxi service at one of the existing private marinas,
        but high-volume access with landside vehicular support may create traffic concerns.

        A public ferry boat landing is located at the Town Pier in Winthrop Harbor, but both the
        water and the landside transportation segments of this route would be as long as or longer
        than those matching segments of the Boston Inner Harbor or Chelsea Creek routes.
        Furthermore, there is no direct public transportation from the Winthrop Town Pier to the
        Project site, and thus the route would require passengers to obtain access to either a second
        bus or the Blue Line rapid transit from the Orient Heights Station.

        Although boats speeds are generally much greater in the outer portions of the Inner Harbor,
        the distances to Winthrop Harbor and the Orient Heights/Belle Isle Embayment, and
        constraints on channel width and configuration, which also limit safe boat speed, are such
        that travel times to the Project site via these routes would be two or three times those of the
        Chelsea Creek and Boston Inner Harbor routes.

        2.2.5.4       Summary

        In terms of convenience and practicality of utilizing water transportation as a component of
        transportation to the Project site, the access across Boston Inner Harbor to the East Boston
        waterfront, and thence to a ground transportation link, is the most efficient route.
        Waterside and landside docking infrastructure is in place, and the landside transportation
        component includes, or is set to include, multimodal options. Conversely, the Chelsea
        Creek and Orient Heights/Belle Isle Embayment are without established docking
        infrastructure, and the locations for establishing such infrastructure are not apparent at the
        terminus of either route. In addition, even if a facility could be constructed at a favorable
        location along either of these routes, a landside transportation component would still be
        required. In either case, the necessary landside component would not be significantly
        different in terms of convenience and practicality than that of the Boston Inner Harbor
        landside component. Ultimately, there would be no benefit to utilizing either of the longer
        water transportation routes in the hope of decreasing the landside travel component.

2.3     Commitment to Green

        The Proponent will set a new standard of excellence in sustainable design for gaming
        development projects. Striving for LEED Gold, the Project will be sustainably designed,
        energy efficient, environmentally conscious, and healthy for its employees and visitors as


3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                   2-13 Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                              Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        well as the nearby neighborhoods. Innovative technologies are currently being explored to
        determine what works best with the Project as well as what might set a visible example for
        those visiting the site.

        Caesars is committed both locally and nationally to achieving a degree of environmental
        sustainability unparalleled in the industry. In 2011, Caesars was the first member of the
        national gaming industry to receive U.S. EPA approval for its GHG reduction plan. In
        2010, Caesars won the WasteWise new Partners Gold Achievement Award from U.S. EPA,
        and in 2008 it was the first in the industry to join the EPA's Climate Leaders Program.

        Caesars' CodeGreen initiative focuses across the board on the company, its employees,
        guests, and suppliers to ensure it remains at the pinnacle of corporate sustainability
        leadership. The Proponent will fully comply with the goals of Massachusetts' revised Solid
        Waste Master Plan and hopes to push the state's goals to new levels of achievement by
        investing in technology such as, possibly, anaerobic digestion for both food waste and
        racetrack wastes.

        As summarized below, the Project includes a conservative approach on floodplain
        management, sea level rise, LEED certification, GHG emissions, and climate change
        preparedness.

        2.3.1         Floodplain Management

        Portions of the Project site are located within the 100-year floodplain as delineated by
        FEMA (see Figure 1-7), and the floodplain has been conservatively classified as BLSF (see
        Section 4.1.6.1) based on two open Orders of Conditions issued by the Boston and Revere
        Conservation Commissions in 2011 (MassDEP File Nos. 006-1276 and 061-0620).
        Recognizing the Project's location within the floodplain and associated exposure to flood
        hazards, careful engineering and design considerations have targeted risk reduction
        strategies and measures to improve existing conditions. The Proponent currently plans to
        provide compensatory flood storage to mitigate potential impacts from flooding. The
        compensatory storage would result in floodplain storage capacity equivalent to or
        exceeding the existing floodplain storage capacity on the property. Exact locations of
        floodplain compensation areas will be further defined as the site design progresses.
        Proposed stormwater management controls will substantially improve the quality of
        discharged water relative to existing conditions, and coupled with the design of site
        development will reduce the rate and volume of stormwater leaving the site (see Section
        4.1.6.2).

        While these measures will attenuate, or at a minimum will not accentuate, flood hazard risk
        on the Project site, flooding will nonetheless occur under storm conditions above a certain
        magnitude. Therefore, all building foundations designed for the Project will be constructed
        to withstand flood conditions and the on-grade parking design for will allow gravity-
        controlled stormwater flows to exit the Project site, and all occupiable spaces for the Project

3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                   2-14 Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                              Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        will be located at or above the Base Flood Elevation (BFE) of 15.46 feet (Boston City Base).
        Mechanical equipment will be placed above the base flood elevation to the maximum
        extent practicable.

        Although the Project site is partially located within a floodplain (see Figure 1-4), there is no
        practicable alternative that would allow redevelopment of this area while avoiding flooding
        hazards entirely. Nonetheless, the Proponent has designed the Project to responsibly
        minimize the risk of flood-related damage and to improve existing conditions. Compliance
        with Federal Executive Order 11988, Floodplain Management, is described in Section
        4.1.12.1.

        2.3.2         Sea Level Rise

        In addition to complying with building codes and FEMA requirements that account for flood
        risks, a responsible development in a coastal area must acknowledge the potential for sea-
        level rise to adversely affect activities in the future. Although the U.S. Geological Survey
        (USGS) assigns a "low" coastal vulnerability level to the Project area, this does not mean the
        area is immune to sea-level rise. A more detailed sea level rise analysis is provided in
        Section 4.1.12.

        As shown on Figure 1-4, the Base Flood Elevation at the Project site is 15.46 feet (Boston
        City Base). The Proponent has conservatively classified the 100-year floodplain as BLSF
        based on two open Orders of Conditions issued by the Boston and Revere Conservation
        Commissions in 2011 (MassDEP File Nos. 006-1276 and 061-0620). The Proponent has
        been made aware that there may be differing interpretations based on specific site
        characteristics and specific storm conditions because, even though no portion of the
        property is subject to tidal action, the site may experience flooding due to one or more
        causes during extreme (e.g., 100-year flood) events and the floodplain may therefore be
        characterized as LSCSF. The Proponent intends to work in consultation with the local
        Conservation Commissions to explore this matter further. Neither BLSF nor LSCSF have a
        100-foot Buffer Zone as defined by the Wetlands Protection Act regulations.

        Although the floodplain does cover portions of the Project site, the proposed building
        footprints for the Resort, including the casino, hotel, and parking garage will not be within
        the currently-designated floodplain. The proposed Casino and hotel first floor elevation will
        be at approximately elevation 28, which is approximately 12 feet higher than current
        floodplain and future estimated floodplain elevations accounting for sea level rise. Every
        effort will be made to locate buildings at an elevation that is above current floodplain
        elevation or future floodplain elevation to the maximum extent practicable.




3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                   2-15 Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                               Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        As the design of the Project advances, the Proponent will also evaluate as necessary the site
        design for consistency with the United States Army Corps of Engineers guidance document
        guidance for sea level rise as well as the EEA Climate Change Adaptation Report. Finally, in
        the DEIR the Proponent will also evaluate the first floor elevation in relation to flood
        elevation.

        2.3.3         LEED Commitments

        As required under Article 37 of the Boston Zoning Code, projects that are subject to Article
        80, Large Project Review, shall be LEED certifiable. There are seven categories in the LEED
        certification guidelines: Sustainable Sites, Water Efficiency, Energy and Atmosphere,
        Materials and Resources, Indoor Environmental Quality, Innovation in Design Process and
        the additional Regional Priority Credits. For this Project, the Proponent is striving to
        achieve LEED Gold, and sustainable measures included in the design include, but are not
        limited to, those addressed in Section 4.2.1.

        2.3.4         Greenhouse Gas Emissions

        Project GHG emissions will be described and quantified, and mitigation measures will be
        documented, in a GHG analysis that will be included within the DEIR in accordance with
        the MEPA GHG Emissions Policy and Protocol. The analysis will clearly demonstrate
        consistency with the objectives of MEPA review by documenting the means by which the
        Proponent plans to avoid, minimize, or mitigate Damage to the Environment to the
        maximum extent feasible. The GHG emissions analysis in the DEIR will address the
        feasibility of mitigation measures suggested in the Policy appendix and, if deemed feasible,
        will include them in the modeling inputs. The rationale for not including any of the
        suggested mitigation measures that would result in a significant reduction of GHG
        emissions will be provided.

        The potential for alternative and renewable energy sources to be incorporated into the
        Project will be examined. Potential use of photovoltaic (PV) electricity generation and
        green roofs will be examined, as well as a CHP system and the potential for anaerobic
        digestion. In compliance with LEED guidelines, the Project will practice Enhanced
        Refrigerant Control, where refrigerants will be selected to minimize their ozone depletion
        and global warming potential. In addition, the management of manure and food waste will
        also be considered as part of the GHG analysis in the DEIR. The DEIR will also address the
        Boston Climate Action Executive Order. Transportation-related GHG emissions reductions
        from roadway and signalization changes and TDM programs will be calculated and
        reported.

        A more detailed discussion of the proposed GHG analysis is provided in Section 4.1.11.




3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                  2-16 Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                            Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        2.3.5         Climate Change Preparedness

        In addition to floodplain management, sea level rise, sustainable design, and GHG
        emissions, the DEIR will also include a discussion of the Proponent's climate change
        preparedness in terms of the Project's potential vulnerability to storm surge, increased storm
        frequency, rising temperatures, increased frequency of extreme heat, and precipitation
        changes, as appropriate.

        2.3.6         TDM Commitments

        The Proponent proposes significant physical enhancements to pedestrian and bicycle access
        to, and circulation within, the Project site to support alternate travel modes. These
        enhancements include ample bicycle parking for employees and patrons and an enhanced
        shuttle service connecting the Suffolk Downs MBTA Blue Line station to the Project
        buildings as an alternate "all-weather" connection to the enhanced pathway system. In
        addition to addressing existing deficiencies in off-site pedestrian and bicycle
        accommodations, the Proponent is committed to incorporating "Complete Streets"
        principles in the design of on- and off-site traffic and roadway improvements.

        Multi-modal transportation access for the Project will be supported by a robust TDM plan
        that will provide incentives to encourage use of alternative transportation modes and
        discourage SOV travel. The TDM plan will be tailored to the differing specific needs of
        patrons and employees. In addition, the Proponent is committed to exploring opportunities
        for connections to water transportation and high occupancy vehicle (HOV) service to
        transportation nodes, hotels, and other visitor hubs, including coordination with Massport
        and other entities. The DEIR will contain additional detail about these commitments.

2.4     Construction Schedule

        Project construction will commence promptly following receipt of the gaming license and
        necessary permits and approvals beyond applicable appeal periods. The widening of Route
        1A and the Route 1A "flyover" are expected to commence approximately four months after
        Project site construction work begins. Barring unforeseen delays, the full Project is
        expected to be complete approximately 30 months after commencement of construction.




3263/Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                   2-17 Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Project Description                                                             Epsilon Associates, Inc.
      Section 3.0
TRANSPORTATION
3.0     TRANSPORTATION

This section describes the multi-modal transportation characteristics of the proposed Caesars Resort
at Suffolk Downs, and discusses existing conditions and potential future conditions without, and
with, the proposed Project (i.e., No-Build and Build conditions, respectively). A range of potential
transportation improvements and mitigation measures are identified to address existing local and
regional transportation problems in the area and to minimize potential negative impacts of the
Project. These include physical multi-modal transportation infrastructure improvements and
strategies as well as a proposed TDM plan to reduce SOV travel and encourage use of alternative
transportation modes by patrons and employees. It is intended that the proposed transportation
plan for the Project will go far beyond mitigating potential traffic impacts of the Project, and will
also address long-standing issues of local and regional concern.

3.1     Introduction

        Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc. (VHB) was retained by Sterling Suffolk Racecourse LLC (the
        Proponent) in 2009 to: (i) study the access needs and potential impacts of a resort casino
        project at Suffolk Downs, and (ii) identify existing local and regional transportation issues.
        VHB performed a preliminary analysis of the transportation needs and impacts of a resort
        gaming project including approximately 3,000 slot machines and 60 gaming tables, along
        with supporting hotel, restaurant, bars and retail facilities. The study also identified specific
        existing local and regional traffic problems on the study area roadway network, and
        developed infrastructure improvement concepts that would address existing traffic and
        safety problems as well as mitigate potential project impacts and provide satisfactory access
        for the Project site.

        Among other key findings, the 2009 study confirmed substantial existing peak period
        congestion and delay at the Boardman Street intersection on Route 1A as well as
        inadequate capacity and safety of the existing site access on Route 1A at Tomasello Drive.
        A preliminary improvement concept to address these issues was developed, referred to as
        the Boardman Street Fly-over,

        New traffic counts were performed at key locations where then-current data were not
        available. This program included Friday evening peak and Saturday afternoon peak period
        turning movement counts (TMCs) at study intersections and automatic traffic recorder (ATR)
        counts over consecutive seven-day periods at key locations.

        3.1.1          Project Overview

        The proposed Project is described in detail in Section 2.0. In brief, Caesars Resort at Suffolk
        Downs is a redevelopment proposed on approximately 161 acres of land that will contain
        two distinct gaming areas, two hotels, a multi-purpose meeting/entertainment space,
        parking, fine dining, sports bars, and retail space, while maintaining and enhancing the
        existing horse racing facilities. Specific Project elements are discussed in Section 2.2.

3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF          3-1     Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                              Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
        The Project includes major off-site roadway, traffic, and safety improvements, comprising new
        roadway infrastructure to be designed and constructed in consultation with MassDOT and the
        City of Boston on Route 1A in the vicinity of the site. These improvements could include a
        Route 1A northbound flyover at Boardman Street, an additional Route 1A southbound lane,
        traffic signal control at Waldemar Avenue, and expansion and signalization of the Tomasello
        Drive intersection. The design of these improvements will be developed in consultation with
        MassDOT and the City of Boston to address existing local and regional traffic difficulties at
        Boardman Street, improve safety, and provide ample capacity to accommodate Project trips
        entering and exiting the site.

        A preliminary concept plan for these improvements is shown in Figure 3-10, presented in
        Section 3.4.

        In addition, as part of the discussions for the Host and Surrounding Community
        Agreements, the cities of Revere and Chelsea have asked that existing regional traffic issues
        along the Route 60 and Route 1 corridors be studied to identify and assist in funding
        potential improvements. New ramp connections at the Route 1/Route 16 interchange and
        improvements along the Revere Beach Parkway corridor have been identified as potential
        mid-term improvements, which, consistent with the Boston MPO's Lower North Shore
        Transportation Improvement Study (prepared by the Central Transportation Planning Staff
        for the Massachusetts Highway Department in October 2000), would shift some regional
        and Project traffic from the Route 60 corridor to Route 1/Route 16. Such strategic new
        connections would be expected to address long-standing regional traffic issues in the Cities
        of Revere and Chelsea along the Route 60 corridor through Butler Circle and Bell Circle, as
        well as along Route 16/Revere Beach Parkway between Webster Avenue and the split to
        Route 145.
        Any such improvements would be intended primarily to address pre-existing regional traffic
        problems, independent of the proposed Project and would be expected to realize benefits
        for regional traffic that far exceed the potential impacts of Project traffic. The design of the
        improvements would be developed in consultation with MassDOT, DCR, and the cities of
        Revere and Chelsea. A preliminary concept plan for these improvements is shown in
        Figure 3-11, presented in Section 3.4.
        3.1.2         Study Scope
        The transportation analysis for the Project to be presented in the DEIR will consider four
        scenarios, as follows:
            1. Existing (2012) conditions, based on recent traffic counts at study area locations and
               inventory of the existing transportation infrastructure;

            2. 2020 No-Build future conditions, assuming that the Project is not built;

            3. 2020 Build future conditions, with the Project complete and operational; and



3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF          3-2    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                             Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
            4. 2020 Build with Mitigation.

        It should be noted that the 2020 No-Build and Build conditions reflect a "horizon" year
        beyond the standard 5-year timeline typically addressed in a DEIR analysis. A proposed
        study area and study intersection locations for the DEIR are presented in Figure 3-1, as
        detailed in Section 3.2.6. Should the City of Boston, the City of Revere or MassDOT
        believe it is necessary, the Proponent is prepared to add additional local intersections to the
        study area for the DEIR analysis.

        In addition to the roadway and traffic analysis, the DEIR analysis will evaluate transit,
        bicycle, and pedestrian access and identify TDM programs and strategies to be
        implemented by the Proponent. Potential TDM strategies are presented in Section 3.7.

        3.1.3        Summary of Transportation Context and Potential Project Benefits

        Key aspects of the transportation overview presented in the following sections include the
        following:

        3.1.3.1      Existing Transportation Conditions

            1. The Project site is very well located in relation to the Interstate and regional
               roadway systems and enjoys direct connections via Route 1A and the Ted Williams
               Tunnel and the Sumner Tunnel to I-93 North, I-93 South (Southeast Expressway),
               and I-90 West continuing west through central Massachusetts, as well as to and from
               Downtown Boston and I-93 via the Sumner and Callahan Tunnels.

            2. Observations indicate that there is significant regional congestion in the Route 1A
               corridor, and continuing north on Route 60 through Revere to Route 1. Difficulties
               on Route 60 are exacerbated by missing direct connections between Route 1 and
               Route 16, and to the north by limited roadway space on Route 1 at Copeland Circle
               and beyond.

            3. Existing regional traffic congestion impacts local access for East Boston, Revere and
               Winthrop, in particular at the Boardman Street/Route 1A intersection. Although the
               Project site is served by three vehicular access points, access to the site is also
               impacted by the regional traffic congestion.

            4. Regional and local traffic congestion is expected to prevail in the foreseeable future
               in the absence of any specifically programmed and funded major transportation
               infrastructure improvements.

            5. The Project site is well served by public transportation and benefits from MBTA
               Blue line service at the abutting Suffolk Downs station, as well as local and express
               bus routes within one-quarter mile of the site.



3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         3-3      Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                             Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
            6. Sidewalks are provided on the majority of the study area roadways, but the physical
               condition of sidewalks and ADA compliance is deficient in several locations, and
               appropriate pedestrian crossing accommodations are absent at many locations.

            7. The existing bicycle infrastructure in the immediate vicinity of the Project site is
               limited, although significant bicycle improvements have been made, in particular in
               the East Boston neighborhoods.

        3.1.3.2      Project Travel Characteristics

            1. Based on proprietary data from numerous existing Caesars venues, it is expected
               that project trip generation will be spread over the 24-hour day, and throughout the
               7-day week, with more than half of weekly gaming activity occurring on Friday,
               Saturday and Sunday combined.

            2. The Project is expected to generate very limited trips during the morning commuter
               period. Peak Project generation is expected to occur after the evening peak
               commuter period during the week and after the afternoon peak on Saturdays.
               Therefore, the existing commuter peak periods are not expected to coincide with
               peak Project trip generation.

            3. As a result of the regional highway connections, a high proportion of Project trips
               are expected to arrive from Route 1A south of Suffolk Downs. Very limited use of
               the Bennington Street corridor and neighborhood streets by Project traffic is
               expected.

            4. While the majority of patrons are expected to travel by auto, the majority of
               employees are expected travel by transit and high-occupancy shuttle service.

        3.1.3.3      Project Benefits Addressing Existing Local & Regional Transportation Issues

            1. Subject to design development in coordination with MassDOT and the City of
               Boston, the proposed Route 1A improvements that are integral to the Project will
               likely go far beyond mitigating the potential impacts of Project trips, significantly
               improving safety and traffic capacity in the vicinity of the site, with reduced queuing
               and delays for both local and regional traffic as well as excellent access to the site
               for Project trips.

            2. Of key importance, the incorporation of well-designed facilities for sidewalks at
               intersections and roadway crossings will enhance pedestrian safety. In addition, the
               Project site layout has been designed to encourage pedestrian activity to and from
               the site by making appropriate connections to the existing off-site pedestrian
               network in the area.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         3-4    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                            Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
            3. As part of the Host and Surrounding Community Agreements to be committed to by
               the Proponent, the Project benefits may, subject to design development in
               coordination with MassDOT, DCR and the cities of Revere and Chelsea, include
               new ramp connections at the Route 1/Route 16 interchange and other safety
               improvements along the Revere Beach Parkway corridor, consistent with the Lower
               North Shore Transportation Improvement Study.

            4. Again subject to design development in coordination with MassDOT, DCR and the
               cities of Revere and Chelsea, the Route 1/Route 16 improvements would be
               expected to significantly relieve the Route 60 corridor through Revere by reducing
               traffic volumes, including volumes at Bell Circle. While they would be intended
               primarily to address pre-existing regional traffic problems, independent of the
               proposed Project, it is expected that patrons of the Project would take advantage of
               these new connections should they be built. Nevertheless, the connections would
               be expected to realize benefits for regional traffic that far exceed the potential
               impacts of Project traffic.

            5. Such Route 1/Route 16 improvements would be expected to also provide significant
               relief to observed current congestion at the Route 16/Webster Avenue/Garfield
               Avenue intersection in Chelsea.

            6. Other potential traffic, roadway and safety infrastructure improvements will be
               studied at key local intersections.

            7. The Proponent intends to coordinate with the MBTA on ways in which to maximize
               the use of MBTA services by patrons and employees, and to strengthen the
               connections between the Project and public transportation.

            8. The Project will provide on-street bicycle accommodations, with spur bicycle
               connections to the Project site. These improvements will create a `beach-to-beach'
               connection between Constitution Beach to the south and Revere Beach to the north,
               as well as enhancing bicycle access to the Project's on site bicycle accommodations
               and parking and the entrance to DCR's Belle Isle Marsh.

            9. The Project site plan will enhance and strengthen the safety and quality of the
               existing pedestrian link across the site from the Orient Heights neighborhood and
               from points in Revere.

        3.1.3.4      Parking and Transportation Demand Management (TDM)

            1. The existing site parking supply of some 6,000 spaces will be reduced to
               approximately 5,150 spaces, which is expected to adequately accommodate the
               Project's peak parking demand.



3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        3-5    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                          Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
            2. Parking management and transit, bicycle and pedestrian connectivity enhancements
               to support alternate travel modes will be supported by a robust TDM plan. The
               TDM plan will comprise a comprehensive package of incentives to encourage non-
               single occupant vehicle travel, including public transit as an access mode,
               particularly for employees.

3.2     2012 Existing Conditions

        This section provides an overview of existing transportation conditions in the study area
        including transit service, pedestrian and bicycle accommodations, and observed conditions
        on the local and regional roadway networks.

        3.2.1        Public Transit

        The Project site is well served by public transportation, with several public transportation
        options within one-quarter mile of the site including bus routes and subway routes provided
        by the MBTA. These services are illustrated in Figure 3-2, and their service and operational
        characteristics are described in further detail below.

        3.2.1.1      Bus Service

        There are eight bus routes available near the Project site, as follows (all trip times and
        service levels are weekday service):

             Route 119 (Northgate to Beachmont Station) runs from 5:00AM to 10:48PM on 25-
             to 35-minute headways during peak periods and 60-minute headways during off-
             peak periods. This bus route stops on Route 145/Winthrop Avenue in the vicinity of
             the Project site.

             Route 120 (Orient Heights to Maverick Station) runs from 5:25AM to 1:18AM on
             16- to 20-minute headways during peak periods and 30- to 60-minute headways
             during off-peak periods. This bus route stops on Bennington Street near Orient
             Heights in the vicinity of the Project site.

             Routes 424, 434, 448 and 449 are all Commuter Buses running from different
             communities in the north shore to Haymarket Station or Downtown Crossing
             Station. Commuter routes have local service at the ends of the routes, but run
             express for the majority of the route in and out of Boston. Although the routes
             travel down Route 1A/ McClellan Highway/ Lee Burbank Highway, there are no
             stops in the vicinity of the Project site.

             Routes 450 (Salem Depot to Haymarket Station) runs from 4:46AM to 1:42AM on
             30-minute headways during peak periods and 60- to 80-minute headways during
             non-peak periods. This bus route stops on Route 1A/ McClellan Highway/ Lee
             Burbank Highway in the vicinity of the Project site.

3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        3-6    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                          Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
              Routes 459 (Salem Depot to Downtown) runs from 5:40AM to 8:15PM on 60- to
              65-minute headways through the day. This bus route stops on Route 1A/ McClellan
              Highway/ Lee Burbank Highway in the vicinity of the Project site.

        Based on the MBTA's Route Performance Indicators data, provided on the MBTA website,
        the average daily ridership in 2010 on the two local bus routes serving Suffolk Downs are
        1,101 daily passengers and 3,071 daily passengers on Routes 119 and 120, respectively.
        The two express buses which have stops in the vicinity of the Project Site currently serve
        1,549 and 1,085 average daily passengers on Route 450 and Route 459, respectively.

        3.2.1.2        Rapid Transit Service

        The Blue Line rapid transit line provides service from Wonderland Station in Revere to
        Bowdoin Station in Boston between 5:13Am and 12:49AM, running every five minutes
        during the peak hour. The closest station to the Project site is Suffolk Downs Station, which
        is accessible from both Bennington Street and Waldemar Avenue. The Blue Line connects
        with the Orange Line at State Street, the Green Line at Government Center, and water
        shuttle service at Aquarium. According to the 13th Edition of the Ridership and Service
        Statistics Blue Book, published by the MBTA in 2010, on a typical weekday approximately
        57,273 riders board the Blue Line, 794 of whom (1.4% of typical weekday ridership) are
        reported to board at the Suffolk Downs Station.        There are no alighting data readily
        available from the MBTA.

        Table 3-1 presents a summary of the peak-hour frequencies for MBTA services in the area.

        3.2.1.3         Shuttle Buses

        Suffolk Downs Racetrack operates a shuttle bus service between Suffolk Downs Station and
        the racetrack facilities. The shuttle runs with approximately 10-minute headways when the
        racetrack is open.

        3.2.2           Pedestrian Environment

        In addition to collecting vehicle volume data, data collection to date includes pedestrian
        counts at key intersections. A brief overview of pedestrian activities in the study area
        follows.

        Sidewalks are provided on the majority of the study area streets except for Tomasello Drive
        (privately owned), which provides a sidewalk only for a short distance in the vicinity of the
        north driveway into the Project site. The physical condition of sidewalks is deficient in
        several locations.

        Crosswalks are provided on the majority of the study area intersections, although Americans
        with Disabilities Act (ADA)-compliance is deficient at many locations. In addition, there are
        malfunctioning or missing pedestrian signal equipment (e.g., pedestrian push buttons or
        signal heads) at several locations.

        Observations indicate that peak hour pedestrian activity in the area is relatively low, with
        the exception of the commercial/transit nodes at Beachmont Station and Orient Heights
        Station.



3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF               3-8    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                                 Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
        3.2.3        Bicycle Accommodations

        The existing bicycle infrastructure in the immediate vicinity of the Project site is limited,
        although significant bicycle improvements have been made, particularly in the East Boston
        neighborhoods. The East Boston Greenway and the bicycle accommodations along
        Chelsea Street and Bennington Street provide good connectivity south of the Project site.
        Figure 3-3 shows existing, as well as proposed, local area bicycle accommodations. Bicycle
        improvements proposed by the Proponent will be described in detail in the DEIR.

        3.2.3.1      East Boston Greenway

        The East Boston Greenway is a linear park that runs approximately three miles between the
        East Boston waterfront and East Boston neighborhoods just north of Prescott Street. The
        Greenway is "L-shaped" and starts at Piers Park, runs along Marginal Street, turns 90
        degrees and runs parallel to Bremen Street, and then terminates near Lovell Street. The
        Greenway provides mixed use pedestrian and bicycle paths and provides good recreational
        connection between several parks in East Boston.

        3.2.3.2      Chelsea Street and Bennington Street Corridors

        The City of Boston has installed on-street bicycle lanes along Chelsea Street between
        Maverick Square in the south and Day Square to the north (approximately three-quarters of
        a mile). These bicycle lanes serve both directions and provide on-street accommodations
        parallel to the East Boston Greenway. A typical cross section of the road includes curbside
        parallel parking, a bicycle lane, and a single vehicular travel lane in each direction.

        Shared lane markings exist on the length of Bennington Street between Neptune Road and
        Saratoga Street. Shared lane markings are provided on both sides of the street, which has a
        typical cross-section containing parking lanes on each side and two vehicular travel lanes in
        each direction. The shared lane markings are located on the travel lane adjacent to the
        curbside parking.

        3.2.3.3      Bicycle Infrastructure Planned by Others

        The City of Boston has plans to extend the East Boston Greenway from its existing northern
        terminus to the new Neptune Green Park, adjacent to the Wood Island MBTA Station,
        between the Blue Line tracks and Logan Airport's new bus depot, and to a small Wood
        Island Marsh Overlook park to be built at the end of Short Street. Construction of the
        extension is expected to begin in the near future.

        Additional discussions regarding extending the Greenway to connect to Constitution Beach
        and even further to the Belle Isle Marsh Reservation are currently in the early phases of
        planning and the future of these plans is unknown. This extension to the Belle Isle Marsh
        would provide a bicycle/pedestrian connection for the entire length of East Boston.



3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         3-9    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                           Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
        The Metropolitan Area Planning Council is working with several community clusters to
        create safe networks for non-vehicular travel. The City of Revere is included in one of 4
        clusters, along with the cities of Chelsea, Everett, Malden and Lynn, and the Town of
        Saugus. The status of this initiative will be discussed in the DEIR.

        3.2.4        Roadway Network

        The location of the Project site in relation to the regional roadway network is shown in
        Figure 3-4. The Project site is surrounded by Route 1A (a state highway) to the west, Route
        145 (Revere Beach Pkwy/Winthrop Avenue) to the north, Bennington Street to the east, and
        Waldemar Avenue to the south.

        Because of its location in East Boston and Revere, the Project site is well located in relation
        to the Interstate and regional roadway systems. Specifically, the site is located on Route 1A
        approximately 1 mile north of the eastern terminus of I-90 (Massachusetts Turnpike) at
        Logan Airport, and therefore enjoys direct connections via the Ted Williams Tunnel and the
        Sumner Tunnel to I-93 North and I-93 South (Southeast Expressway), as well as I-90 West
        continuing west through central Massachusetts. In addition, Route 1A connects to and from
        Downtown Boston and I-93 via the Sumner and Callahan Tunnels. There is a toll for
        vehicles travelling toward Downtown Boston (away from the Project site) in both the
        Sumner and Ted Williams Tunnels.

        From the north, Route 1 is an important regional corridor, but it relies on connections via
        Route 60 through Revere, and an incomplete connection with Revere Beach Parkway, to
        access the Project site via Route 1A or Route 145(Winthrop Avenue). Additional sub-
        regional access from the north is provided by Route 1A North through Swampscott and
        beyond, and via Route 60 and Route 107 to Salem.

        Immediately to the west, Route 145 (Revere Beach Parkway) provides connections to Route
        16, which in turn connects with I-93 in Medford, and somewhat circuitously to Routes 2
        and 3 to the northwest.

        3.2.5        Site Access

        As shown in Figure 3-5, existing vehicular access to the site is provided by Tomasello
        Drive, a privately-owned roadway through the site, with connections to Route 1A and
        Route 145 (Revere Beach Pkwy/Winthrop Avenue). Furlong Drive, a public way from
        Route 1A to the Target/Stop & Shop plaza, provides an additional access connection
        between Route 1A and Tomasello Drive, via a publically-accessible private drive through
        the plaza.

        Tomasello Drive at Route 1A is un-signalized, and left-turns out of the site to Route 1A
        southbound are prohibited, except during large events at Suffolk Downs when a police
        detail is provided. At Route 145 (Revere Beach Pkwy/Winthrop Avenue), Tomasello Drive
        is signalized in coordination with the off-set intersection at North Shore Road. While

3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         3-10    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                            Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
        Furlong Drive connects with Tomasello Drive at a stop-controlled intersection within the
        site, turning movements to and from Furlong Drive at Route 1A are limited to right-in and
        right-out on the northbound side of Route 1A.

        3.2.6          Proposed Study Area

        A proposed study area for the DEIR, as previously presented in Figure 3-1, includes the
        following intersections:

            1. Route 1A at Suffolk Downs (Tomasello Drive);
            2. Route 1A at Furlong Drive (un-signalized);
            3. Winthrop Avenue (Route 145) at Route 1A southbound On-Ramp;
            4. (a) Winthrop Avenue (Route 145) at North Shore Road;
                 (b) Winthrop Avenue (Route 145) at Suffolk Downs (Tomasello Drive);
            5. Bennington Street/State Road at Winthrop Avenue;
            6. Bennington Street at Saratoga Street;
            7. Boardman Street at Route 1A;
            8. Winthrop Avenue (Route 145) at Revere Beach Parkway (Route 16)/Harris Street;
            9. (a) Route 60 (American Legion Highway) at Bell Circle;
                 (b) Route 1A (Beach Street) at Bell Circle;
                 (c) Route 16 and Route 1A at Bell Circle;
                 (d) Beach Street at Bell Circle;
            10. Ocean Avenue at State Road/Revere Beach Parkway;
            11. Eliot Circle (roundabout/rotary);
            12. Route 1A at Jug Handle;
            13. (a) Bennington Street at Neptune Road;
                 (b) Neptune Road at Route 1A NB off-ramp;
            14. Butler Circle (roundabout/rotary);
            15. Revere Street at Route 60;
            16. Brown Circle (roundabout/rotary);
            17. Copeland Circle (three weave locations, one merge location)
            18. Route 1/Route 16 Interchange (three merge locations);
            19. Route 16 (Revere Beach Parkway) at Garfield Avenue/Webster Avenue; and
            20. Route 1A northbound at Waldemar Avenue (un-signalized).

3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF            3-11   Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                              Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
        Although the majority of study intersections operate under traffic signal control, two
        locations on Route 1A (Furlong Drive and Waldemar Avenue) are under stop control. The
        expanded study area includes three roundabouts/rotaries (Elliot, Butler, and Brown Circles).
        Despite its name, Bell Circle (the intersection of Routes 1A, 16, and 60) is not a roundabout
        or rotary, but rather it is controlled by a set of four coordinated traffic signals. Similarly,
        Copeland Circle is not a roundabout or rotary, but comprises a series of weave and merge
        sections within its rotary-style layout. Because it comprises a series of on- and off-ramps,
        the Route 1/Route 16 interchange also involves merge locations.

        The differences in the types of intersection control will be reflected in the DEIR traffic
        operations analysis.

        3.2.7        Data Collection

        To provide a basis for evaluation of existing traffic operational conditions in the DEIR
        throughout the study area, bi-directional daily traffic volume data were collected for an
        entire week in June 2010 along Route 1A (two locations), Route 16, and Route 60, the key
        roadways surrounding the Project site.

        Supplemental daily counts were performed for a full week in July 2012 along Route 1A, as
        well as at the three site access roads, Tomasello Drive at Route 1A, Tomasello Drive at
        Route 145, and Furlong Drive.

        In addition to daily traffic volumes, manual TMCs were conducted in June 2010 at the
        majority of the proposed study area intersections, while data from local studies conducted
        in 2009 were available for a limited number of locations. Counts were conducted during
        the Friday evening commuter peak hours and Saturday afternoon hours.

        3.2.8        Existing Daily Traffic Volumes

        Daily traffic volumes were established by ATR counts at seven locations in June 2010, as
        presented in Figure 3-6. These counts were performed over a full week (seven-day) period,
        and include a repetition of the ATR on Route 1A near the Project site in July 2012 to
        provide a comparison with the 2010 data.

        The daily traffic volume information derived from the ATR data is summarized in Table 3-2.
        In addition to illustrating the pattern of traffic flow in the study area, as influenced by
        nearby land-use and commuting patterns, these data will also serve as the basis for
        identifying the critical analysis and design periods for the Project.

        Daily traffic patterns from the ATRs show that the most traveled corridor of the locations
        counted currently is Route 1A south of Furlong Drive with a weekday ADT of
        approximately 61,700 vpd. The directional split is slightly greater in the SB direction
        towards Boston (56%). Route 1A north of the Route 145 ramps has a higher split in the NB


3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         3-12    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                            Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
                     direction towards Bell Circle (58%). On Saturday, traffic on Route 1A is approximately
                     15% less compared to Friday, the busiest weekday. At other locations, traffic volumes are
                     between approximately 13-15% lower on Saturday compared to Friday.

                     The three vehicular access points to Suffolk Downs have a combined weekday ADT of
                     15,933 vpd. Of the 15,933 vpd, 63% of the total volume enters/exits on Tomasello Drive
                     south of Route 145, 20% enters/exits on Furlong Drive east of Route 1A, and 17%
                     enters/exits on Tomasello Drive east of Route 1A. On Tomasello Drive south of Route 145
                     the majority of traffic, 63% and 56%, is exiting Suffolk Downs on Friday and Saturday
                     respectively. On Tomasello Drive east of Route 1A the majority of traffic is entering, 85%,
                     on Friday and exiting, 52%, on Saturday. Traffic on Furlong Drive has roughly an even split
                     between entering and exiting on both Friday and Saturday.
