                      3.2.9             Peak Hour Traffic Volumes

                      The Friday and Saturday peak period TMCs were analyzed to identify the peak one-hour
                      (60-minute) period for the roadway network. The actual peak hour is not necessarily the
                      same at each study location, but generally occurs between 4:00PM and 6:00PM on a
                      weekday, and between 2:00PM and 5:00PM on a Saturday. Because the base traffic counts
                      reflect year 2010 conditions, a nominal growth factor of 0.5% per annum was applied to
                      provide a conservative 2012 Existing condition baseline. In practice, very limited, if any,
                      growth has been experienced on area roadways over the past five years or so, and indeed
                      volumes at some locations may even have declined since that time. When the 2012 ATR
                      performed on Route 1A north of Tomasello Drive is compared to the previous 2010 ATR
                      and seasonally adjusted, there is no significant change at that location.

                      The 2012 Existing condition Friday PM and Saturday peak hour traffic volumes at all
                      proposed study locations are presented in Figures 3-7 (A & B) and Figures 3-8 (A & B),
                      respectively.




             3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                    3-14         Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
             Transportation                                                                                  Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
        3.2.10       Existing Project Site Traffic

        Under existing conditions, the Project site generates trips associated with the Suffolk Downs
        Racetrack which, although somewhat seasonal in nature, is operational throughout the year.
        In addition, the three vehicular site access points (Route 1A/Tomasello Drive, Route
        145/Winthrop Avenue/Tomasello Drive, and Route 1A/Furlong Drive) attract other users not
        associated with the Project site itself. These include trips associated with the retail plaza
        abutting the site on Furlong Drive and un-related trips that utilize Tomasello Drive as a
        connection between Route 1A and Route 145/Winthrop Avenue.

        It is difficult to distinguish accurately between the different users of the three site access
        points, but the aggregate traffic volumes on each access road are identified in the Friday PM
        and Saturday peak turning movement network figures. Based on the daily driveway
        volumes discussed previously in Section 3.2.8 and presented in Table 3-2, approximately
        63% of total existing driveway volumes use Tomasello Drive at Route 145, compared to
        approximately 17% on Tomasello Drive at Route 1A and 20% on Furlong Drive.

        3.2.11       Crash Analysis

        The DEIR/DEIR will include an analysis of study-area crash data from MassDOT records for
        the most recently available three-year period.

        3.2.12       Parking

        A substantial portion of the Project site comprises surface parking, with a total capacity of
        approximately 5,830 spaces. The parking areas are generally defined by surface striping and
        limited raised curbing. Although crosswalks are marked along parts of Tomasello Drive,
        there are no sidewalks or formal pedestrian walkways on the site.

        Off-site parking in the vicinity of the site is presented in Figure 3-9. While some time-
        restricted on-street parking is available, portions of the abutting residential neighborhoods
        are controlled by Resident Parking Permit (RPP) restrictions. Limits of the East Boston and
        City of Revere RPP zones and time-restricted parking cover residential streets that are within
        easy walking distance of the MBTA stations, and it is assumed that these are intended to
        deter commuter parking in the neighborhoods.

3.3     2017 No-Build Traffic Projections

        The DEIR will include a No-Build traffic analysis based on the projection of traffic volumes
        for a "horizon" year of 2020, assuming that the proposed Project is not built. This will
        comprise general background growth due to regional growth and traffic associated with
        specific planned developments or transportation projects.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF             3-15   Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                               Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
        Preliminary review of traffic volume data suggests that there has been little, if any, growth,
        in recent years. Therefore, a conservative rate of 0.5% per year is suggested as an
        appropriate background growth rate for the DEIR analysis.

        As discussed in Section 2.2, the proposed Project will retain the existing racetrack
        operations at Suffolk Downs. In the event that the Project does not proceed, however, it is
        anticipated that the racetrack function will not be sustainable in the long term, and that
        more realistically the entire Suffolk Downs site might be developed for some form of mixed-
        use development. This potential outcome is not anticipated in the near term, however, and
        therefore it would not be appropriate to include the potential traffic associated with such a
        build-out in the No-Build traffic projections.

        A Draft Traffic Feasibility Study for a previously proposed mixed-use development of the
        Project site was prepared by Vanasse & Associates, Inc. in 2008 (based upon 2006 traffic
        volumes). A detailed trip generation comparison will be presented in the DEIR.

3.4     2017 Build Conditions

        The DEIR will include a detailed travel demand/trip generation analysis for the Project by all
        modes. Build (2017) condition traffic volumes on study area roadways will be developed to
        facilitate analysis of potential traffic impacts.

        3.4.1        Project Travel Demand

        The Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation manual does not contain
        guidance appropriate for the proposed Project land use. Therefore, the Project trip
        generation projections will be based on research of data for other comparable projects, and
        information provided by the Proponent including proprietary data for existing gaming
        venues and projected data for its proposed operations at Suffolk Downs.

        A synthesis of information and data used in the development of the Project travel
        characteristics and trip generation will be included in the DEIR.

        3.4.2        Trip Generation Characteristics

        The trip generation characteristics of the proposed Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs will be
        unique to this type of proposed land use and the specific operator. In addition, the general
        travel demand characteristics will need to be adjusted to reflect the unique geographic
        location of the proposed Project and its supporting transportation infrastructure. These
        characteristics will be reflected in the DEIR analysis.

        In general, it is expected that the Project trip generation will vary by both day of week and
        time of day, with more than half of the weekly gaming activity expected to occur on Friday,
        Saturday, and Sunday.



3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        3-16    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                            Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
        Since the proposed Project is expected to operate 24 hours per day, it is expected that there
        will be significant variation in trip generation throughout the day. The distribution by time
        of day will be based on an analysis of data for other gaming facilities owned or operated by
        Caesars. The DEIR analysis will reflect different hourly distributions for employees and
        patrons. In addition, the analysis will reflect employee shift changes, which are expected to
        include a wide range of employee types with differing shift changes.

        3.4.3         Projected Project Trips

        The DEIR analysis will include the basis for mode share and vehicle occupancy
        assumptions from which trip generation by mode is developed. Daily and peak hour
        Project trip projections by mode will be presented for patrons and employees separately
        and combined. The continuation of operation of the race track will be included in the
        Project trip projections. It is not expected that activity associated with the race track itself
        will attract additional patrons in its own right, except for special events which, as racing is a
        daytime activity, will not occur during peak activity periods. Rather, it is expected that
        some race track patrons will choose to also use the Project's resort facilities, and, to a lesser
        extent, visa-versa.

        Based on preliminary analysis for the ENF, a total of approximately 24,600 daily vehicle
        trips are projected for the Project, as noted on the ENF form. A portion of the Project
        vehicle trips will comprise existing trips already using the roadway network.

        3.4.4         Trip Distribution & Assignment

        The geographic directional distribution of Project trips is a function of several variables
        including the relative locations and densities of population, competing land uses, existing
        travel patterns, and the efficiency of the roadways leading to the Project site. Trip
        distribution patterns for the DEIR analysis will be developed based on the gravity
        model prepared by the Proponent which yields the geographic distribution of patrons by
        community or zip code. Project vehicle trips will be assigned to the regional and local
        roadway network based on existing travel patterns and route choices available to drivers.

        The choice of routes by drivers to get to and from the Project site access points will be
        influenced by significant roadway infrastructure improvements. As noted previously, the
        Project includes major off-site roadway, traffic, and safety improvements, specifically the
        construction of major new roadway infrastructure on Route 1A in the vicinity of the site.
        The DEIR analysis will reflect these changes.

        A further factor in the assignment of project trips will be the impact of tolls returning west-
        bound through both the Sumner and Ted Williams tunnels. It is expected that some trips
        arriving through the Harbor tunnels will depart via Route 16 to access I-93 North in order to
        avoid paying a toll. Again, the DEIR trip assignment analysis will reflect this phenomenon.



3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF          3-17    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                              Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
        3.4.5        Peak Hour Build Condition Traffic Volumes

        The DEIR will include an analysis to determine the worst combination of projected Project
        traffic and existing roadway volumes to determine the critical peak hours for analysis on a
        Friday and a Saturday.

        3.4.6        Build Condition Project-Related Roadway Infrastructure

        As noted in Section 3.1.1, the Project includes a proposal for major off-site roadway, traffic,
        and safety improvements, comprising new roadway infrastructure to be designed and
        constructed in consultation with MassDOT and the City of Boston on Route 1A in the vicinity
        of the site. These improvements could include a Route 1A northbound flyover at Boardman
        Street, an additional Route 1A southbound lane, and the signalization of the Route
        1A/Waldemar Avenue and Route 1A/Tomasello Drive intersections.

        A preliminary concept plan for these improvements is presented in Figure 3-10. The design
        of these improvements will be developed in consultation with MassDOT and the City of
        Boston to reflect specific findings of the DEIR traffic analysis.

        Due to the preliminary nature of the design, the Proponent does not, as yet, control all of
        the land necessary to construct the improvements. The Proponent is in discussions with the
        various property owners regarding land acquisition. An updated report on land ownership
        will be included in the DEIR.

        3.4.7        Potential Regional Roadway Improvements

        As part of the discussions for the Host and Surrounding Community Agreements, the cities
        of Revere and Chelsea have asked that existing regional traffic issues along the Route 60
        and Route 1 corridors and various local intersections be studied to identify and assist in
        funding potential improvements. New ramp connections at the Route 1/Route 16
        interchange and improvements along the Revere Beach Parkway corridor have been
        identified as potential mid-term improvements, which, consistent with the Boston MPO's
        Lower North Shore Transportation Improvement Study (prepared by the Central
        Transportation Planning Staff for the Massachusetts Highway Department in October 2000),
        would shift some regional and Project traffic from the Route 60 corridor to Route
        1/Route 16.

        Such strategic new connections would be expected to address long-standing regional traffic
        issues in the Cities of Revere and Chelsea along the Route 60 corridor through Butler Circle
        and Bell Circle, as well as along Route 16/Revere Beach Parkway between Webster Avenue
        and the split to Route 145. Any such improvements would be intended primarily to address
        pre-existing regional traffic problems, independent of the proposed Project, and would be
        expected to realize benefits for regional traffic that far exceed the potential impacts of
        Project traffic.


3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        3-18   Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                          Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
        A preliminary concept plan for potential mid-term improvements is presented in Figure 3-
        11. The DEIR will include a study of such improvements using the CTPS Regional
        Transportation Model, and any design of the improvements will be developed in
        coordination with MassDOT, DCR, and the cities of Revere and Chelsea.

        Other supporting improvements at the Route 16/Route 145 Revere Beach Parkway
        intersection at Harris Street will be explored in the DEIR analysis, again in coordination
        with MassDOT, DCR, and the City of Revere.

3.5     Traffic Operations Analysis

        Capacity analyses for the Existing (2012), 2020 No-Build, 2020 Build and 2020 Build with
        Mitigation conditions will be performed in the DEIR analysis to determine how well the
        roadway facilities serve existing and future traffic demands. A full evaluation of level of
        service (LOS) results, including volume/capacity ratios and vehicular delay as appropriate,
        will be presented in the DEIR.

3.6     Alternative Modes of Transportation

        While auto travel is expected to be a dominant mode of travel for the proposed Project, the
        Proponent is committed to improvements and strategies to encourage and maximize multi-
        modal access for the Project, and take advantage of the unique adjacency of a rapid transit
        line.

        3.6.1        Transit

        As discussed in Section 3.2.1, the Project site is well served by public transportation, with
        several public transportation options including the Blue line rapid-transit Suffolk Downs
        station abutting the site and bus routes within one-quarter mile of the site, all provided by
        the MBTA.

        The Proponent will collaborate with the MBTA to determine ways to enhance the
        connections between the Suffolk Downs Station and the Resort. Stronger pedestrian, bicycle
        and shuttle bus connections will be made on-site to promote use of the station. The DEIR
        will include details of proposed improvements.

        As described in detail in Section 3.7, the TDM Plan for the Project will include a range of
        incentives to encourage public transit as an access mode, particularly for employees.

        In addition, the proponent will work with the MBTA to develop an analysis of potential
        impacts to Blue Line and bus routes as a result of the Project. This analysis will be
        presented in the DEIR.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        3-19    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                           Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
        3.6.2        Pedestrian Access

        Due to the close proximity of residential areas to the Project site, walking is, and will
        continue to be, attractive to some employees and patrons. For this reason, the Project site
        layout has been designed to encourage pedestrian activity to and from the site by making
        appropriate connections to the existing off-site pedestrian network in the area.

        The Project recognizes the existing connection between the Orient Heights neighborhood
        and the retail stores located north of the site. Currently, the residents of the Orient Heights
        neighborhood access these stores through the Suffolk Downs site. The Project site plan will
        enhance and strengthen the safety and quality of this pedestrian link.

        On-site pedestrian circulation is described in detail in Section 2.2.           Pedestrian
        accommodations and safety will be afforded priority in the design development of off-site
        infrastructure. Associated pedestrian improvements will be evaluated in the DEIR analysis.

        3.6.3        Bicycle Access

        The Project seeks to continue the ongoing north-eastward expansion of the bicycle network
        from the East Boston piers. This expansion provides an excellent opportunity for the Project
        to significantly add to the bicycle infrastructure of the area, which will not only benefit
        Project patrons and employees but also the communities of East Boston, Revere, and other
        nearby municipalities.

        The Proponent currently proposes to provide on-street bicycle accommodations along the
        Bennington Street corridor extending between Saratoga Street to the south and Revere
        Beach Boulevard to the north. With the current on-street bicycle accommodations on
        Bennington Street south of Saratoga Street, the proposed extension will provide the
        communities of East Boston and Revere with a `beach-to-beach' connection between
        Constitution Beach to the south and Revere Beach to the north. In addition to these
        proposed accommodations on Bennington Street, the Proponent proposes to provide
        bicycle connections that extend from these proposed accommodations into the Project site
        at the Suffolk Downs Station at the south of the site and at the Route 145 driveway to the
        north. Figure 3-3 presents a summary of both existing and proposed bicycle
        accommodations in the vicinity of the site.

        3.6.3.1      Bennington Street Corridor connection to Revere Beach

        The Project's proposed expansion of the existing bicycle network would extend bicycle
        accommodations from Saratoga Street along Bennington Street to Eliot Circle at Revere
        Beach. This connection would provide the area with an almost continuous route between
        the East Boston waterfront, Constitution Beach, and the front entrance to DCR's Belle Isle
        Marsh and Revere Beach, connecting several residential neighborhoods with retail,
        recreation, and transportation opportunities. It is anticipated that the changes to the
        corridor would be within the existing curb-to-curb width, thus minimizing the impact to

3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         3-20    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                            Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
        adjacent communities. A bicycle route connecting several recreational opportunities may
        bring additional visitors to the area and has the potential to increase neighborhood livability
        and economic activity without significantly increasing automobile traffic and impacts.

        The Proponent also plans to provide a spur connection from the Bennington Street corridor
        to the site to support Project employees and patrons with bicycle access to the site. It is
        expected that many Project employees will live within adjacent neighborhoods, and
        providing bicycle access from Bennington Street will encourage them to bicycle to work.

        3.6.3.2      Site Accommodations

        As described in Section 2.2.2, bicycle paths and connections are integrated into Project site
        plans. These paths will connect the Project's main bicycle access points from the wider
        area bicycle network with desired destinations within the Project site. Secure bicycle
        parking will be provided at the employee entrances and at locations convenient for patrons.

        In addition, bicycle access from Bennington Street and accommodations internal to the site
        will provide bicycle access to the retail plaza north of the Project for residents living near
        and adjacent to the Bennington Street corridor.

3.7     Transportation Demand Management

        The primary objective of the TDM program to be developed for the Project is to reduce
        SOV travel, thereby reducing parking demand, congestion, and associated environmental
        impact from the resort. Complementary to the reduction in vehicular impacts, the TDM
        plan also will support enhancement of mobility via alternate modes of travel by promoting
        walking, bicycling, ridesharing, and transit. The TDM Plan is an integral component of the
        overall Project mitigation package and it overlaps with other key plan elements such as
        parking demand management and infrastructure improvements.

        While the goals for TDM programs targeted at employees and patrons are the same (i.e., to
        reduce drive-alone travel, reduce travel during commuter peak hours, reduce reliance on
        personal automobile, etc.), the actual execution and implementation of these programs vary
        because of the differences in travel behavior and characteristics of employees and patrons.
        As such, TDM programs need to be tailored to each group and should account for unique
        needs. The Proponent proposes to develop and implement TDM actions and strategies
        appropriate for each user group.

        The Proponent will prepare the TDM plan in close coordination with other stakeholders
        such as Massport, MassDOT, the MBTA, and the cities of Boston and Revere, and will
        commit to the plan by executing a Transportation Access Plan Agreement (TAPA) with the
        Boston Transportation Department (BTD). The plan will be comprehensive and include
        policy/management, infrastructure, and programmatic components. The remainder of this
        section discusses the proposed TDM plan in more detail.


3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         3-21    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                            Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
        3.7.1        Regulatory Context

        Existing state and local regulations create TDM requirements that influence the way in
        which the Project can proceed. The Proponent intends to comply with both the letter and
        the spirit of these regulations.

        State Regulation 310 CMR 7.16, also referred to as the "Rideshare Regulation", is part of the
        Massachusetts State Implementation Plan (SIP) and requires employers of more than 250
        employees to establish a SOV reduction target goal and to implement a variety of TDM
        measures for their employees to reach that goal.

        In addition, the City of Boston also will require the Proponent to submit a TAPA, which will
        establish a variety of TDM programs to be implemented by the Proponent and monitored
        by the BTD. It is the Proponent's expectation that a coordinated set of TDM measures will
        be developed for the Project regardless of jurisdiction.

        In combination, the regulatory framework creates an environment in which TDM can be
        successful by aggressively managing parking, requiring employers to implement TDM
        programs and working with developers to mitigate transportation impacts through the TAPA
        agreements. They also provide means for the city and the state to monitor the TDM
        measures identified in this plan.

        3.7.2        Construction Management Plan

        In accordance with requirements under Article 80 Large Project Review, the Proponent will
        prepare a CMP which details measures to ensure the maintenance of existing levels of
        service on adjacent roadways during the construction of the Project and to minimize
        disruption in the area. The CMP will be submitted to BTD for approval, which will be
        obtained prior to the Proponent obtaining any building permit from ISD. It is understood by
        the Proponent that the development of a CMP is a precondition to the issuance of a
        building permit for the Project by ISD.

        A framework for the CMP will be presented in the DEIR.

        In addition to the CMP for the on-site construction, the Proponent will also develop a
        construction phasing and maintenance of traffic plan (MTP) in coordination with MassDOT
        and the BTD for the construction of the off-site roadway improvements on Route 1A which
        are part of the project. Similarly, the Proponent will prepare a MTP in coordination the
        MassDOT, DCR and/or the cities of Boston and Revere as appropriate for the construction
        of any other off-site traffic and roadway improvements or mitigation required for the Project.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        3-22    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                            Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
3.8     Parking

        Today, large sections of the Suffolk Downs site are dominated by expansive impervious
        parking areas, providing a total of approximately 6,000parking spaces. It is expected that
        the total number of parking spaces will be reduced to a supply of approximately 5,150
        spaces, comprising 2, 600 spaces in a parking garage structure, 450 spaces below grade,
        and 2,100 spaces in surface lots, which is expected to adequately accommodate the
        Project's peak demands. The layout and allocation of the parking areas is described in
        detail in Section 2.

        While patron cars will be accommodated on site, it is anticipated that employee cars will be
        accommodated only during off-peak parking demand periods. While employee parking
        demand will be substantially reduced by management and TDM strategies to accomplish
        maximum use of public transportation, alternative transportation will be necessary for
        employees who commute outside of the MBTA operating hours. It is anticipated that this
        demand will be accommodated by HOV shuttle service, potentially in coordination with
        Massport or other area employers.

        The DEIR will include a detailed parking demand and supply analysis, reflecting all of the
        foregoing considerations.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        3-23   Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Transportation                                                          Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc.
                     Section 4.0
DEVELOPMENT REVIEW COMPONENTS
4.0    DEVELOPMENT REVIEW COMPONENTS

The development review components discussed in this ENF include transportation, environmental
protection, urban design, historic resources, and infrastructure systems. Where potential for direct
or indirect impacts exists, design measures may be required to mitigate the impacts, to the extent
economically feasible. Transportation is discussed in Section 3.0, and the remainder of this section
is devoted to the studies and mitigation that may be required.

To analyze potential impacts to the general Project area as well as nearby neighborhoods, a future
conditions year (or horizon year) used in the transportation, air, and noise analyses will be 2020
rather than a more typical five-year projection.

4.1    Environmental Protection

       4.1.1         Wind

       Existing and the approximate proposed building heights associated with the Project and
       Project site are provided in Table 4-1. The Proponent expects that the DEIR will include
       results from a quantitative analysis of potential pedestrian-level wind impacts at selected
       locations. Due to the relatively low building heights, impacts on pedestrian use and
       enjoyment of the site from wind are anticipated to be minimal.

Table 4-1      Existing and Approximate Proposed Building Heights on the Project Site

                                   Structure                         Height (feet)
                Existing Buildings
                Grandstand                                                60
                Link                                                      48
                Clubhouse                                                 39
                Proposed Buildings
                Casino Area I (renovated grandstand)                      60
                Casino Area II                                          30/60
                Hotel I                                                  135
                Hotel II                                                 166
                Central Utility Plant                                    TBD



       4.1.2         Shadow

       The Project proposes two buildings over 100 feet tall: Hotel I, at 135 feet in height; and
       Hotel II, at 166 feet in height. For the DEIR, shadow impacts will be studied for the 21st of
       March, June, September, and December.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF          4-1   Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                    Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       4.1.3         Daylight

       In addition to casting shadows, buildings can also, depending on their locations, heights,
       and proximity to other buildings, block views of the sky. The Project is composed of the
       crescent-shaped Hotel I and other structures with carefully-considered massing. The
       arrangement of Project buildings has been designed to preserve access to daylight for public
       open spaces and pedestrian areas. As part of its review under Article 80 of the Boston
       Zoning Code, the Proponent will conduct a daylight analysis using the Boston
       Redevelopment Authority Daylight Analysis (BRADA) model.

       4.1.4         Solar Glare

       Non-reflective glass will be included in the Project design to avoid adverse impacts from
       spot glare. Steps will be taken in final design to mitigate areas where reflected sunlight and
       glare have the potential to impact vehicular traffic, pedestrian, or neighborhood areas.
       Solar glare will be studied by the Proponent as part of its review under Article 80 of the
       Boston Zoning Code.

       4.1.5         Air Quality

       Potential long-term air quality impacts will be limited to emissions from Project-related
       mechanical equipment and pollutant emissions from vehicular traffic generated by the
       proposed site development. Due to the size of the Project and the proposed changes in
       traffic operations, the potential air quality impacts will be modeled for both existing and
       future conditions in the DEIR to demonstrate conformance with the National Ambient Air
       Quality Standards. Both regional and local analysis will be conducted. A microscale (local)
       intersection analysis as required by the BRA will be conducted for all years and conditions
       included in the transportation analysis which includes the year 2020. In addition a
       mesoscale (regional) emissions analysis will be included in accordance with the triggers set
       forth by the MEPA regulations and/or the BRA.

       Implementation of a TDM program will provide mitigation by reducing vehicle trips to the
       site, and TDM details will be evaluated in the DEIR.

       Construction period air quality impacts and mitigation are discussed in Section 4.5.1.

       4.1.6         Floodplain and Wetlands

       4.1.6.1       On-Site Wetland Resource Areas

       On April 24 through 26 and May 3, 2012, wetland and soil scientists from Epsilon
       Associates, Inc. delineated wetlands and other resource areas within an approximately 200-
       acre study area on and immediately adjacent to the Project site. Wetlands and other
       resource areas off-site were also evaluated by wetland scientists from VHB, Inc. for the
       proposed Route 1A flyover, and are discussed in more detail in Section 4.1.6.3. The


3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        4-2    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                  Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       purpose of the delineation and evaluation efforts was to define the extent of wetlands
       resource areas and associated buffer zones regulated under the Massachusetts Wetlands
       Protection Act (WPA) (MGL Ch. 131 § 40), Sections 401 and 404 of the U.S. Clean Water
       Act (33 U.S.C. 1344), and local wetland ordinances in the cities of Boston and Revere.

       The Suffolk Downs facility is located adjacent to Route 1A in Revere and East Boston,
       Massachusetts. The vast majority of the site, including the buffer zone to delineated
       wetland resource areas, is heavily developed with a thoroughbred race track, ancillary
       facilities and structures, paved parking lots and areas of urban fill. The site is bordered to
       the north by Winthrop Avenue and residential developments, to the east by Washburn
       Avenue, and beyond it the MBTA Blue Line tracks and Bennington Street as well as a mix of
       residential and commercial developments, to the south by Waldemar Avenue and
       residential developments, and to the west by Route 1A, a large fuel storage facility with
       numerous above ground storage tanks, and a retail shopping plaza. On-site wetland
       resource areas and related buffer zones are depicted on Figure 1-4 and are described below.

       100-year Floodplain

       Portions of the Project site are located within the 100-year floodplain as delineated by
       FEMA (see Figure 1-7). The Proponent has conservatively classified the 100-year floodplain
       as BLSF based on two open Orders of Conditions issued by the Boston and Revere
       Conservation Commissions in 2011 (MassDEP File Nos. 006-1276 and 061-0620). The
       Proponent has been made aware that there may be differing interpretations based on
       specific site characteristics and specific storm conditions because, even though no portion
       of the property is subject to tidal action, the site may experience flooding due to one or
       more causes during extreme (e.g., 100-year flood) events and the floodplain may therefore
       be characterized as LSCSF. The Proponent intends to work in consultation with the local
       Conservation Commissions to explore this matter further. Neither BLSF nor LSCSF have a
       100-foot Buffer Zone as defined by the Wetlands Protection Act regulations.

       Riverfront Area

       Sales Creek, which in the Project site is primarily a manmade drainage channel, is depicted
       as a perennial stream on the applicable USGS quadrangle map (see Figure 1-1). According
       to 310 CMR 10.58(2)(a)1a, a river or stream shown as perennial on the current USGS
       quadrangle or more recent map provided by MassDEP is perennial. Perennial streams (i.e.,
       rivers) have an associated Riverfront Area that is defined as the area of land between a
       river's mean annual high-water line and a parallel line located 200 feet away, except that
       the parallel line is located 25 feet away in Boston and 25 feet away in densely developed
       areas as designated by the EEA Secretary pursuant to 301 CMR 10.00 (see 310 CMR
       10.58(2)(a)3). On March 12, 1999, the EEA Secretary designated those portions of Sales
       Creek not within the City of Boston and the surrounding environs on the Project site as a




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        4-3    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                  Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       densely developed area. Accordingly, the Riverfront Area on the Project site that is
       associated with Sales Creek is 25 feet wide. Similar to BLSF, Riverfront Area does not have
       a 100-foot buffer zone.

       Bordering Vegetated Wetlands

       According to the WPA regulations (310 CMR 10.55), BVWs are freshwater wetlands which
       border on creeks, rivers, streams, ponds and lakes. The types of freshwater wetlands are
       wet meadows, marshes, swamps and bogs. BVWs are areas where the soils are saturated
       and/or inundated such that they support a predominance of wetland indicator plants.

       Epsilon delineated a total of eight (8) separate areas on the Project site that meet the
       regulatory definition of BVW. These areas are shown on Figure 1-4. BVW has a 100-foot
       buffer zone under the WPA regulations. The BVWs delineated by Epsilon border on
       intermittent streams (drainage channels), Sales Creek or are otherwise hydologically
       connected to other BVWs via culverts and pipes. From a functions and values perspective,
       the BVWs on the Project site are generally degraded given their juxtaposition in a heavily
       developed urban environment. The primary function of these BVWs appears to be flood
       control, storm damage prevention and pollution attenuation. The BVWs are comprised
       primarily of invasive herbaceous and woody plant species including but not limited to
       common reed (Phragmites australis), multiflora rose (Rosa multiflora), buckthorn (Frangula
       alnus), and purple loosestrife (Lythrum salicaria). Non-invasive species include but are not
       limited to sweetgale (Myrica gale) and various sedges, rushes and grasses.

       Two artificial man-made stormwater detention/retention basins located in the City of Revere
       were not classified as BVW or other jurisdictional wetland resource areas under the WPA
       (310 CMR 10.00) regulations because they do not meet the criteria to be regulated as inland
       wetland resource areas. In addition, the up-gradient intermittent stream that flows into the
       jurisdictional pond located in the racetrack infield in the City of Boston was also not
       classified as a WPA-jurisdictional wetland resource area per the definition of "stream" in
       310 CMR 10.04.

       Inland Bank and Land Under Water Bodies and Waterways

       Inland Bank (310 CMR 10.54) and Land Under Water Bodies and Waterways (LUW) (310
       CMR 10.56) on the Project site are associated with intermittent streams/drainage ditches,
       Sales Creek and the pond located in the center of the racetrack infield.

       Area of Critical Environmental Concern

       An ACEC is an area designated by the EEA Secretary in accordance with 301 CMR 12.00 of
       the Coastal Zone Management (CZM) regulations. Sales Creek is associated with the Belle
       Isle Inlet that is within the Rumney Marshes ACEC. The ACEC extends through the Project



3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        4-4   Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                 Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       site from approximately the northwest corner, passing between the proposed construction
       and the existing horse barns, through the northern portion of the racing track infield, and
       continuing east of the Project site (see Figure 1-6).

       4.1.6.2       Potential On-Site Wetlands Impacts

       Project activities are proposed within BLSF (see Section 4.1.6.1), the 100-foot Buffer Zone
       to BVW and potentially 25-foot Riverfront Area associated with Sales Creek. No on-site
       activities are proposed in BVW, Inland Bank and/or LUW.

       Activities proposed in floodplain will occur primarily in two locations: (1) in the vicinity of
       the proposed entrance drive and rotary area at the west end of the site, and (2) in the
       parking lot located at the north end of the Project site. These activities will involve altering
       the parking lot elevations as well as raising the grade in the vicinity of the proposed traffic
       circle. There will also be some grading involving the placement of fill in grassed areas
       around the traffic circle and the construction of stormwater Best Management Practices.
       The work will occur in previously developed areas comprised of pavement or urban fill.
       Pursuant to the WPA regulations (310 CMR 10.57), the filling of BLSF requires
       compensatory flood storage to prevent an increase in potential flood hazard during peak
       flows. Although the Project may fill some areas of BLSF, compensatory flood storage areas
       will be provided on the Project site to mitigate these impacts and result in floodplain
       storage capacity equivalent to or exceeding the existing floodplain storage capacity on the
       property. The compensatory flood storage areas will be designed to comply with the WPA
       performance standards for BLSF. The location of the potential storage areas along with the
       estimated volume will be further detailed in the DEIR.

       With regard to the Sales Creek Riverfront Area, activities in this location are limited to
       proposed stormwater management system improvements and upgrades. The proposed
       upgrades to the stormwater management system, including any new or modified discharges,
       will be set back from the receiving water and will comply with MassDEP stormwater
       standards. The proposed upgrades to the stormwater management system should
       substantially improve the quality of discharged water relative to existing conditions. In
       addition, the proposed development will decrease impervious area on the site by
       approximately nine acres, thereby reducing the rate and volume of stormwater leaving the
       site. Refer to Section 4.4.4.2 for additional information on stormwater management. No
       work is anticipated to occur on or below the Inland Bank of Sales Creek or its adjoining
       BVW.

       Activities in the 100 foot buffer zone to BVW and Inland Bank include construction of the
       proposed entrance drive and parking areas, utility connections and upgrades to the
       stormwater management system. These activities will occur in previously developed areas
       of the buffer zone comprised of impervious surfaces or urban fill. No work is proposed in
       BVW or Inland Bank. Erosion controls will be installed along the limit of work line in these
       locations to protect the resource areas.

        4.1.6.3         Existing Off-Site Jurisdictional Wetland Resource Areas

        Wetland resource areas are present in and near the off-site improvements planned along the
        Route 1A corridor, but the only existing wetland resource area located where work is
        proposed is floodplain (see Figure 4-1).

        4.1.6.4         Potential Off-Site Wetlands Impacts

        The off-site improvements may potentially include approximately 40,000 square feet of
        work in areas subject to flooding (LSCSF) and approximately 20,000 square feet of work
        within the 100-foot Buffer Zone to Coastal Bank and Salt Marsh (see Figure 4-1). All work
        proposed in these areas will occur in or immediately adjacent to areas that are presently
        developed (i.e., covered by paved surfaces). Measures to prevent adverse impacts will
        include installing erosion and sedimentation controls and installing structural measures to
        treat roadway drainage.

        4.1.7           Groundwater

        Historical measurements of observation wells have indicated groundwater levels at the
        Project site are 0.5 to 16 feet below site grades, and are generally on the order of two to six
        feet below grade.1 In recent test pit explorations completed for this Project, groundwater
        was observed typically at depths of 2.5 to 7 feet below site grades. Seasonal fluctuations in
        groundwater levels can also be expected.

        Dewatering is discussed in Section 4.5.3.3.

        4.1.8           Geotechnical

        Based on the results of recent test boring programs completed at the Project site and borings
        previously completed by others, subsurface soil conditions underlying the Project site are
        expected to be characterized by the general soil profile described in Table 4-3.

Table 4-3         General Soil Profile Expected Under the Project Site.

                  Generalized Description                       Approximate Thickness of Layer (feet)
         Fill                                                                  3.8 to 28
         Estuarine/Organic Deposits                                            5 to 55.5
         Marine Deposits                                                        7 to 63
         Glacial Till                                                           3 to 15
         Bedrock (Cambridge Argillite)                              Depth to Rock of 50 to 137.5 ft



1
    Geotechnical Investigation, Suffolk Downs, East Boston and Revere, Massachusetts. GEI Consultants, Inc. February
