3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                4-7     Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                              Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       Foundation support requirements for the proposed new structures have not yet been
       determined. However, based on available information, the currently planned development,
       and the height of the proposed structures, Project engineers anticipate the following:

            For new buildings, including casino facilities, two hotels, and a parking structure,
            deep foundation support will likely be required due to column spacing and
            structural loads, depth to suitable bearing materials, efforts to lower the potential for
            settlement, and depth to groundwater.

            Driven piles will be selected to support the new structures, and depending on the
            design loads, the foundation elements will be installed through overburden soils
            and driven to end bearing conditions in either glacial till or bedrock. Pile types that
            are under consideration include precast pre-stressed concrete piles and steel H-
            Piles. Means and methods for installation of the deep foundation system will
            consider potential impacts to abutting facilities to remain within the property limits
            (e.g., the grandstand). Vibration monitoring will be conducted during pile-driving
            activities. It is not anticipated that vibrations will approach thresholds that could
            potentially impact existing facilities.

            For the existing grandstand building that is proposed for renovation into a new
            casino facility, Project engineers anticipate supporting the structure on its existing
            pile foundation. Test pit operations were completed within the building to obtain
            information related to the existing pile foundation system to evaluate whether
            supplementary foundations may be required at column locations. The main
            purpose of these test pits is to determine the top of the existing pile caps. The
            existing floor will need to be lowered to achieve a higher floor-to-ceiling height for
            the Project. It is anticipated that the lowest level slab for this building will be a
            reinforced structural slab bearing within a few feet of existing grades.
            Supplementary foundation support required for the lowest level slab and columns is
            anticipated to include a foundation system associated with low vibrations and low
            headroom requirements for installation, such as micropiles.

                In an effort to lower the carbon footprint associated with the development, the
               Proponent intends to keep soils on-site to the extent possible, thus lowering the
               potential for off-site disposal or transport of soil. Currently the Project proposes just
               one-level of below-grade parking. Project engineers anticipate that small excavation
               support systems may be required locally for below-grade parking and elevator pit or
               similar excavations and, given the relatively shallow depth to groundwater in some
               areas, temporary construction dewatering efforts will be required to allow for
               construction in-the-dry.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         4-8     Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                    Epsilon Associates, Inc.
            Project engineers anticipate that the lowest level floor slabs for the new buildings
            may have underslab drainage systems and likely will need to be waterproofed.

       4.1.9         Operational Solid and Hazardous Wastes

       Following construction, solid waste generated by the proposed development will be
       collected and disposed of off-site by a licensed contractor. The Proponent will implement a
       recycling program throughout the Project, with recycled materials expected to include
       newspaper, cardboard, cans, and bottles.

       A Phase I and Phase II Environmental Site Assessment was conducted in 2007 which found
       asbestos containing materials and lead-based paint within the administration building and
       grandstand areas. These materials will be abated in accordance with all appropriate rules
       and regulations.

       In December 2012, MassDEP released a Revised Solid Waste Master Plan with the
       overarching goals largely focused on increasing recycling, advancing greater diversion of
       solid waste, and assisting municipalities in achieving these goals for municipal solid waste.
       Two major initiatives in the revised plan include a focused effort to achieve zero waste in
       the near future and a clear recognition that solid waste management activities play a
       significant role in GHG emissions. Pertinent regulatory changes have grown out of these
       initiatives:

             Implementing integrated organics and construction and demolition diversion
             strategies that include a combination of initiatives to both increase diversion and
             build new markets;

             Promoting a limited new degree of gasification or pyrolysis of municipal solid
             waste capabilities in the state by adjusting the state's moratorium on incineration;
             and

             Eliminating barriers to siting of anaerobic digestion recycling and composting
             facilities with a particular focus on organic food waste.

        Although it is too early to identify exactly which solid waste management strategies will be
        employed at the proposed resort casino, the Proponent is committed to the following:

             As a racetrack and major entertainment venue, the Project provides a unique
             opportunity to study innovative technologies such as anaerobic digestion as both a
             waste diversion and green energy model. The Proponent is studying the possibility
             of using this technology on site and has been corresponding with proponents of
             this green technology in the state. A more thorough analysis of the feasibility of
             employing anaerobic digestion for the Project will be included in the DEIR.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        4-9    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                  Epsilon Associates, Inc.
             Caesars is committed both locally and nationally to achieving a degree of
             environmental sustainability unparalleled in the industry. In 2011, Caesars was the
             first member of the national gaming industry to receive U.S. EPA approval for its
             GHG reduction plan. In 2010, Caesars won the WasteWise New Partners Gold
             Achievement Award from U.S. EPA, and in 2008 it was the first in the industry to
             join the EPA's Climate Leaders Program.

        Caesars' CodeGreen Initiative focuses across the board on the company, its employees,
        guests, and suppliers to ensure it remains at the pinnacle of corporate sustainability
        leadership. The Proponent will fully comply with the goals of the state's new Solid Waste
        Master Plan and hopes to push the state's goals to new levels of achievement by investing
        in technology such as, possibly, anaerobic digestion for both food waste and racetrack
        wastes.

       4.1.10        Noise

       Stationary project-related operational noise sources are expected to consist of the following:
       ventilating fans for the parking garage; heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC)
       equipment for the casinos, hotels, and restaurants; emergency generators at the CUP; and
       vehicular traffic generated by the proposed site development. The Cadna/A software
       program will be used to predict future exterior sound levels from the Project at the nearest
       on-site and off-site sensitive receptors. Cadna/A uses the ISO 9613-2 standard for sound
       level propagation. As part of the Article 80 review process, future sound levels will be
       compared to the City of Boston noise regulations. In addition, a baseline sound level
       measurement program will be conducted in and around the residential neighborhoods
       north, east, and south of the Project site to determine existing daytime and nighttime sound
       levels. The existing racetrack will be included as part of the existing condition
       measurements.

       An analysis of noise generated by the traffic using the facility is only required for highway
       projects receiving Federal aid. The roadway improvements for this Project will be funded
       privately; therefore, a traffic noise analysis is not required. However, the applicant will
       conduct an analysis of traffic-generated noise using the Federal Highway Administration
       (FHWA) Traffic Noise Model (TNM) for informational purposes. The analysis will examine
       both on-site and off-site traffic within the study area to understand what, if any, impact the
       additional Project-generated traffic has on community sound levels. Based on a review of
       hourly traffic data over the course of a typical 24-hour day, two scenarios will be analyzed:
       a daytime off-peak hour and a nighttime hour. Modeled sound levels will be compared to
       both existing condition measurements and the FHWA Noise Abatement Criteria (NAC).

       Construction-period noise impacts and mitigation are discussed in Section 4.5.2.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF       4-10    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                  Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       4.1.11        Greenhouse Gas Emissions

       A GHG analysis will be conducted in accordance with the MEPA GHG Emissions Policy
       and Protocol (GHG Policy).

       Project GHG emissions come from three sources:

                    on-site fuel combustion in the CUP;

                    off-site emissions related to electricity provided by utilities and used on-site and
                    energy used off-site for water supply and wastewater treatment; and

                    transportation-related emissions.

       All of these will be described and quantified, and mitigation measures will be documented,
       in a GHG Analysis within the DEIR in accordance with the MEPA GHG Emissions Policy
       and Protocol. The analysis will clearly demonstrate consistency with the objectives of
       MEPA review by documenting the means by which the Proponent plans to avoid,
       minimize, or mitigate Damage to the Environment to the maximum extent feasible.

       The GHG Policy requires proponents to use energy modeling software to quantify projected
       energy usage from stationary sources and mobile source modeling software to predict
       transportation-related emissions. The DEIR will clearly state the types of modeling software
       used, the Building Code used for baseline case, and emissions factors applied to GHG
       calculations. Modeling assumptions will be clearly described, and the analysis will explain
       which GHG reduction measures have been modeled and which cannot be modeled due to
       constraints of the modeling software.

       The GHG Analysis in the DEIR will include building energy modeling for two cases, the
       baseline case and preferred case. Boston and Revere are both Stretch Code communities,
       which means they require very high standards for efficient use of energy in buildings; this
       will be reflected in the preferred case. The Proponent will compute the Energy Use Index
       (EUI) for baseline and proposed buildings, using the differential percentage to confirm that
       the Boston/Revere Stretch Code will be complied with.

       The DEIR will include energy use and emissions tables that compare base case with the
       preferred design, showing the anticipated reductions in emissions by emissions source (i.e.,
       direct, indirect, and transportation). A technical appendix will be provided containing a
       clear and complete listing of modeling inputs (e.g., R-values, U-values, efficiencies, lighting
       power density) for items such as equipment, walls, roofs, windows, lighting, and HVAC
       units for both the base case and preferred design. The appendix will also contain the
       modeling results printout for each building in both Base and Preferred cases.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         4-11    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                    Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       The GHG emissions analysis in the DEIR will address the feasibility of mitigation measures
       suggested in the Policy appendix and, if deemed feasible, will include them in the
       modeling inputs. The rationale for not including any of the suggested mitigation measures
       that might result in a significant reduction of GHG emissions will be provided.

       The potential for alternative and renewable energy sources to be incorporated into the
       Project will be examined. Potential use of PV electricity generationwill be examined, as
       well as a Combined Heat and Power (CHP) system and the potential for anaerobic digestion
       of organic wastes to derive fuel gas.

       The management of manure will also be considered as part of the GHG analysis in the
       DEIR. The Proponent will also address the Boston Climate Action Executive Order as part
       of the Article 80 review process for the Project.

       Commitments to Project-related programs that have indirect GHG reduction elements, such
       as reducing water use and maximizing recycling, will also be addressed. Transportation-
       related GHG emissions reductions from roadway and signalization changes and TDM
       programs will be calculated and reported.

       The Proponent will arrange a meeting with the MEPA Office, the Massachusetts Department
       of Energy Resources (DOER), and MassDEP to discuss the approach to the GHG Analysis
       during preparation of the DEIR. Furthermore, the Proponent will consult with State
       environmental and energy programs, including the Clean Energy Center, to identify possible
       energy-efficiency or environmental technology programs that may be feasible for inclusion
       in the Project.

       4.1.12        Sea Level Rise

       The Proponent has assessed potential impacts to the Project as a result of projected sea-level
       rise. The Project is designed to comply with building codes and FEMA requirements, which
       account for flood risks in the context of proposed uses. In addition to meeting the FEMA
       requirements, a responsible development in a coastal area must acknowledge the potential
       for sea-level rise to adversely affect activities in the future.

       The Coastal Vulnerability Index (CVI), created by the USGS, is intended to provide a
       preliminary overview of the relative susceptibility along the U.S. coastline to impacts
       associated with sea-level rise. As a tool to assess relative risks, the CVI is based on
       geomorphology, regional coastal slope, tidal range, wave height, shoreline erosion and
       accretion rates, and projected rates of future sea-level rise. Although the CVI delineates
       broad regions with different relative magnitudes of likely physical changes, it is a useful tool
       for completing a baseline evaluation of the issue; to facilitate such an evaluation, CVI data
       are available in a GIS data-layer.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        4-12    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                    Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        The CVI assigns a "low" risk ranking to the Project location; this low vulnerability to future
        sea-level rise is also delineated for the majority of northern New England's coastline.2
        Based on this information, the level of risk at the Project site from damage due to sea-level
        rise is low. However, this does not mean the area is immune to sea-level rise. The
        National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) estimates that sea-level rise in
        the Boston area will occur at a rate of 2.65 mm/year (0.104 inches/year), translating to 0.87
        feet (10.44 inches) over the next century (NOAA, 2007) according to the "South Shore
        Coastal Hazards Characterization Atlas", published by the Massachusetts Office of Coastal
        Zone Management in 2005, sea level rise in the general vicinity of the Project site is
        estimated as 2.45 mm/year (0.096 inches/year). Over the Project's assumed 100-year
        lifespan, this Atlas estimate suggests a 0.80 feet (9.6-inch) rise in sea level. It is relevant to
        note, however, that this rise in sea level may not directly correlate with a rise in flood
        elevation.

        As shown on Figure 1-4, the BFE at the Project site is 15.46 feet (Boston City Base). The
        Proponent has conservatively classified the 100-year floodplain as BLSF based on two open
        Orders of Conditions issued by the Boston and Revere Conservation Commissions in 2011
        (MassDEP File Nos. 006-1276 and 061-0620). The Proponent has been made aware that
        there may be differing interpretations based on specific site characteristics and specific
        storm conditions because, even though no portion of the property is subject to tidal action,
        the site may experience flooding due to one or more causes during extreme (e.g., 100-year
        flood) events and the floodplain may therefore be characterized as LSCSF. The Proponent
        intends to work in consultation with the local Conservation Commissions to explore this
        matter further. Neither BLSF nor LSCSF have a 100-foot Buffer Zone as defined by the
        Wetlands Protection Act regulations.

        Although the floodplain does cover portions of the Project site, the proposed building
        footprints for the Resort, including the casino, hotel, and parking garage will not be within
        the currently-designated floodplain. The proposed Casino and hotel first floor elevation will
        be at approximately elevation 28, which is approximately 12 feet higher than current
        floodplain and future estimated floodplain elevations accounting for sea level rise. Every
        effort will be made to locate the maintenance building at an elevation that is above current
        floodplain elevation or future floodplain elevation to the maximum extent practicable.

        As the design of the Project advances, the Proponent will also evaluate the site design for
        consistency with the USACE guidance document guidance for sea level rise as well as the
        EEA Climate Change Adaptation Report. Finally, in the DEIR the Proponent will also
        evaluate the first floor elevation in relation to flood elevation.




2
    Hammar-Klose and Thieler, E.R., 2001. Coastal Vulnerability to Sea-Level Rise: A Preliminary Database for the U.S.
    Atlantic, Pacific, and Gulf of Mexico Coasts. U.S. Geological Survey, Digital Data Series DDS-68.


3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                4-13     Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                               Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       4.1.12.1      Compliance with Federal Executive Order 11988, Floodplain Management

       Executive Order 11988 was signed in 1977 with the intent "to avoid to the extent possible
       the long and short term adverse impacts associated with the occupancy and modification of
       floodplains and to avoid direct or indirect support of floodplain development wherever
       there is a practicable alternative..." As such, the Order directs all federal agencies to
       evaluate how agency actions may affect floodplain use, management, and/or exposure to
       flood hazards. In the case of an action located within a floodplain, an alternatives analysis
       must demonstrate efforts to avoid and minimize adverse effects.

       Section 4.1.6 describes in detail the location of the Project within the floodplain, and
       demonstrates how the Project design exceeds minimum floodplain construction
       requirements. Furthermore, the ENF Form contains an alternatives analysis which
       demonstrates the efficacy of redeveloping this particular area of previously-disturbed land in
       the Cities of Boston and Revere.

       Recognizing the Project's location within the floodplain and associated exposure to flood
       hazards, careful engineering and design considerations have targeted risk reduction
       strategies and measures to improve existing conditions. As described in Section 4.1.6.2, the
       provision of compensatory storage in a volume equaling or exceeding the volume of
       potential floodwater displacement by the redevelopment will ensure that the Project
       expands, rather than reduces, the floodwater storage capacity of the area. The DEIR will
       include additional detail on both the locations of compensatory storage as well as
       anticipated volumes required. Proposed stormwater management controls will substantially
       improve the quality of discharged water relative to existing conditions, and coupled with
       the design of site development will reduce the rate and volume of stormwater leaving the
       site (see Section 4.1.6.2).

       While these measures will attenuate, or at a minimum will not accentuate, flood hazard risk
       on the Project site, flooding will nonetheless occur under storm conditions above a certain
       magnitude. Therefore, all building foundations designed for the Project will be constructed
       to withstand flood conditions and the on-grade parking design for will allow gravity-
       controlled stormwater flows to exit the Project site, and all occupiable spaces for the Project
       will be located at or above the BFE of 15.46 feet (Boston City Base).

       Although the Project site is partially located within a floodplain (see Figure 1-4), there is no
       practicable alternative that would allow redevelopment of this area while avoiding flooding
       hazards entirely. Nonetheless, the Proponent has designed the Project to responsibly
       minimize the risk of flood-related damage and to improve existing conditions.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        4-14    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                    Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       4.1.12.2      Climate Change Preparedness

       In addition to those items included above, the Proponent will also consider in the DEIR
       potential impacts or changes resulting from a storm surge, increased frequency of storms,
       rising temperatures, increased frequency of extreme hot days, precipitation changes, as
       appropriate.

       4.1.13        Rodent Control

       A rodent extermination certificate will be filed with the building permit application to the
       City of Boston. In compliance with City requirements, rodent inspection monitoring and
       treatment will be carried out before, during, and at the completion of construction. Rodent
       extermination prior to work start-up will consist of treatment throughout the Project area,
       including building interiors. During construction, regular service visits will be made to
       maintain effective rodent control levels.

       Operation of the proposed development will focus on a high quality of maintenance.
       Although the details have not yet been finalized, the Proponent will develop a safe, cost-
       effective, and ecologically sound pest management program.

4.2    Urban Design

       The Project's main objectives are to create a resort destination embedded within beautifully-
       landscaped, lush surroundings and to establish a vibrant, accessible urban environment
       offering visitors a respite from their busy lives. Massing of the proposed new buildings will
       offer both a sense of monumentality and a carefully-scaled composition of new and restored
       buildings, streets, and open spaces that will tie back into the surrounding urban landscape.

       Upon entering the resort from Route 1A, visitors will be welcomed by a stately, tree-lined
       entrance drive reminiscent of Commonwealth Avenue in Boston. A circular driveway will
       lead to the main entrance of Casino Area II and the crescent-shaped seven-story, 300-room
       luxury Hotel I. Turning north at the end of the entrance drive, along Tomasello Drive, will
       allow visitors to bypass the main entrance of Casino Area II and proceed toward the main
       entrance drive of Casino Area I, located along the northern edge of the detached seven-
       story, 2,600-car-capacity parking garage. The parking garage will define the western edge
       of the inner courtyard, a 170-foot by 540-foot urban square that will articulate the main
       entrance to Casino Area I and the north entrance to Casino Area II. Hotel II will mark the
       northern end of the long axis of the new urban space.

       4.2.1         Sustainable Design and LEED

       Beyond striving for LEED Gold, the Proponent will set a new standard of excellence in
       sustainable design for gaming development projects.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF       4-15    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                  Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       At all of its casino resorts, Caesars Entertainment implements an Environmental-Social-
       Governance sustainability strategy. This strategy, CodeGreen, is committed to addressing
       critical issues of energy, waste, water, and carbon emissions and seeks to engage Caesars
       employees in efforts to reduce natural resource use, conserve energy, and promote reuse
       and recycling. In the past nine years, Caesars has invested nearly $70 million on energy
       conservation projects alone and has invested in more than 162 retrofits involving, among
       others items, energy-efficient lighting, improved air-handling systems, upgraded
       thermostats, advanced energy-saving sensors, and low-flow water controls and fixtures.
       Annual savings from these retrofits include in excess of 208 million kilowatt-hours in
       energy, over 3.3 million therms in natural gas, more than $24 million in annual resources,
       and 298 million pounds of carbon dioxide emissions. A CodeGreen Fact Sheet from
       Caesars is provided as Attachment I.

       Building on the CodeGreen program, the Project will be sustainably designed, energy
       efficient, environmentally conscious, and healthy for its employees and visitors. Innovative
       technologies are currently being explored to determine what works best with the Project as
       well as what might set a visible example for those visiting the site.

       As required under Article 37 of the Boston Zoning Code, projects that are subject to Article
       80B, Large Project Review, shall be LEED certifiable. There are seven categories in the
       LEED certification guidelines: Sustainable Sites, Water Efficiency, Energy and Atmosphere,
       Materials and Resources, Indoor Environmental Quality, Innovation in Design Process and
       the additional Regional Priority Credits. For this Project, the Proponent is striving to
       achieve LEED Gold, and sustainable measures included in the design include, but are not
       limited to, those addressed below.

       4.2.1.1       Sustainable Sites

       The Project site is in a dense urban neighborhood close to the MBTA Blue Line and other
       public transportation options. The proposed Project design includes maintaining the
       existing racetrack, renovating the existing grandstand building, and constructing a new
       casino resort that will include gaming areas, hotels, restaurants, a spa, and all necessary
       administrative and support spaces. Parking will be accommodated in a seven-story parking
       structure, limited underground parking as well as surface parking.

       Sustainable stormwater designs will be incorporated into the Project to the maximum extent
       practicable. The Proponent will make every effort to design the Project consistent with
       LEED Credits 6.1 (Stormwater Design Quantity Control) and 6.2 (Stormwater Design
       Quality Control). The ability to obtain these points will be determined as the Project's
       drainage design advances. Since the Project will reduce impervious surface on the site by
       approximately nine acres, there will be a reduction in the rate and volume of stormwater
       leaving the site. Stormwater runoff from the 90% annual rainfall will be captured and




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF       4-16   Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                 Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       treated, which will remove 80% of total suspended solids. LID drainage BMPs, including
       water quality swales, bioretention basins, and constructed wetlands, are being considered
       where appropriate to promote infiltration and provide water quality treatment.

       4.2.1.2       Water Efficiency

       The State Building Code requires the use of water-conserving fixtures. Water conservation
       measures such as low-flow toilets and restricted flow faucets will reduce the domestic water
       demand on the existing distribution system. Sensor-operated sinks with water-conserving
       aerators and sensor-operated toilets will be installed in all restrooms.

       4.2.1.3       Energy and Atmosphere

       In addition to compliance with stringent standards for energy use in the Stretch Code, the
       Proponent is evaluating the feasibility of installing PV arrays on several rooftops, including
       the parking structure, where they could also function as sunshades for parked vehicles.
       High-efficiency mechanical equipment, such as boilers and chillers, and high performance
       building shells, will substantially reduce energy use.

       Building systems will not use refrigerants that are harmful to the environment. The
       Proponent will engage a Commissioning Agent to confirm the building systems are installed
       and operated as intended and designed.

       4.2.1.4       Materials and Resources

       Throughout construction, the Construction Management team shall endeavor to divert
       Construction and Demolition waste from area landfills and procure materials that have
       recycled content and/or are extracted and manufactured within 500 miles of the Project
       site.

       4.2.1.5       Indoor Environmental Quality

       Air quality will be monitored during Project construction and likely prior to occupancy.
       Low-emitting materials will be used throughout construction to maintain and improve air
       quality. Building occupants will be able to maintain a comfortable environment through
       access to thermal and lighting controls.

4.3    Historic and Archaeological Resources

       This section identifies historic resources within and in the vicinity of the Project. A review
       of the State and National Registers of Historic Places and the survey files of the MHC and
       Boston Landmarks Commission (BLC), as well as a field review of the areas in the vicinity of
       the Project, were undertaken to identify historic resources.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF       4-17    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                  Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       4.3.1          Historic Resources within the Project Site

       The Project site encompasses the Suffolk Downs Racetrack, Grandstand, and Clubhouse,
       which are included in the Inventory of Historic and Archaeological Assets of the
       Commonwealth (Inventory) (MHC No. 209). Constructed in 1935, the facility was the first
       major racetrack in New England. Originally designed in the International Style, the
       property has undergone substantial renovations through the years, including enclosure of
       the grandstand in 1945, major renovations and modifications in 1962 with a new grand
       entrance and the joining and complete enclosure of the grandstand and clubhouse, a major
       renovation in 1992, and a series of updates and improvements over the past five years.

       4.3.2          Historic Resources in the Vicinity of the Project Site

       The Project site is located in the towns of Revere to the north and East Boston's Orient
       Heights neighborhood to the south. A review of the State and National Registers, Inventory,
       and MHC databases revealed there are limited previously identified historic resources in the
       vicinity of the Project area. Directly north of the Project site is the Revere Beach Parkway,
       which is listed in the National Register of Historic Places. To the east of the site in Revere's
       Beachmont neighborhood is the Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church Complex.
       To the south of the Project site is the Madonna Queen Shrine and Don Orione Rest Home
       complex on Orient Avenue. In addition, there are two residences on Orient Avenue
       included in the Inventory. These historic resources are described below.

       Table 4-4 lists State and National Register-listed and inventoried properties located within a
       quarter mile radius of the Project site. The resources are keyed to Figure 4-2.

Table 4-4      Historic Resources within and in the Vicinity of the Project Site

        Map No.                      Name                                         Address

       Properties listed in the State and National Registers of Historic Places

       1             Revere Beach Parkway

       Properties included in the Inventory of Historic and Archaeological Resources of the Commonwealth

       2             Suffolk Downs                           111 Waldemar, Boston

       3             Our Lady of Lourdes Complex             1, 2 Endicott Avenue, Revere

       4             Residence                               54-56 Orient Avenue, East Boston

       5             Residence                               75-79 Orient Avenue, East Boston

       6             Don Orione Complex                      111, 120, 150 Orient Avenue, East Boston




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF             4-18     Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                         Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       Revere Beach Parkway is a curvilinear, 5.3-mile, heavily traveled boulevard that runs
       between Wellington Circle in Medford and Eliot Circle in Revere. Designed by Olmsted,
       Olmsted and Eliot, and its successor firm, Olmsted Brothers for the Metropolitan Park
       Commission, Revere Beach Parkway was originally built in 1896-1905. Throughout its
       history, the parkway has undergone changes, including having been widened to
       accommodate increased traffic and to improve crossings and intersections. The parkway
       was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2007.

       The Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church Complex is comprised of the Church,
       Rectory, Garden with Shrine, and Garage (MHC Nos. REV.G, REV.7, REV.83, REV.84,
       Rev.958). The complex was designed by Maginnis, Walsh and Sullivan in the Neoclassical
       style in 1907. It is associated with the development of the Beachmont section of Revere in
       the early twentieth century. The complex was surveyed in 2005 and recommended eligible
       for inclusion in the National Register of Historic Places.

       The Don Orione Complex at the top of Orient Heights in East Boston is the national
       headquarters for the Don Orione religious order. The Madonna Queen National Shrine
       (MHC No. BOS.902), constructed in 1954, features a full-size replica of the statue at the
       Don Orione Center in Rome, Italy. It was constructed in 1954 by Jewish-Italian sculptor
       Arrigo Minerbi to show his gratitude to the Catholic Church for having protected him and
       his family during World War II. Across the street from the Shrine is the Don Orione
       Nursing Home (MHC No. BOS.113), a nursing home which was also founded by the Don
       Orione order. The complex includes the Mother Queen Shrine Chapel (BOS.114), Don
       Orione Rest Home (BOS.110) and the Franciscan Sisters of Mary Convent (BOS 111).

       In addition to the Don Orione complex, two nearby properties at 54-56 and 75-79 Orient
       Avenue (MHC Nos. BOS.109 and 112) are included in the Inventory. Both are Colonial
       Revival residences constructed ca. 1915.

       4.3.3         Archaeological Resources on the Project Site

       There are no known archaeological resources listed in the State and National Registers of
       Historic Places or included in the Inventory of Historic and Archaeological Assets of the
       Commonwealth within the Project site. New construction associated with the proposed
       Project is sited on a previously developed parcel consisting of filled land. It is not
       anticipated that the Project site will impact archaeological resources.

4.4    Infrastructure Systems

       This section discusses energy, wastewater, water, and stormwater.             Transportation
       infrastructure is discussed in Section 3.0.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF       4-19   Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                 Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       4.4.1         Energy and Site Utilities

       New power service will be brought to the site to supply the Project's electrical needs. The
       incoming power feed from the electric utility will terminate in one or two customer stations
       located on the site. Power will be routed underground from the stations to main electrical
       service in the CUP. Natural gas will be provided via a new or existing service, as will water
       supply and wastewater disposal.

       4.4.1.1       Mechanical Systems

       Cooling for the Project will be provided from the CUP, with high-efficiency centrifugal
       chillers producing chilled water to serve as the cooling medium. The chilled water will be
       pumped throughout the casino areas and two hotels. A variable flow pumping system will
       be used to reduce energy consumption. It is anticipated that a waterside economizer will
       be provided to provide free wintertime cooling. Cooling towers will be located outside the
       CUP.

       Heating for the facility will be provided from the CUP, with high-efficiency, natural gas-
       fired condensing boilers producing hot water as the heating medium. A variable flow
       pumping system will be used to reduce energy consumption. The hot water will be
       pumped throughout the casino areas and two hotels.

       Domestic hot water will be produced via natural gas-fired condensing hot water heaters that
       will be located near areas with high domestic hot water demands (e.g., restaurants, hotel,
       etc.).

       Space heating and cooling for the restaurants, gaming, and back-of-house areas will be
       accomplished primarily via air handling units. The air handling units will use chilled water
       and hot water as the cooling and heating sources. Economizer sections will be
       incorporated. Energy recovery devices (e.g., enthalpy wheels and/or run-around heat
       exchanger loops) will be used to reduce energy consumption for areas with high outside air
       requirements. Fan coils will be used for supplemental cooling where needed, or where
       building geometry dictates; the fan coil units will be "four-pipe" units.

       Space ventilation will be designed in accordance with the Massachusetts Building Code and
       ASHRAE-62 guidelines.

       The parking garage will be unheated. It will be partially naturally ventilated, and partially
       mechanically ventilated.

       4.4.1.2       Electrical Systems

       The electrical distribution will be based on the programmatic and mechanical system needs
       of each portion of the Project (i.e., Casino Area I, Casino Area II, two hotels, and garage).
       The main electrical service will enter the CUP from which it will be transformed and

3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         4-20   Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                   Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       distributed throughout the Project. Code-required emergency power and optional standby
       power will be provided for each portion of the Project. Emergency and standby power will
       be obtained from on-site generators burning ultra-low sulfur diesel fuel.

       Power will be brought to the Project from an existing utility substation with spare capacity
       via new buried electrical conductors; thus, the existing electrical grid serving adjacent
       neighborhoods should not be affected.

       Lighting systems will be designed to meet requirements of the Massachusetts State Energy
       Code and ASHRAE 90.1, where applicable. Lighting control schemes including daylight-
       responsive control will be analyzed on a case-by-case basis for implementation.

       4.4.1.3       Energy Management System

       The facility will be equipped with a direct digital control (DDC) energy management system
       that will allow operators to monitor and adjust system and energy performance of the
       mechanical systems.

       4.4.1.4       Energy Efficiency

       Mechanical and electrical systems will be designed to meet requirements of the
       Massachusetts Stretch Energy Code and to achieve the energy use requirements of the
       Stretch Code and the LEED standard. The Proponent anticipates that the Project will
       include at least the following energy efficiency measures: high-efficiency chillers,
       condensing boilers, water- and air-side economizers, heat recovery, high-efficiency lighting
       with energy-saving lighting controls, and water-conserving plumbing fixtures. Section 4.2.1
       contains additional details regarding sustainable design and LEED.

       4.4.2         Wastewater

       4.4.2.1       Existing Sewer Infrastructure

       Currently, sanitary sewage generated by the existing grandstand and other utility buildings
       on site are collected by a gravity sewer line that runs north-south and connects to a private
       sewer pump station located on the southerly side of the property. This pump station pumps
       sanitary sewer via force main to an existing BWSC 12-inch sanitary gravity sewer in
       Waldemar Avenue. This gravity sewer runs easterly in Waldemar Avenue until it ultimately
       discharges into a 24-inch sanitary sewer main at the end of Waldemar Avenue. Additional
       wastewater from the existing CAFO, or horse stable, is pumped from a settling pond at the
       northeastern corner of the racetrack to an existing sewer manhole located in the bus drop-
       off near the Suffolk Downs MBTA station on the Suffolk Downs property. Wastewater from
       this manhole discharges to the same existing BWSC sanitary sewer manhole located in
       Walley Avenue between the Suffolk Downs MBTA station and the southeast corner of the
       Project site. From there, wastewater flows easterly via a BWSC 24-inch sanitary main in



3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        4-21   Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                  Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       Leverett Avenue. Flow is eventually transported by the BWSC sewer system to the ultimate
       discharge point at the MWRA Deer Island Waste Water Treatment Plant for treatment and
       disposal. The existing sewer system is illustrated in Figure 4-3.

       The Project will replace the existing pump station located on the property, and the existing
       force main connecting to the gravity sewer line in Waldemar Avenue will be discontinued.
       Instead, wastewater from the new pump station will be pumped to the existing sewer
       manhole located near the bus drop-off near the Suffolk Downs MBTA station; this is the
       same manhole that accepts wastewater from the CAFO. Due to the configuration of the
       proposed development program, a second pump station is expected to be required. The
       second pump station will collect sanitary sewage via a gravity collection system from the
       portion of the development located in the existing grandstand area as well as portions of
       Casino Area II. This pump station will convey sewage via force main to a new pump station
       proposed in the vicinity of the existing pump station. It will also collect and convey sewage
       form the other portions of the Project as well as from the existing grandstand area and
       discharge via force main to the gravity sewer manhole located on the Project site in the bus
       drop-off area near the Suffolk Downs MBTA station. This new configuration will divert
       wastewater flows that are currently discharged to the 12-inch gravity sewer located in
       Waldemar Avenue and will relocate the discharge point from the Project site downstream
       of the residential neighborhood along Waldemar Avenue. Therefore, any sanitary sewage
       generated by the Project will not impact the existing 12-inch gravity sewer line in
       Waldemar Avenue.

       No changes are proposed to the existing discharge from the stable area to the BWSC
       sanitary sewer at the east end of Waldemar Avenue.

       4.4.2.2       Estimated Wastewater Generation

       Sewage generation rates for the proposed Project were estimated using the MassDEP
       regulations at 310 CMR 15.00. The State Environmental Code, Title 5: Standard
       Requirements for The Siting, Construction, Inspection, Upgrade and Expansion of On-Site
       Sewage Treatment and Disposal Systems (310 CMR 15.00) lists typical generation values for
       the sources listed in Table 4-5 for the proposed Project. Typical generation values are
       generally conservative for estimating sewage flows from new construction. Sewage flow
       design criteria values at 310 CMR 15.00 are used to evaluate new sewage flows or the
       increase in flows to existing connections. Table 4-5 describes the increased sewage
       generation in gallons per day (gpd) for the proposed Project.

       In 310 CMR 15.00 under the Establishment column, there are no provisions for Casino
       uses. Therefore, wastewater estimates were developed based on the various uses proposed
       within the new development to best describe the sewage generation in a manner that
       coincides with 310 CMR 15.00, as shown in Table 4-5.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF       4-22    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                  Epsilon Associates, Inc.
        Wastewater generation factors from Title V were applied to different uses within the
        proposed casino. Since some Title V factors were not directly applicable to the casino uses,
        care was taken to apply those factors from Title V to corresponding uses as appropriate. For
        example, a flow factor of 20 gallons per day was used for all seats at gaming tables, office
        building factors (75 gpd/1000 sf) were used for the office uses within the casino, restaurant
        factors (35 gpd/seat) were used for restaurant uses, and theatre seating flow factors (3
        gpd/seat) were used for the grandstand areas. Estimates of the numbers of seats in each
        gaming and restaurant area were determined by the Project's program. These flows were
        verified against flow factors used in other states for casino uses.

        Estimates provided for racing also include flows for a lounge area and a restaurant. Flow
        estimates were performed assuming full capacities, and therefore may be conservative when
        compared to actual flow values since the facilities will not always operate at full capacity.
        Estimates provided below for the racing component of the proposed Project are based on
        Title V flow factors. Although they indicate a higher flow than is currently experienced by
        the racing facility, this should not be interpreted as an increase in size of the racing program
        or imply any increases in size to the stable area. The stable area may decrease in size,
        resulting in a reduction in flows generated by the CAFO operation.

        Peak flows generated by the Project will be developed using the Merrimack curve as the
        design progresses. These peak flows will be shared with BWSC to assist in evaluating the
        Project's effects on the BWSC system.

       The proposed Project's impact to the existing BWSC systems in the directly adjacent streets
       was analyzed based on the proposed wastewater generation estimated above. Capacity

       The existing 12-inch gravity sewer line demonstrates adequate capacity to accept and
       convey the increase in flow from the proposed Project. The Proponent will coordinate with
       the BWSC to confirm downstream capacities of the sewage conveyance system.

       4.4.2.4              Proposed Wastewater Infrastructure

       Sanitary sewage generated by the proposed Project will be discharged to an existing sewer
       manhole located on the property and conveyed via a 12-inch PVC gravity sewer line to the
       BWSC sanitary sewer system located near the Suffolk Downs MBTA station. This pipe


3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF                   4-24      Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                                       Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       discharges to a BWSC 24-inch gravity sewer pipe conveys flow from the Suffolk Downs site
       as well as flows from Waldemar Avenue underneath the MBTA tracks to the BWSC system.
       The Proponent will work closely with the BWSC to ensure the design and capacity of the
       proposed wastewater infrastructure will avoid adverse impacts to the existing BWSC 24-
       inch sanitary sewer main as well as any downstream conveyance infrastructure. The
       Proponent will continue to coordinate with BWSC regarding potential Project impacts on
       downstream piping, and will provide appropriate mitigation if necessary. As the Project
       design progresses, revisions to the wastewater flow estimates will be provided. The
       Proponent understands that these flows will be utilized by BWSC's consultant to model the
       existing system and determine Project impacts. In addition, the Proponent will submit a
       General Service Application and site plan for review as the Project progresses. All
       proposed improvements and connections to BWSC infrastructure will be reviewed as part of
       the BWSC's site plan review process for the Project. This process will include a
       comprehensive design review of proposed service connections, an assessment of estimated
       Project demands and system capacity, and the establishment of service accounts.

       Renovation of the existing grandstand building will include installation of a new gravity
       sanitary sewer main in the courtyard in between the grandstand and the proposed parking
       garage; a majority of the proposed development will be connected to the new gravity
       sanitary main. The main will transport flow to a proposed pump station located northwest
       of the parking garage, although the exact location of the pump station has not yet been
       determined. This pump station will transfer flow to a second new pump station that will
       replace the existing pump station on the south side of the property.

       The existing gravity sewer servicing the grandstand building will be abandoned, and new 8-
       inch gravity sewer line will be installed in a similar location. A new force main is proposed
       to connect to an existing sewer manhole and 12-inch PVC gravity sewer pipe that leaves the
       Suffolk Downs property. This 12-inch line connects to a 24-inch gravity sewer line that
       flows underneath the MBTA tracks.

       The Project will generate new wastewater flows greater than 50,000 GPD; therefore, a
       Sewer Connection Permit BRP WP 74 will be required from MassDEP. Since the Project
       also includes an extension of sewer line greater than 1,000 linear feet, it will also require a
       Sewer Extension Permit (BRP WP 71) from MassDEP.

       4.4.3         Water

       4.4.3.1       Existing Water Infrastructure

       BWSC provides water service to the Project site. Of the five different water systems within
       the City of Boston, which provide service to portions of the City based on ground surface
       elevation, the northern high service exists at the Project site. There is an existing 8-inch
       northern high water main beneath Waldemar Avenue. The City of Revere also provides
       water service to the Project site. The existing water system is illustrated in Figure 4-4.


3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        4-25    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                   Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       Existing domestic water use on the Project site is approximately 17,800 GPD, and existing
       irrigation of the racetrack is approximately 6,700 GPD (April through October only). The
       Project site uses an additional 15,700 GPD for operations of the maintenance facility as
       well as outdoor racetrack irrigation that is supplied by the City of Revere.

       4.4.3.2        Estimated Proposed Water Consumption

       The Project's water demand for domestic services is estimated by applying a conservative
       factor of 1.1 (i.e., 110%) to the estimated sewage generation described in Section 4.4.2.2.
       Based on this calculation, the Project's total estimated water demand for domestic services
       is approximately 355,410 GPD (based on a total domestic sewage generation of 323,100
       GPD) (see Table 4-7). The total change in domestic water use is 337,610 GPD which is
       calculated by subtracting the existing 17,800 GPD from the projected water use of 355,410
       GPD. The Project will not change the existing 6,700 GPD that are used to irrigate the
       racetrack from April through October, or the 15,700 GPD supplied by Revere that that is
       used to operate the maintenance facilities. Additional irrigation of the Project site, based on
       an estimated one-inch of watering per week of the 14.3 acres of irrigation landscape around
       the casinos, parking garage, and entry drive, will be approximately 58,000 GPD. Water for
       the Project will be supplied by the BWSC system. The Proponent will engage in further
       discussions with the City of Revere to determine if the existing water service will be
       maintained.

       The Project design will incorporate various measures to reduce water consumption,
       including aeration fixtures and appliances that conserve water and sensor-operated faucets
       and toilets. Section 4.2.1.2 contains a description of sustainability measures that describe
       water-conserving design features in greater detail.

       All new water services will be installed in accordance with the latest local, state, and
       federal codes and standards. Backflow preventers will be installed at domestic and fire
       protection service connections. New meters will be installed with Meter Transmitter Units
       (MTUs) as part of the BWSC's AMR system. The existing water use numbers in Table 4-7
       were developed based on water use records provided by Suffolk Downs. Proposed water
       use volumes are based on Title V flow factors for the proposed Project only and do not
       contemplate any additional site development.

       4.4.3.3         Water System Capacity and Impacts

       At the Proponent's request, BWSC recently conducted a hydrant flow test at two hydrants
       located along Waldemar Avenue because BWSC record flow test data for hydrant flow and
       pressure in the Project vicinity were not available. Results of these tests are provided in
       Table 4-8.
