       Water capacity problems are not anticipated within the existing system as a result of Project
       construction. However, the design team will evaluate hourly peak flows as well as
       maximum daily flows as the Project design progresses.

       4.4.3.4         Proposed Water Infrastructure

       The Project includes an upgrade to the existing water connection in Waldemar Avenue that
       will serve the entire proposed development. The new water service connection will be
       located in generally the same location as the existing service to the site. The Project also
       includes a secondary looped water connection to the Waldemar Avenue main. The second
       connection will be located near the Route 1A entrance.

       Domestic and fire protection water service connections required by the proposed Project
       will meet the applicable City and State codes and standards, including cross-connection
       backflow prevention. Compliance with standards for the domestic water system service
       connection will be reviewed as part of BWSC's Site Plan Review Process. This review will
       include, but will not be limited to, sizing of domestic water and fire protection services,
       calculation of meter sizing, backflow prevention design, and location of hydrants and
       siamese connections that conform to BWSC and Boston Fire Department requirements.


3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF            4-27    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                        Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       4.4.4         Water Quality and Stormwater

       4.4.4.1       Existing Stormwater Infrastructure

       When the existing Suffolk Downs development was constructed in 1935, the stormwater
       management system was designed and installed consistent with standard engineering
       practice at that time. The system was constructed to convey stormwater from the site but
       not to provide water quality treatment. Due to the age of the existing stormwater system,
       some of the catch basins and piping have filled with sand and are unable to convey
       stormwater; during heavy rains, ponding occurs throughout the parking lot. The existing
       on-site drainage system is shown on Figure 4-5.

       As determined by recent soil testing on site, existing soil conditions are primarily urban fill
       material that was placed during the site's original development. Groundwater is generally
       encountered at approximately two to six feet below existing grade, and soils are generally
       unsuitable for groundwater infiltration. This combination of poor soil and large impervious
       areas generate a significant amount of stormwater runoff.

       The site generally grades and drains to wetlands systems located along the perimeter of the
       property. These systems, many of which were man-made during site development in the
       1930s, ultimately drain to Boston Harbor.

       Storm drain improvements were recently made in the stable area located north of the
       racetrack and Sales Creek to collect stormwater in that area. Since the stable area is
       considered a CAFO, all precipitation that falls on the ground in this area is considered
       process water. All process water is collected by a closed collection system and routed to an
       impoundment facility located in the racetrack infield. Water collected in the impoundment
       pond is pumped to the BWSC sewer system via a force main that runs through the racetrack
       and discharges to the previously-described gravity collection system in Waldemar Avenue.

       Stormwater that falls on the roofs within the CAFO area is collected by a separate system, is
       considered stormwater, and is discharged directly to Sales Creek.

       4.4.4.2       Proposed Stormwater Management

       The Project includes a new stormwater management system that will significantly improve
       existing conditions. In addition, the proposed development will decrease impervious area
       on the site by approximately nine acres, thereby reducing the rate and volume of
       stormwater leaving the site. A combination of conventional and LID drainage BMPs will be
       included as part of the site's drainage design. These measures will include water quality
       swales, bioretention basins, catch basins with hoods and sumps, and proprietary structural
       water quality units. Additional sustainable stormwater measures, such as constructed
       wetlands and rainwater harvesting, are currently being evaluated. The Proponent will make
       efforts to increase the amount of retention, reuse, and infiltration of stormwater on the
       Project site, further reducing water quality impacts to adjacent properties. Furthermore,

3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        4-28      Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                     Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       installation of stormwater BMPs designed in accordance with MassDEP Stormwater
       Management Guidelines will improve water quality treatment. Proposed stormwater BMPs
       include catch basins with deep sumps and hoods, water quality swales, bioretention basins,
       and proprietary water quality units, when necessary. The improved drainage system will
       significantly improve the quality of discharged water relative to existing conditions.

       Stormwater management in the northern and northeastern portions of the site where the
       existing stables are located has already been addressed by the CAFO work and so will
       remain generally the same.

       Since the Proponent anticipates discharging stormwater to wetlands or private
       infrastructure, any connections to BWSC infrastructure will be minimal. However, all
       improvements and connections to BWSC infrastructure, if any, will be reviewed as part of
       BWSC's site plan review process. This process will include a comprehensive design review
       of proposed service connections, an assessment of Project demands and system capacity,
       and compliance with the City of Boston Zoning Code.

       4.4.4.3       Water Quality Improvements

       As described above, the Project will improve the water quality of nearby wetlands and
       water bodies by significantly improving stormwater management and treatment on site.

       Various measures will also be utilized during construction to minimize potential adverse
       impacts from runoff. Erosion and sediment control measures such as silt fence and haybales
       will be installed to protect off-site areas and BWSC storm drain systems. Existing and
       proposed catch basins will be protected with filter fabric; hay bales, and/or crushed stone to
       remove sediment from runoff during construction. These controls will be inspected and
       maintained throughout construction until disturbed areas have been stabilized by the
       placement of pavement, structure, or vegetative cover.

       All necessary dewatering will be conducted in accordance with applicable MWRA and
       BWSC discharge permits. Once construction is complete, the Project will be in compliance
       with all local and state stormwater management policies to the maximum extent practicable
       (see Section 4.4.4.4).

       4.4.4.4       Compliance with MassDEP Stormwater Management Policy Standards

       In 1997, MassDEP adopted a new Stormwater Management Policy to address non-point
       source pollution and published the Massachusetts Stormwater Handbook as guidance on
       the Stormwater Policy. The Handbook and Guidelines were revised in 2008. The Policy
       prescribes specific stormwater management standards for development projects, including
       urban pollutant removal criteria for projects that may impact environmental resource areas.
       Compliance is achieved through the implementation of BMPs in the stormwater
       management design. The Policy is administered locally pursuant to MGL Ch. 131, s. 40.


3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF       4-29    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                  Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       A brief explanation of each Policy Standard and proposed system compliance is provided
       below.

       Standard #1: No new stormwater conveyances (e.g., outfalls) may discharge untreated
       stormwater directly to or cause erosion in wetlands or waters of the Commonwealth.

       Compliance: The proposed Project design will comply with this Standard. All stormwater
       from the Project site will be treated via conventional or LID drainage BMPs.

       Standard #2: Stormwater management systems must be designed so that post-development
       peak discharge rates do not exceed pre-development peak discharge rates.

       Compliance: The proposed Project design will comply with this Standard. Stormwater
       management improvements associated with the proposed Project will decrease the existing
       discharge rate. Project development will decrease impervious area on the Project site by
       approximately nine acres, which will decrease the rate and volume of stormwater
       discharged from the Project site.

       Standard #3: Loss of annual recharge to groundwater should be minimized through the use
       of infiltration measures to the maximum extent practicable. The annual recharge from the
       post development site should approximate the annual recharge from the pre-development
       or existing site conditions, based on soil types.

       Compliance: The Project will decrease impervious area on the site by approximately nine
       acres, which will decrease peak flows from the Project site and promote infiltration. Due to
       the site's poor soil conditions and high groundwater table, dedicated underground
       infiltration facilities are not proposed as part of the Project.

       Standard #4: For new development, stormwater management systems must be designed to
       remove 80% of the average annual load (post-development conditions) of Total Suspended
       Solids (TSS). It is presumed that this standard is met when: Suitable nonstructural practices
       for source control and pollution prevention are implemented; Stormwater management best
       management practices (BMPs) are sized to capture the prescribed runoff volume; and
       Stormwater management BMPs are maintained as designed.

       Compliance: The proposed Project is a redevelopment project, and every effort will be
       made to treat stormwater to achieve 80% TSS removal. Stormwater generated on site will
       be treated using a mix of LID and conventional BMPs including water quality swales,
       bioretention basins, and catch basins with hoods and sumps. In areas where LID practices
       are not feasible, structural water quality units may be installed to provide additional
       stormwater treatment. All paved areas on the Project site will be treated to remove TSS.
       The Project will discharge treated stormwater to wetlands surrounding the site, the closed
       drainage system located along Tomasello Drive, and directly to Sales Creek.



3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF       4-30    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                  Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       Standard #5: For land uses with higher potential pollutant loads, source control and
       pollution prevention shall be implemented in accordance with the Massachusetts
       Stormwater Handbook to eliminate or reduce the discharge of stormwater runoff from such
       land uses to the maximum extent practicable. If, through source control and/or pollution
       prevention, all land uses with higher potential pollutant loads cannot be completely
       protected from exposure to rain, snow, snow melt, and stormwater runoff, the proponent
       shall use the specific structural stormwater BMPs determined by the Department to be
       suitable for such uses as provided in the Massachusetts Stormwater Handbook. Stormwater
       discharges from land uses with higher potential pollutant loads shall also comply with the
       requirements of the Massachusetts Clean Waters Act, M.G.L. c. 21, §§ 26-53 and the
       regulations promulgated there under at 314 CMR 3.00, 314 CMR 4.00 and 314 CMR 5.00.

       Compliance: Given that the proposed parking area will support over 1,000 vehicle trips per
       day, the Project site meets the definition of a Land Use with Higher Potential Pollutant
       Loads. All stormwater generated by the Project will be treated for TSS removal though
       either LID or conventional BMPs. As a redevelopment project, the Project design will strive
       to meet the requirements to the maximum extent practicable.

       Standard #6: Stormwater discharge to critical areas must utilize certain stormwater
       management BMPs approved for critical areas. Critical areas are Outstanding Resource
       Waters (ORWs), shellfish beds, swimming beaches, cold-water fisheries and recharge areas
       for public water supplies.

       Compliance: The Project will significantly improve the quality of stormwater discharged
       from the property relative to existing conditions by incorporating a mix of LID and
       conventional BMPs into the site design to provide water quality treatment. As a
       redevelopment project, the Project design will strive to meet the requirements to the
       maximum extent practicable.

       Standard #7: A redevelopment project is required to meet the following Stormwater
       Management Standards only to the maximum extent practicable: Standard 2, Standard 3,
       and the pretreatment and structural stormwater best management practice requirements of
       Standards 4, 5, and 6. Existing stormwater discharges shall comply with Standard 1 only to
       the maximum extent practicable. A redevelopment project shall also comply with all other
       requirements of the Stormwater Management Standards and improve existing conditions.

       Compliance: The Project is a redevelopment, and the design will comply with this
       Standard. The proposed Project will comply with the Stormwater Management Standards to
       the maximum extent practicable.

       Standard #8: Erosion and sediment controls must be implemented to prevent impacts
       during construction or land disturbance activities.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF      4-31    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                 Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       Compliance: The Project design will comply with this standard. Sedimentation and
       erosion controls will be incorporated into the Project design and employed during
       construction. These controls will be inspected regularly consistent with local, state, and
       federal requirements.

       Standard 9: A Long-Term Operation and Maintenance (O&M) Plan shall be developed and
       implemented to ensure that stormwater management systems function as designed.

       Compliance: The Project design will comply with this standard. An O&M Plan including
       long-term BMP operation requirements will be prepared for the Project to ensure proper
       maintenance and functioning of the stormwater management system.

       Standard 10: All illicit discharges to the stormwater management system are prohibited.

       Compliance: The Project design will comply with this standard. There will be no illicit
       connections associated with the proposed Project.

4.5    Construction-Period Considerations

       4.5.1         Air Quality

       Impacts associated with construction activities may generate fugitive dust, which will result
       in localized increases in airborne particulate levels. Fugitive dust emissions from
       construction activities will depend on such factors as the properties of the emitting surfaces
       (e.g., moisture content and volume of spoils), meteorological variables, and construction
       practices employed.

       The contractor will implement dust control measures during active demolition and
       construction that will primarily consist of using wetting agents regularly to control and
       suppress dust that may come from the structure being demolished or the construction
       materials. The contractor will comply with National Emission Standards for Hazardous
       Pollutants (NESHAP) throughout renovation, demolition, and construction activities.

       The proposed redevelopment may also include on-site processing of brick and concrete,
       which would involve use of an on-site crusher. Appropriate notifications 30 days prior to
       any crushing will be performed, including notifying local officials and MassDEP in
       accordance with 310 CMR 16.05(3)(e)6. At no time shall fugitive dust be allowed to
       migrate beyond the immediate work zone. Dust mitigation during processing will include
       the use of water sprayers.

       Site preparations involving construction haul roads, soil stockpiles, and vehicles exiting the
       Project site have the greatest potential to create fugitive dust; soil excavation does not
       typically generate dust, however, due to the natural moisture content of subsurface soils.
       As necessary, haul roads will be routinely misted to suppress dust generation. Soil
       stockpiles can either be covered or vegetated, depending on how long the stockpile will

3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF       4-32    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                  Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       remain. Dust from construction traffic exiting the Project site onto public roads will be
       controlled with the use of vehicle tracking pads, which remove soil from the tires of
       construction vehicles. Paved construction entrances will also be routinely swept by street
       sweepers to remove accumulated soils. At no time will visible soils be permitted on public
       streets that could result in fugitive dust issues.

       4.5.2         Noise

       As a conservative measure, the Project will include a noise mitigation plan to minimize, to
       the extent practicable, the generation of sound levels that will impact off-site receptors. The
       noise mitigation plan will involve mitigation measures such as:

            Allowable construction timeframes will adhere to local requirements, and major
            activities such as excavation or demolition will typically be limited to normal
            working hours;

            In accordance with Massachusetts Vehicle Idling Regulations, idling of construction
            equipment will comply with 310 CMR 7.11;

            All construction equipment will be required to be properly maintained, lubricated,
            and fitted with properly functioning muffler systems; and

            To the extent practicable, specific activities such as crushing and pulverizing, as
            well as equipment staging areas, will be located at appropriate distances from
            residential receptors.

       Specific mitigation measures will be incorporated into the contract document based on the
       anticipated activities and impacts related to each stage of Project construction. Project
       activities will adhere to MassDEP's Noise Pollution Policy at 310 CMR 7.10.

       4.5.3         Water Quality and Stormwater

       The Proponent will prepare a Stormwater Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP) and submit a
       Notice of Intent (NOI) to the EPA for coverage under EPA's NPDES Construction General
       Permit (CGP). The SWPPP will detail methods for preventing soil erosion and pollution of
       downstream receiving waters due to stormwater runoff from construction zones, and will
       include both structural and non-structural BMPs to be used during and after construction. It
       will also require site inspections in accordance with the CGP during all periods of
       construction when ground surfaces remain un-stabilized. Locations for materials stockpiles,
       construction staging, construction trailers, fueling areas, and equipment storage will be
       identified on the Civil Engineering sheet set.

       Construction-period erosion and sediment controls will include the non-structural and
       structural BMPs described below. These controls will be designed, installed, and
       maintained in accordance with the SWPPP as well as the following documents:

3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        4-33    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                   Epsilon Associates, Inc.
            "Storm Water Management for Construction Activities, Developing Pollution
            Prevention Plans and Best Management Practices" (EPA 832-R92-005, Sept. 1992);

            "Storm Water Management for Construction Activities, Developing Pollution
            Prevention Plans and Best Management Practices ­ Summary Guidance" (EPA 833-
            R92-001, Oct. 1992);

            Massachusetts Stormwater Management Policy Handbook (Volume I) and Technical
            Handbook (Volume II) issued by the Massachusetts Department of Environmental
            Protection, March 1997; and

            Massachusetts Erosion and Sediment Control Guidelines for Urban and Suburban
            Areas, A Guide for Planners, Designers and Municipal Officials, March 1997.

       4.5.3.1       Non-Structural Controls

       One of the most important methods of preventing soil erosion and sedimentation associated
       with stormwater runoff is to minimize the amount and duration of non-stabilized surfaces.
       Maintaining an efficient construction sequence that minimizes the size of disturbed areas
       reduces the exposure of non-stabilized surfaces to the erosive effects of stormwater. Both
       the SWPPP and CMP will require contractors to minimize areas of disturbance and to
       schedule equipment and materials deliveries to reduce the need for on-site storage. The
       thoughtful siting of storage and stockpile areas away from downstream receptors will also
       help prevent sedimentation from stormwater runoff.

       On-site storage of hazardous materials or toxic chemicals will be limited to what is
       absolutely necessary. Where necessary, these materials will be stored off the ground and in
       enclosed or covered structures to prevent contact with stormwater runoff.

       Daily mechanical street sweeping of construction areas and surrounding streets and
       sidewalks will be required throughout construction to control fugitive dust emissions. The
       mechanical sweeping and construction entrance mats will help prevent sediment from
       being tracked off site where they could be washed into surface waters, wetland resource
       areas, or the municipal stormwater management system. Permanent stabilization of
       exposed surfaces will be required within seven days of the completion of work in any given
       area. In instances when it is not possible to permanently stabilize exposed soils within
       seven days of work completion, or when soils will be exposed for 14 days or longer
       without work occurring, temporary stabilization of surfaces will be required. This
       temporary stabilization will be achieved by seeding with quickly-germinating grasses or the
       use of erosion control blankets.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF       4-34   Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                 Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       4.5.3.2       Structural Practices

       In addition to the non-structural controls discussed above, many construction-period
       structural BMPs will be required to prevent pollution from stormwater runoff. Appropriate
       perimeter controls such as silt socks, straw wattles, silt fence, and compost berms will be
       installed to filter and slow stormwater runoff as it leaves the construction site. To prevent
       the import of invasive species and weed seeds, hay bales will not be used for erosion and
       sedimentation control in the Project. These perimeter controls will be inspected in
       accordance with the General Permit. Sediment build-up behind perimeter controls will be
       removed when it reaches one-half the height of the controls, and controls will be repaired
       or replaced as needed.

       To prevent the tracking of sediments beyond the construction site, stabilized construction
       exits (i.e., site entrance mats) of crushed stone will be installed. All construction traffic will
       be directed over these exits when leaving the site to remove soils from vehicle tires.
       Construction exits will be inspected in accordance with the SWPPP, and will be repaired or
       replaced as necessary when sediment builds up on the surface or crushed stone is
       displaced. Appropriately-sized concrete truck wash-out basins will be installed in locations
       to prevent contact with stormwater runoff. These basins will be cleaned as needed, and
       concrete materials will be disposed of in accordance with applicable local, state, and
       federal regulations.

       New and existing inlets to stormwater management systems will be protected against
       sediment inflow. Catch basins will be fitted with filter inserts or will be surrounded by silt
       socks or other materials to filter incoming stormwater. The stormwater management
       systems will be constructed starting at the downstream end, and no flows will be directed to
       permanent stormwater BMPs prior to their completion and upstream surface stabilization.

       Where larger site disturbances are necessary to accommodate particular construction
       activities, various measures will be implemented to prevent sediment-laden runoff from
       leaving the Project site. Where long, exposed slopes are required, temporary check dams
       will be constructed to reduce runoff velocities and promote less erosive sheet flow. These
       check dams may be earthen berms, straw wattles, compost berms, or other appropriate
       systems of slowing runoff velocities and promoting sediment removal. Temporary sediment
       basins will be constructed where necessary to allow sediments to drop out of suspension
       prior to discharge and promote construction-period infiltration to groundwater. Disturbed
       surfaces will be temporarily graded towards these basins, or temporary diversion swales will
       be built to direct flows to these basins. Basin outlets will be constructed to promote low-
       velocity sheet flow and will be directed towards existing vegetated areas for further
       treatment.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         4-35    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                     Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       4.5.3.3       Dewatering

       Temporary construction dewatering will likely be required locally for various excavations.
       Intermittent pumping will be used as needed to allow for construction in-the-dry. Effluent
       generated during temporary construction dewatering will be infiltrated into the ground
       where possible. If necessary, effluent will be chemically tested and discharged in
       compliance with applicable regulations and discharge permits. In such a scenario, water
       quality of dewatering discharge effluent will also be monitored during construction as part
       of the discharge permit requirements.

       4.5.4         Infrastructure Protection

       Existing public and private infrastructure located in nearby public rights-of-way will be
       protected during Project construction. Installation of proposed utility connections within
       public ways will be performed in accordance with BWSC, Boston Public Works
       Department, the Dig-Safe Program, and applicable utility company requirements. Specific
       methods for constructing proposed utilities where they are near to, or connect with, existing
       water, sewer, and drain facilities will be reviewed by BWSC as part of the Site Plan Review
       process. All necessary permits will be obtained before commencement of work.

       The Proponent will continue to work and coordinate with BWSC and the utility companies
       to ensure safe and coordinated utility operations in connection with the Project.

       4.5.5         Construction and Demolition Debris

       The Project includes the demolition of existing buildings, paved driveways, parking lots,
       sidewalks, and various utilities including portions of existing water mains and sewer mains.
       Based on available information, a portion of the demolition waste will include hazardous
       materials such as asbestos and lead-based paint. These materials are classified as "special
       waste" under MassDEP solid waste regulations. Accordingly, the Proponent will segregate
       asbestos, asbestos-containing material, and materials with lead-based paint to follow the
       required special handling and transporting methods set out in MassDEP regulations.

       Based on a February 14, 2007 Phase I/Phase II Environmental Site Assessment report
       completed by GEI Consultants, an on-site inspection for asbestos-containing building
       materials and lead-based paint was conducted by Smith & Wessel of Merrimac,
       Massachusetts in select buildings on the Project site. Materials that tested positive for
       asbestos included floor tile and paper, wall and ceiling panels, insulation, window glazing
       compound, and door caulking. It is unclear whether the existing grandstand roof contains
       asbestos. It is also noted that some painted surfaces contain lead-based paint.

       Surveys and abatement plans related to asbestos-containing material, PCB-containing
       material, and lead-based paint will be required for each building prior to demolition.
       Asbestos, PCBs, and lead-based paint will be disposed, per MassDEP regulations, at landfills


3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         4-36   Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                   Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       that have been approved to accept these materials. Any entity or individual engaged at the
       site for asbestos, lead-based paint, or PCB abatement or containment shall be licensed and
       certified under 453 CMR 6.00.

       Proposed demolition and construction activities will also generate solid waste. Brick,
       concrete, wood, gypsum wallboard and metal will be segregated from other construction
       debris for recycling. Other debris will be disposed of as non-banned construction waste in
       accordance with waste facility management regulations at 310 CMR 19.017. Asphalt
       pavement materials demolished during construction will be processed and reused as base
       course materials beneath new pavements. If concrete or brick is found to be coated, the
       Project would apply for a beneficial use determination permit prior to construction to allow
       for reuse.

       4.5.6         Construction Management Plan

       A CMP will be submitted to the BTD for review and approval prior to issuance of a building
       permit, and a draft will be included in the DEIR. This CMP will include detailed measures
       to ensure the maintenance of existing levels of service on adjacent roadways during Project
       construction and to minimize disruption in the area. The CMP will include such items as a
       construction activity schedule, construction staging areas, perimeter protection and public
       safety, material handling, construction trip generation and worker parking, defined truck
       routes and volumes, the need for full or partial street closures, delivery schedules,
       pedestrian and vehicle access, TDM measures for construction workers, construction-period
       air quality and dust control, construction-period noise, additional construction-period
       mitigation measures (e.g., rodent control), and coordination with other construction projects
       in the area.

       Appropriate construction techniques will be employed to ensure public safety and protect
       nearby residences and businesses. These techniques may include, as necessary, barricades,
       walkways, painted lines, and signage. Construction management and scheduling will
       minimize impacts on the surrounding environment by planning for construction worker
       commuting and parking, establishing routing plans and scheduling for trucking and
       deliveries, protecting existing utilities, maintaining fire access, and controlling noise and
       dust. Throughout Project construction, a secure perimeter will be maintained to protect the
       public from construction activities.

4.6    Request for a Public Benefit Determination

       In November 2007, the Massachusetts House and Senate passed An Act Relative to the
       Licensing Requirements for Certain Tidelands (HB 4324), which was signed by
       Governor Patrick on November 15, 2007 (Chapter 168 of the Acts of 2007) as the
       "Landlocked Tidelands Legislation." The legislation, among other things, names the
       Secretary of EEA as the "administrator of tidelands," and requires the Secretary to conduct a
       "public benefit review" for projects located on tidelands and to issue a written

3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF       4-37    Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                  Epsilon Associates, Inc.
       determination (the "Public Benefit Determination"). The Secretary must conduct a public
       benefit review for any proposed project located on tidelands or on landlocked tidelands
       that requires an EIR pursuant to MEPA.

       4.6.1         Nature of Affected Tidelands

       As evidenced by Attachment F, MassDEP determined that the Project site is not subject to
       Chapter 91 licensing jurisdiction and the only tidelands on the Project site are landlocked
       tidelands. This determination has since been relied upon in two separate MEPA filings (one
       by DCR and one by the Proponent). Chapter 168 of the Acts of 2007 confirmed the validity
       of such previously-issued determinations from MassDEP. Pursuant to Chapter 168 of the
       Acts of 2007 and accompanying regulatory changes, the portion of the site that constitutes
       landlocked tidelands is subject to an analysis of its public benefits as well as any impacts on
       the public trust rights to access, use, and enjoy tidelands that are protected by Chapter 91.

       4.6.2         Public Benefit of Project

       In making the Public Benefit Determination, the Landlocked Tidelands Legislation requires
       that the Secretary consider the following:

               "Purpose and effect of the development, the impacts on abutters and the
               surrounding community; enhancement to the property, benefits to the
               public trust rights in tidelands or other associated rights, including but not
               limited to, benefits provided through previously obtained municipal permits;
               community activities on the development site; environmental protection and
               preservation; public health and safety; and the general welfare; provided
               further that the secretary shall also consider the differences between
               tidelands and landlocked tidelands and great ponds when assessing the
               public benefit and shall consider the practical impact of the public benefit
               on the development."

       The DEIR will include a request for a public benefit determination.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF         4-38   Attachment A: Supplemental Project information
Development Review Components                                                   Epsilon Associates, Inc.
                                     Section 5.0
COORDINATION WITH OTHER GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES
5.0    COORDINATION WITH OTHER GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES

The Proponent will coordinate Project design and review with a number of governmental agencies
and community groups, some of which are addressed below. Section 1.6 contains a list of agencies
from which the Proponent will seek permits and approvals for the Project.

5.1    Massachusetts Environmental Policy Act

       The Project requires review under MEPA. The Project team met with the MEPA office
       before filing this ENF.

5.2    Chapter 91 Waterways Protection Act

       In a determination from the Assistant Commissioner dated June 23, 2000, MassDEP
       concluded that the filled portions of the Project site constitute landlocked tidelands, and
       therefore the site is not subject to Chapter 91 Licensing jurisdiction (see Attachment F).
       Chapter 168 of the Acts of 2007 confirmed the validity of such previously-issued
       determinations from MassDEP. A request for a Public Benefit Determination will be
       included within the DEIR.

5.3    Massachusetts Historical Commission

       The MHC has review authority over projects requiring state funding, licensing, permitting,
       and/or approvals that may have direct or indirect impacts to properties listed in the State
       Register of Historic Places, in compliance with M.G.L., Chapter 9, Sec. 26-27c, as amended
       by Chapter 254 of the Acts of 1988 (950 CMR 71.00). The State Register Review process
       will be initiated through the filing of this ENF under the MEPA.

5.4    Massachusetts Gaming Commission

       The Massachusetts Gaming Commission (the "Gaming Commission") was appointed
       pursuant to M.G.L. c.23K to license and regulate gaming in Massachusetts. The Proponent
       plans to file an application with the Massachusetts Gaming Commission seeking a license to
       operate a category I gaming establishment at Suffolk Downs pursuant to the provisions of
       M.G.L. Chapter 23K (on August 10, 2012, the Proponent paid to the Massachusetts Gaming
       Commission a statutorily-established fee to commence that process, and subsequently filed
       its RFA-1 suitability application with the Commission on January 15, 2013).

5.5    Massachusetts Department of Transportation

       Since formally becoming a Gambling License Applicant in August 2012, the Proponent is
       coordinating with MassDOT and expects to continue to participate in a series of on-going
       coordination meeting with MassDOT staff.




3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF       5-1    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Coordination with Other Agencies                                              Epsilon Associates, Inc.
5.6    Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation

       The Proponent has met with DCR to discuss the Project and will continue to coordinate
       with DCR as the Project moves forward.

5.7    City of Boston Review

       The Proponent has met numerous times with representatives from the City of Boston and
       the BRA as well as the City of Boston's Host Community Advisory Committee to discuss
       Project plans and to solicit feedback and input. The Proponent has also met with the BWSC
       to coordinate the design of water, sewer, and stormwater infrastructure. As required by the
       Gaming Act, the Proponent will enter into a Host Community Agreement with Boston. A
       Notice of Intent will be filed with the Boston Conservation Commission under the Wetlands
       Protection Act and Regulations and local wetlands ordinance. The Proponent looks forward
       to continuing to work with the City in addressing all applicable local requirements.

5.8    Massachusetts Port Authority

       The Proponent has met with representatives of the Massachusetts Port Authority and will
       continue to coordinate with the Port Authority as the Project moves forward.

5.9    Architectural Access Board

       The Project will comply with the requirements of the Architectural Access Board and the
       standards of the Americans with Disabilities Act.

5.10   Boston Civic Design Commission

       The Project will comply with the provisions of Article 28 of the Boston Zoning Code,
       including review by the Boston Civic Design Commission by the BRA as part of the Article
       80 process.

5.11   City of Revere Review

       The Proponent has met numerous times with officials and representatives from the City of
       Revere and looks forward to continuing to work with the City in addressing all applicable
       local requirements. A Notice of Intent will be filed with the Revere Conservation
       Commission under the Wetlands Protection Act and Regulations and local wetlands
       ordinance. As required by the Gaming Act, the Proponent will enter into a Host
       Community Agreement with Revere.

5.12   City of Chelsea

       The Project has met with officials and representatives from the City of Chelsea to discuss the
       Project and the terms of a Surrounding Community Agreement, and will continue to
       coordinate with the City as the Project moves forward.

3263/Caesars Resort at Suffolk Downs/ENF        5-2    Attachment A: Supplemental Project Information
Coordination with Other Agencies                                               Epsilon Associates, Inc.
5.13   Town of Winthrop

       The Project has met with officials and representatives from the Town of Winthrop to discuss
       the Project and the terms of a Surrounding Community Agreement, and will continue to
       coordinate with the Town as the Project moves forward.

5.14   Massachusetts Convention Center Authority

       The Proponent has met with representatives of the Massachusetts Convention Center
       Authority to discuss ways to enhance the travel and tourism industry in Massachusetts and
       will continue to do so as the Project moves forward.

5.15   Federal Aviation Administration

       The Project will comply with all applicable requirements of the Federal Aviation
       Administration.

Coordination with Other Agencies                                              Epsilon Associates, Inc.

                                Attachment I

CAESARS ENTERTAINMENT CODEGREEN FACT SHEET
          Caesars Entertainment Corporation Sustainability
                           FACT SHEET

CodeGreen Sustainability Strategy:
Caesars Entertainment's CodeGreen strategy is committed to critical issues of energy, waste,
water, and carbon emissions at all of its casino resorts and seeks to engage Caesars employees
in efforts to reduce natural resource use, conserve energy, and promote reuse and recycling.

Employees implement company-wide strategy through an enterprise executive steering
committee and property CodeGreen teams. Many of these best practices come from employee
suggestions and result in big savings and far reaching impacts. Caesars' ability to rapidly evolve
its strategy and programs reinforce the effectiveness of this top-down, bottom-up approach.

Global CodeGreen programs have included:
 Participation in the World Wildlife Fund's Earth Hour: More than 40 of Caesars casinos
   and resorts powered down exterior and non-essential lighting for one hour to bring attention
   to the issue of global climate change.
   National Park Trust's (NPT) Kids to Parks Day: More than 30 Caesars Entertainment
   Corporation properties in more than 19 communities across the country hosted events to
   promote conservation and outdoor recreation as part of NPT's signature National Kids to
   Parks Day initiative ­ a grassroots movement that encourages children and families to get
   outside and explore local, state and national parks in their community. More than 3,500
   people attended these events in 2012.
   Big Green Bus Tour (BGBT): Dartmouth students travel from coast-to-coast on a bus with
   a fuel system converted to run on waste vegetable oil in an effort to educate and engage
   publics about energy and environmental responsibility. Caesars Entertainment has
   sponsored the BGBT through monetary and in kind donations including the refueling of the
   bus with recycled waste vegtable oil (WVO) from its resorts and casinos in nine regions.
   Thousands of gallons of WVO was donated by the properties to fuel the bus, and hundreds
   of people attended the hosted events this summer.
   (LAS VEGAS) Teacher EXCHANGETM: Las Vegas Meetings by Caesars Entertainment
   collects left over convention supplies (i.e. notepads, pens and other useable materials) and
   donates them to The Public Education Foundation for their use in classrooms. The company
   and its charitable arm, Caesars Foundation, have given nearly $1.5 million to aid in funding
   the operation of the program as well as purchase of school supplies.

http://www.caesars.com/corporate/environment-sustainability.html
                                                                                           12/2012
   Clean the World Foundation: Since 2010, the Caesars Foundation has committed a
   combined $250,000 to aid Clean the World in opening a Las Vegas recycling operations
   facility, and decreasing acute respiratory infection and diarrheal disease related deaths that
   result from lack of soap and health education in impoverished communities around the world.
   In 2011, Caesars' U.S. properties donated more than 46 tons of soap and bottled amenities
   that were recycled and are helping to save lives every day
   Total CodeGreen At Home program: An employee-focused sustainability program
   designed to encourage employees to adopt green practices in their home, rewarding their
   efforts. By engaging employees in environmentally friendly practices, the company not only
   enhances its CodeGreen teams (sustainability advocates/leaders) but it also inspires whole
   communities.
   CodeGreen Day: A day at Caesars properties dedicated to celebrating and sharing the
   company's best sustainability practices that help to reduce energy, water use and waste
   consumption at our casino resorts with employees and guests.


Annual Resources Saved:
Caesars Entertainment has invested nearly $70 million on energy conservation projects alone
during the past nine years and has invested in more than 162 major retrofits, including:
 Installing energy efficient indoor and outdoor lighting, and reduce lighting usage
   Improving efficiency and effectiveness of air-handling systems
   Retrofitting equipment with energy-efficient upgrades
   Reducing water consumption in laundry facilities
   Upgrading guestroom thermostats
   Replacing technological controls with advanced energy-saving sensors
   Installing low-flow water controls and fixtures in guest areas
   Incorporating comprehensive recycling programs
   Training employees on environment-friendly practices

Savings include:
 In excess of 208 million kilowatt-hours in energy saved each year - enough to power more
   than 19,000 average homes and support a population greater than 50,000.
   Over 3.3 million therms in natural gas are saved each year.
   More than $24 million in annual resources is saved each year.
   298 million pounds of carbon dioxide emissions is averted each year. The avoided carbon
   dioxide is equivalent to:
      o   29,288 million passenger cars and 15 million miles not driven in one year
      o   155,532 round trip flights from Los Angeles to New York not taken
      o   314,680 barrels of oil not consumed
      o   112,760 extra acres of pine or fir forests storing carbon for a year
   In 2011, Caesars Entertainment's Las Vegas properties:

http://www.caesars.com/corporate/environment-sustainability.html
                                                                                         12/2012
      o   Recycled more than 7,763 tons of paper, glass, plastics, and cardboard
      o   Recovered more than 8,000 tons worth of assets (i.e. plates, utensils, linens, etc.)
      o   Average a 31 percent waste diversion rate amongst all properties
      o   Recycled nearly 3,000 tons of food waste at Paris Las Vegas and Caesars Palace
   In 2011, Caesars Entertainment's non-Las Vegas properties recycled more than 61,000
   pounds of soap and bottled amenities. Every single Caesars' property reported recycling
   cardboard, waste vegetable oil, soap and scrap metal further the environmental efforts in
   difficult to reach areas.


Sustainable Success Stories:
   Several resorts, including the Rio All-Suite Hotel & Casino, Harrah's Lake Tahoe and
   Showboat Atlantic City; have co-generation facilities that generate electricity, reducing
   demand on the nation's power grid.
      o   A five-megawatt co-generation facility was installed at the Rio All-Suite Hotel & Casino
          that uses waste heat from the generator stacks to warm water on-site for showers and
          other hot water needs.
      o   Harrah's Lake Tahoe hosts a co-gen facility that generates electricity and heats
          domestic water.
      o   A steam turbine in Atlantic City Showboat generates electricity as a by-product of the
          normal steam production at the resort. Use of the steam turbine produced an annual
          savings of 2,283,041 kWh and avoided emissions of more than 1,077,685 pounds of
          carbon dioxide and other gases.
   1,600,000 pounds of cardboard bailed and recycled at Caesars Atlantic City resorts.
   Designated Audubon Certified Golf Courses ­ Atlantic City Country Club and Sanctuary at
   Horseshoe Southern Indiana's Chariot Run Golf Course.
   At its domestic resorts, Caesars Entertainment recycles more than 320,000 gallons of waste
   vegetable oil annually.
   Caesars Entertainment's properties donated more than 140,000 tons of lightly used soap
   and bottled amenities to Clean the World Foundation to be recycled and distributed to
   peoples in need across the world saving lives and diverting waste from landfills.


Sustainability Awards:
Caesars Entertainment Corporation has been recognized with many prestigious honors and
awards for its commitment to the environment and sustainable practices including:
   IMEX/ GMIC "Green Supplier Award" (2012): Caesars was awarded the silver award for its
   sustainable practices and unique approach to engaging its employees in its CodeGreen
   efforts.
   Audubon Cooperative Sanctuary Certification in Environmental Planning (2011):
   Certified the Atlantic City Country Club.
   Sierra Club, Toiyabe Chapter "Corporate Environmental Steward" (2010)
   USGBC Nevada Chapter's "Organizational Excellence Award" (2010)


http://www.caesars.com/corporate/environment-sustainability.html
                                                                                               12/2012
   Travelocity "eco-friendly hotel" certified resorts (2010): Seven of Caesars Las Vegas
   resorts earned the eco-friendly certification designated by a leaf icon on Travelocity's Travel
   Directory.
   Virgin Holidays "Partner in Sustainability Award" (2010): Caesars was selected as one
   of three companies worldwide
   Travelife "Sustainability Gold Level Accreditations" (2009): Seven of Caesars Las
   Vegas Strip casinos and resorts achieved the highest accreditation for their best
   sustainability practices. Caesars is the only gaming entertainment operator in the world to
   receive multiple gold level awards.
   Travelocity Green Hotels: Seven properties were awarded the `green leaf' certification by
   Travelocity for its sustainability efforts.
   EPA WasteWise "Gold Achievement New Partner Award" at Bally's and Paris resorts
   (2008)
   EPA "Regional Environmental Quality Award" (2008): Caesars is the first casino
   entertainment company to win this prestigious award for its Atlantic City Region.


Caesars casinos and resorts have also been recognized for their sustainability work within their
communities including:
   Travelife "Sustainability Gold Level Accreditations" (2012): Harrah's Rincon, Harrah's
   Lake Tahoe Casino and Harvey's Lake Tahoe Casino achieved the highest accreditation for
   their best sustainability practices.
   Blue Ribbon Award: Large Green Business (2012): Harrah's Lake Tahoe Casino and
   Harvey's Lake Tahoe Casino were recognized by the Lake Tahoe Chamber of Commerce
   for their exemplary sustainability efforts.
   Travelife Gold Certification (2012): Harrah's Rincon Casino & Hotel as well as Harrah's
   Lake Tahoe Casino and Harvey's Lake Tahoe Casino received this commendation for their
   responsible business operations that reduce the company's impacts on the environment.
   Douglas Blue Ribbon Award for "Large Green Business" (2012) ­ Harrah's Lake Tahoe
   Casino and Harvey's Lake Tahoe Casino
   "Energy Showcase Award" ­ Harrah's Rincon Casino
   "Certificate of Environmental Stewardship" from the New Jersey Department of
   Environmental Protection ­ Atlantic City Country Club
   U.S. Green Buildings Council Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)
   Silver - Caesars Palace Octavious Convention Center
   "New Jersey Business of the Year" - Caesars Atlantic City Region: Harrah's, Caesars,
   Bally's and Showboat Atlantic City resorts.
   "Green Business of the Year" from the Laughlin Chamber - Harrah's Laughlin Casino &
   Hotel (two-time winner)
   "Golden Pinecone Environmental Award" "Water Hero Award" Water Conservation
   Coalition ­ Northern Nevada regional properties
   "Green Apple Award" Green Organisation ­ London Clubs International
http://www.caesars.com/corporate/environment-sustainability.html
                                                                                            12/2012
History of Sustainability:

2012:
   Harrah's Rincon Casino & Hotel as well as Harrah's Lake Tahoe Casino and Harvey's Lake
   Tahoe Casino received the Travelife Gold Certification recognizing each property's
   responsible business operations are in accordance with its international standards.
   Caesars acquired its 45th sustainability award/certification in four years from IMEX and
   Green Meetings Industry Council for its sustainable practices receiving the silver "Green
   Supplier Award".
   Caesars formally expanded its sustainability structure with a centralized environmental
   compliance manager and sustainable operators director.


2011:
   Caesars Entertainment Corporation joined the United Nations Foundation's Global
   Sustainability Tourism Council, which adheres to its strict transparency policies related to
   sustainable tourism, environmental and social impact practices and public reporting.
   The company develops its "Next Stage" five-year strategy with more aggressive targets
   around carbon, energy, water, waste and social metrics (employee and guest).


2010:
   Caesars Entertainment Corporation (then Harrah's Entertainment, Inc.) incorporated
   environmental sustainability into its Code of Commitment - the industry-leading pledge of
   corporate responsibility to Caesars guests, employees, and to the communities where it
   operates - in the form of its corporate initiative CodeGreen.
   The company determines its domestic carbon footprint, publicly announces carbon reduction
   goals, and publishes a GRI influenced sustainability report ­ the first of its kind for the
   gaming industry.
   The Caesars Foundation updates its giving strategy to focus on environmental sustainability
   for regional gifts.
   The company develops the industry's first meeting and convention planner Green Meetings
   and Events Certification Programs and certifies 200 managers on developing and managing
   more sustainable meetings.

2009:
   Caesars became the first global gaming company to join the EPA's Waste Wise to manage
   waste reduction and recycling programs. Its Bally's and Paris Las Vegas properties later
   garnered a New Partner Gold Medal award for its recycling and employee engagement
   programs.

   Caesars' Las Vegas properties are audited by Travelife Sustainability ­ a global social-
   environmental accreditation body organized by (then) Federation of Tour Operators. Of the


http://www.caesars.com/corporate/environment-sustainability.html
                                                                                           12/2012
   eight properties audited, it received seven gold medals and one silver ­ making Caesars
   Entertainment the most accredited gaming entertainment company.


2008:
   Caesars Entertainment Corporation (then Harrah's Entertainment, Inc.) developed a
   comprehensive sustainability strategy; CodeGreen that focuses on operational efficiencies
   through large scale investments and grassroots employee engagement.


   Caesars became the first casino company to join the EPA's Climate Leaders industry-
   government partnership of leading firms committed to targeted, measurable reductions in
   greenhouse gas emissions.


2003:
   Caesars established a commitment to conservation with the formation of its Corporate
   Energy & Environmental Services, a corporate-level function to identify and implement
   energy and water conservation projects across Caesars portfolio of resorts.




http://www.caesars.com/corporate/environment-sustainability.html
                                                                                       12/2012
